P1para.Text: If a short-term detention certificate is granted in respect of a patient who is subject to an emergency detention certificate, the emergency detention certificate shall, on the granting of the short-term detention certificate, be revoked.

P2para.Text: Subsection (2) below applies where

P3para.Text: a patient is subject to a relevant order; and
a short-term detention certificate is granted in respect of the patient.

Text.Substitution: A relevant order shall cease to authorise the measures specified in it for the period during which the patient is subject to
the short-term detention certificate, or
an extension certificate.

Text.Addition: In this section, the references to a relevant order are to
a compulsion order, or
a compulsory treatment order or an interim compulsory treatment order.

Chapter.Title: Application for, and making of, orders

P1group.Title: Mental health officers duty to apply for compulsory treatment order

P2para.Text: Where subsections (2) to (5) below apply in relation to a patient, a mental health officer shall apply to the Tribunal under section 63 of this Act for a compulsory treatment order in respect of that patient.
This subsection applies where two medical practitioners carry out medical examinations of the patient in accordance with the requirements of section 58 of this Act.
This subsection applies where each of the medical practitioners who carries out a medical examination mentioned in subsection (2) above is satisfied

P3para.Text: that the patient has a mental disorder;
that medical treatment which would be likely to

P4para.Text: prevent the mental disorder worsening; or
alleviate any of the symptoms, or effects, of the disorder,

P3para.Text: is available for the patient;
that if the patient were not provided with such medical treatment there would be a significant risk

P4para.Text: to the health, safety or welfare of the patient; or
to the safety of any other person;

P3para.Text: that because of the mental disorder the patients ability to make decisions about the provision of such medical treatment is significantly impaired; and
that the making of a compulsory treatment order is necessary.

P2para.Text: This subsection applies where each of the medical practitioners who carries out a medical examination mentioned in subsection (2) above submits to the mental health officer a report (any such report being referred to in this Act as a mental health report)

P3para.Text: stating that the medical practitioner submitting the report is satisfied that the conditions mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (e) of subsection (3) above are met in respect of the patient;

stating, in relation to each of the conditions mentioned in paragraphs (b) to (e) of subsection (3) above, the medical practitioners reasons for believing the condition to be met in respect of the patient;
specifying (by reference to the appropriate paragraph (or paragraphs) of the definition of mental disorder in section 328(1) of this Act) the type (or types) of mental disorder that the patient has;
setting out a description of

P4para.Text: the symptoms that the patient has of the mental disorder; and
the ways in which the patient is affected by the mental disorder;

P3para.Text: specifying the measures that should, in the medical practitioners opinion, be authorised by the compulsory treatment order;
specifying the date or dates on which the medical practitioner carried out the medical examination mentioned in subsection (2) above; and
setting out any other information that the medical practitioner considers to be relevant.

P2para.Text: This subsection applies where

P3para.Text: for the purposes of subsection (4)(c) above each of the mental health reports specifies at least one type of mental disorder that is also specified in the other report;
for the purposes of subsection (4)(e) above each of the mental health reports specifies the same measures; and
one of the mental health reports (being a report by an approved medical practitioner) states the views of that medical practitioner as to

P4para.Text: subject to subsection (6) below, whether notice should be given to the patient under section 60(1)(a) of this Act; and
whether the patient is capable of arranging for a person to represent the patient in connection with the application under section 63 of this Act.

P2para.Text: A medical practitioner may state the view that notice should not be given under section 60(1)(a) of this Act only if, in the opinion of that medical practitioner, the giving of notice would be likely to cause significant harm to the patient or any other person.

Where a mental health officer is required by subsection (1) above to make an application for a compulsory treatment order, the mental health officer shall make the application before the expiry of the period of 14 days beginning with

P3para.Text: in the case where each of the mental health reports specifies the same date (or dates) for the purposes of subsection (4)(f) above, that date (or the later, or latest, of those dates); or
in the case where each of those reports specifies for those purposes a different date (or different dates), the later (or latest) of those dates.

P1group.Title: Medical examination: requirements

P2para.Text: The requirements referred to in section 57(2) of this Act are set out in subsections (2) to (6) below.
Subject to subsection (4) below and to regulations under subsection (5) below

P3para.Text: each medical examination of the patient shall be carried out by an approved medical practitioner; and
subject to subsection (6) below, each such examination shall be carried out separately.

P2para.Text: Where the medical examinations are carried out separately, the second shall be completed no more than five days after the first.
The patients general medical practitioner may carry out one of the medical examinations of the patient although not an approved medical practitioner.
The medical examinations need not be carried out separately if

P3para.Text: where the patient is capable of consenting to the examinations, the patient consents to the examinations being carried out at the same time; or
where the patient is incapable of consenting to the examinations

P4para.Text: the patients named person;
any guardian of the patient; or
any welfare attorney of the patient,

P3para.Text: consents to the examinations being carried out at the same time.

P1group.Title: Mental health officers duty to identify named person

P1para.Text: Where a mental health officer is required by 57(1) of this Act to make an application under section 63 of this Act in respect of a patient, the mental health officer shall, as soon as practicable after the duty to make the application arises, take such steps as are reasonably practicable to ascertain the name and address of the patients named person.

P1group.Title: Application for compulsory treatment order: notification

P2para.Text: Where a mental health officer is required by section 57(1) of this Act to make an application under section 63 of this Act in respect of a patient, the mental health officer shall, as soon as practicable after the duty to make the application arises (and, in any event, before making the application) give notice that the application is to be made

P3para.Text: subject to subsection (2) below, to the patient in respect of whom the application is to be made;
to the patients named person; and
to the Commission.

P2para.Text: If the view set out in one of the mental health reports by virtue of section 57(5)(c) of this Act is that notice should not be given under paragraph (a) of subsection (1) above, the mental health officer

P3para.Text: need not give such notice; but
may, if the mental health officer considers it appropriate to do so, give such notice.

P1group.Title: Mental health officers duty to prepare report

P2para.Text: This section applies where a mental health officer is required by section 57(1) of this Act to make an application under section 63 of this Act in respect of a patient.
The mental health officer shall, before the date on which, by virtue of section 57(7) of this Act, the application is to be made

P3para.Text: subject to subsection (3) below, interview the patient;
if the patient has not been given notice under section 60(1)(a) of this Act, inform the patient that the application is to be made;
inform the patient of

P4para.Text: the patients rights in relation to the application; and
the availability of independent advocacy services under section 259 of this Act;

P3para.Text: take appropriate steps to ensure that the patient has the opportunity of making use of those services; and
prepare in relation to the patient a report in accordance with subsection (4) below.

P2para.Text: If it is impracticable for the mental health officer to comply with the requirement in subsection (2)(a) above, the mental health officer need not do so.
The report shall state

P3para.Text: the name and address of the patient;
if known by the mental health officer, the name and address of

P4para.Text: the patients named person; and
the patients primary carer;

P3para.Text: the steps that the mental health officer has taken in pursuance of the requirements imposed by subsection (2) above;
if it was impracticable for the mental health officer to comply with the requirement in subsection (2)(a) above, the reason for that being the case;
in so far as relevant for the purposes of the application, details of the personal circumstances of the patient;
the mental health officers views on the mental health reports relating to the patient;
if known by the mental health officer, details of any advance statement that the patient has made (and not withdrawn); and
any other information that the mental health officer considers relevant to the determination by the Tribunal of the application.

P1group.Title: Mental health officers duty to prepare proposed care plan

P2para.Text: This section applies where a mental health officer is required by section 57(1) of this Act to make an application under section 63 of this Act in respect of a patient.
The mental health officer shall, before the date on which, by virtue of section 57(7) of this Act, the application is to be made, prepare a plan (a proposed care plan) relating to the patient.
Before preparing the proposed care plan, the mental health officer shall consult

P3para.Text: the medical practitioners who provided the mental health reports relating to the patient;
subject to subsection (7) below, the persons mentioned in subsection (4) below; and
such other persons as the mental health officer considers appropriate.

P2para.Text: The persons referred to in subsection (3)(b) above are persons who appear to the mental health officer to provide

P3para.Text: medical treatment of the kind that it is proposed to specify, by virtue of paragraph (d) of subsection (5) below, in the proposed care plan;
community care services, or relevant services, of the kind that it is proposed to specify, by virtue of paragraph (e) of that subsection, in that plan; or
other treatment, care or services of the kind that it is proposed to specify, by virtue of paragraph (f) of that subsection, in that plan.

P2para.Text: The proposed care plan shall specify

P3para.Text: (by reference to the appropriate paragraph (or paragraphs) of the definition of mental disorder in section 328(1) of this Act), the type (or types) of mental disorder which the patient has;
the needs of the patient for medical treatment that have been assessed by the medical practitioners who submitted the mental health reports relating to the patient;
in so far as relevant for the purposes of the application

P4para.Text: where the patient is a child, the needs of the patient that have been assessed under section 23(3) of the Children (Scotland) Act 1995 (c. 36);
where the patient is not a child, the needs of the patient that have been assessed under section 12A(1)(a) of the Social Work (Scotland) Act 1968 (c. 49);

P3para.Text: the medical treatment which it is proposed to give to the patient in relation to each of the needs specified by virtue of paragraph (b) above (including the names of the persons who would give the treatment and the addresses at which the treatment would be given);

any community care services or relevant services which it is proposed to provide to the patient in relation to each of the needs specified by virtue of paragraph (c) above (including the names of the persons who would provide such services and the addresses at which such services would be provided);
in so far as relevant for the purposes of the application

P4para.Text: any treatment or care (other than treatment or care specified, by virtue of paragraph (d) above, in the proposed care plan); or
any service (other than a service specified, by virtue of paragraph (e) above, in the proposed care plan),

P3para.Text: which it is proposed to provide to the patient (including the names of the persons who would provide such treatment, care or service and the addresses at which such treatment, care or service would be provided);
which of the measures mentioned in section 66(1) of this Act it is proposed that the compulsory treatment order should authorise;
where it is proposed that the compulsory treatment order should authorise the detention of the patient in hospital, the name and address of the hospital;
where it is proposed that the compulsory treatment order should authorise any of the measures mentioned in section 66(1)(c) to (h) of this Act, details of the measure (or measures);
where it is proposed that the compulsory treatment order should specify

P4para.Text: any medical treatment specified, by virtue of paragraph (d) above, in the proposed care plan;
any community care services, or relevant services, specified, by virtue of paragraph (e) above, in the proposed care plan; or
any treatment, care or service specified, by virtue of paragraph (f) above, in the proposed care plan,

P3para.Text: that medical treatment, those services or that treatment, care, or service, as the case may be;

where it is proposed that the compulsory treatment order should authorise measures other than the detention of the patient in hospital, the name of the hospital the managers of which should have responsibility for appointing the patients responsible medical officer; and
the objectives of

P4para.Text: the medical treatment which it is proposed, by virtue of paragraph (d) above, to give to the patient;
any community care services or relevant services which it is proposed, by virtue of paragraph (e) above, to provide to the patient;
any treatment, care or service which, by virtue of paragraph (f) above, it is proposed to provide to the patient; and
the measures (other than detention of the patient in hospital) that it is proposed that the compulsory treatment order should authorise.

P2para.Text: The proposed care plan shall be signed by the mental health officer.
The mental health officer need not consult any person such as is mentioned in subsection (4) above in any case where it is impracticable to do so.
In this section child has the same meaning as in section 23(3) of the Children (Scotland) Act 1995 (c. 36).

P1group.Title: Application for compulsory treatment order

P2para.Text: An application to the Tribunal for a compulsory treatment order may be made by, and only by, a mental health officer.
An application

P3para.Text: shall specify

P4para.Text: the measures that are sought in relation to the patient in respect of whom the application is made;
any medical treatment, community care services, relevant services or other treatment, care or service specified in the proposed care plan by virtue of section 62(5)(j) of this Act; and

where it is proposed that the order should authorise measures other than the detention of the patient in hospital, the name of the hospital the managers of which should have responsibility for appointing the patients responsible medical officer; and

P3para.Text: shall be accompanied by the documents that are mentioned in subsection (3) below.

P2para.Text: Those documents are

P3para.Text: the mental health reports;
the report prepared under section 61 of this Act; and
the proposed care plan,

P2para.Text: relating to the patient.

P1group.Title: Powers of Tribunal on application under section 63: compulsory treatment order

P2para.Text: This section applies where an application is made under section 63 of this Act.
Before determining the application, the Tribunal shall afford the persons mentioned in subsection (3) below the opportunity

P3para.Text: of making representations (whether orally or in writing); and
of leading, or producing, evidence.

P2para.Text: Those persons are

P3para.Text: the patient;
the patients named person;
any guardian of the patient;
any welfare attorney of the patient;
the mental health officer;
the medical practitioners who submitted the mental health reports which accompany the application;
if the patient has a responsible medical officer, that officer;
the patients primary carer;
any curator ad litem appointed in respect of the patient by the Tribunal; and
any other person appearing to the Tribunal to have an interest in the application.

P2para.Text: The Tribunal may

P3para.Text: if satisfied that all of the conditions mentioned in subsection (5) below are met, make an order

P4para.Text: authorising, for the period of 6 months beginning with the day on which the order is made, such of the measures mentioned in section 66(1) of this Act as may be specified in the order;

specifying such medical treatment, community care services, relevant services, other treatment, care or service as the Tribunal considers appropriate (any such medical treatment, community care services, relevant services, other treatment, care or service so specified being referred to in this Act as a recorded matter);

recording (by reference to the appropriate paragraph (or paragraphs) of the definition of mental disorder in section 328(1) of this Act) the type (or types) of mental disorder that the patient has; and

if the order does not authorise the detention of the patient in hospital, specifying the name of the hospital the managers of which are to have responsibility for appointing the patients responsible medical officer; or

P3para.Text: refuse the application.

P2para.Text: The conditions referred to in subsection (4)(a) above are

P3para.Text: that the patient has a mental disorder;
that medical treatment which would be likely to

P4para.Text: prevent the mental disorder worsening; or
alleviate any of the symptoms, or effects, of the disorder,

P3para.Text: is available for the patient;
that if the patient were not provided with such medical treatment there would be a significant risk

P4para.Text: to the health, safety or welfare of the patient; or
to the safety of any other person;

P3para.Text: that because of the mental disorder the patients ability to make decisions about the provision of such medical treatment is significantly impaired;
that the making of a compulsory treatment order in respect of the patient is necessary; and
where the Tribunal does not consider it necessary for the patient to be detained in hospital, such other conditions as may be specified in regulations.

P2para.Text: Subject to subsection (7) below, an order under subsection (4)(a) above may, in addition to, or instead of, specifying some or all of the measures sought in the application to which the order relates, specify measures other than those set out in that application.
The Tribunal may specify in the order under subsection (4)(a) above measures other than those set out in the application only if, before making the order

P3para.Text: subject to subsection (8) below, the Tribunal gives notice to the persons mentioned in subsection (3) above

P4para.Text: stating what it is proposing to do; and
setting out what those measures are;

P3para.Text: the Tribunal affords those persons the opportunity

P4para.Text: of making representations (whether orally or in writing) in relation to the proposal; and
of leading, or producing, evidence.

P2para.Text: Where the duty under subsection (7)(a) above arises during a hearing of the application, notice need not be given under that subsection to any person mentioned in subsection (3) above who is present at the hearing.
Before making regulations under subsection (5)(f) above, the Scottish Ministers shall consult such persons as they consider appropriate.

P1group.Title: Powers of Tribunal on application under section 63: interim compulsory treatment order

P2para.Text: This section applies where an application is made under section 63 of this Act.

Subject to subsections (3) and (4) below and to section 69 of this Act, on the application of any person having an interest in the proceedings, or ex proprio motu, the Tribunal may, if satisfied as to the matters mentioned in subsection (6) below, make an order (an interim compulsory treatment order)

P3para.Text: authorising for such period not exceeding 28 days as may be specified in the order such of the measures mentioned in section 66(1) of this Act as may be so specified; and

if the order does not authorise the detention of the patient in hospital, specifying the name of the hospital the managers of which are to have responsibility for appointing the patients responsible medical officer.

P2para.Text: The Tribunal may not make an interim compulsory treatment order if its effect, when taken with any other interim compulsory treatment order made in respect of the patient, would be to authorise measures in respect of the patient for a continuous period of more than 56 days.
Before making an interim compulsory treatment order, the Tribunal shall afford the persons mentioned in subsection (5) below the opportunity

P3para.Text: of making representations (whether orally or in writing); and
of leading, or producing, evidence.

P2para.Text: Those persons are

P3para.Text: the persons referred to in section 64(3)(a) to (e) and (g) to (i) of this Act;
the medical practitioners who submitted the mental health reports which accompany the application under section 63 of this Act; and
any other person appearing to the Tribunal to have an interest in that application.

P2para.Text: The matters referred to in subsection (2) above are

P3para.Text: that the conditions mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (d) of section 64(5) of this Act are met in respect of the patient; and
that it is necessary to make an interim compulsory treatment order.

P1group.Title: Measures that may be authorised

P2para.Text: Subject to subsection (2) below, the measures referred to in sections 64(4)(a)(i) and 65(2)(a) of this Act are

P3para.Text: the detention of the patient in the specified hospital;
the giving to the patient, in accordance with Part 16 of this Act, of medical treatment;
the imposition of a requirement on the patient to attend

P4para.Text: on specified or directed dates; or
at specified or directed intervals,

P3para.Text: specified or directed places with a view to receiving medical treatment;
the imposition of a requirement on the patient to attend

P4para.Text: on specified or directed dates; or
at specified or directed intervals,

P3para.Text: specified or directed places with a view to receiving community care services, relevant services or any treatment, care or service;
the imposition of a requirement on the patient to reside at a specified place;
the imposition of a requirement on the patient to allow

P4para.Text: the mental health officer;
the patients responsible medical officer; or

any person responsible for providing medical treatment, community care services, relevant services or any treatment, care or service to the patient who is authorised for the purposes of this paragraph by the patients responsible medical officer,

P3para.Text: to visit the patient in the place where the patient resides;
the imposition of a requirement on the patient to obtain the approval of the mental health officer to any proposed change of address; and
the imposition of a requirement on the patient to inform the mental health officer of any change of address before the change takes effect.

P2para.Text: Regulations may make provision for measures prescribed by the regulations to be treated as included among the measures mentioned in subsection (1) above.
In this section

Para.Text: directed means in accordance with directions given by the patients responsible medical officer; and
specified means specified in the compulsory treatment order or, as the case may be, the interim compulsory treatment order.

P1group.Title: Order authorising detention: ancillary authorisation

P2para.Text: Where a compulsory treatment order or an interim compulsory treatment order

P3para.Text: authorises the detention of a patient in a hospital specified in the order; or
imposes a requirement on a patient to reside at a place specified in the order,

P2para.Text: this section authorises the removal, before the expiry of the period of 7 days beginning with the appropriate day, of the patient in respect of whom the order is made to that hospital or, as the case may be, place.
In subsection (1) above, appropriate day means the day on which

P3para.Text: a compulsory treatment order or, as the case may be, an interim compulsory treatment order authorising detention of a patient in hospital is made; or
a compulsory treatment order is varied so as to authorise the detention of a patient in the hospital specified in the order.

Title.Emphasis: Extension of short-term detention: special case

P1group.Title: Extension of short-term detention pending determination of application

P2para.Text: Where

P3para.Text: the detention of a patient in hospital is authorised by

P4para.Text: a short-term detention certificate; or
an extension certificate; and

P3para.Text: before the expiry of the period of detention so authorised, an application is made under section 63 of this Act,

P2para.Text: the measures mentioned in subsection (2) below are authorised.
Those measures are

P3para.Text: the detention in hospital of the patient for the period of 5 days beginning with the expiry of the period for which the certificate authorises the detention of the patient in hospital; and
the giving to the patient, in accordance with Part 16 of this Act, of medical treatment.

P2para.Text: In reckoning the period of days mentioned in subsection (2)(a) above, there shall be left out of account any day which is not a working day.
In this section working day has the meaning given by section 47(8) of this Act.

Title.Emphasis: Time limit for Tribunals determination: special case

P1group.Title: Time limit for determining application etc. where section 68 applies

P1para.Text: Where section 68 of this Act applies, the Tribunal shall, before the expiry of the period of 5 days referred to in section 68(2)(a) of this Act

P3para.Text: determine whether an interim compulsory treatment order should be made; and
if it determines that an interim compulsory treatment order should not be made, determine the application.

Title.Emphasis: Effect of making of orders on short-term detention

P1group.Title: Effect of subsequent order on short-term detention certificate

P1para.Text: If a compulsory treatment order, or an interim compulsory treatment order, is made in respect of a patient who is in hospital under authority of a short-term detention certificate, the certificate shall, on the making of the order, be revoked.

Title.Emphasis: Application of Chapter where patient subject to hospital direction or transfer for treatment direction

P1group.Title: Application of Chapter where patient subject to hospital direction or transfer for treatment direction

P1para.Text: Where a patient is subject to

P3para.Text: a hospital direction; or
a transfer for treatment direction,

P1para.Text: this Chapter shall have effect in accordance with schedule 3 to this Act.

Title.Addition: Compulsory treatment in hospital unit

Text.Addition: In sections 62 to 68 of this Act, a reference to a hospital may be read as a reference to a hospital unit.
For the purposes of subsection (1) above,
means any part of a hospital which is treated as a separate unit.

Chapter.Title: Interim compulsory treatment orders: review and revocation

P1group.Title: Interim compulsory treatment order: responsible medical officers duty to keep under review

P2para.Text: Where a patient is subject to an interim compulsory treatment order, the patients responsible medical officer shall from time to time consider

P3para.Text: whether the conditions mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (d) of section 64(5) of this Act continue to apply in respect of the patient; and
whether it continues to be necessary for the patient to be subject to an interim compulsory treatment order.

P2para.Text: If, having considered the matters mentioned in paragraphs (a) and (b) of subsection (1) above, the responsible medical officer is not satisfied

P3para.Text: that the conditions mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (d) of section 64(5) of this Act continue to apply in respect of the patient; or
that it continues to be necessary for the patient to be subject to an interim compulsory treatment order,

P2para.Text: the responsible medical officer shall make a determination revoking the interim compulsory treatment order.
A determination under this section shall be made as soon as practicable after the duty to make it arises.

P1group.Title: Commissions power to revoke interim compulsory treatment order

P2para.Text: This section applies where a patient is subject to an interim compulsory treatment order.
If the Commission is satisfied

P3para.Text: that not all of the conditions mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (d) of section 64(5) of this Act continue to apply in respect of the patient; or
that it does not continue to be necessary for the patient to be subject to an interim compulsory treatment order,

P2para.Text: the Commission may revoke the interim compulsory treatment order.

P1group.Title: Revocation under section 72 or 73: notification

P2para.Text: Where a patients responsible medical officer makes a determination under section 72 of this Act, the responsible medical officer shall, as soon as practicable after doing so

P3para.Text: give notice of the determination; and
send a statement of the reasons for it,

P2para.Text: to the Commission and to the persons mentioned in subsection (3) below.
Where the Commission makes a determination under section 73 of this Act, it shall, as soon as practicable after doing so

P3para.Text: give notice of the determination; and
send a statement of the reasons for it,

P2para.Text: to the patients responsible medical officer and to the persons mentioned in subsection (3) below.
The persons referred to in subsections (1) and (2) above are

P3para.Text: the patient;
the patients named person;
any guardian of the patient;
any welfare attorney of the patient;
the mental health officer; and
the Tribunal.

P1group.Title: Effect of subsequent compulsory treatment order on interim compulsory treatment order

P1para.Text: If a compulsory treatment order is made in respect of a patient who is subject to an interim compulsory treatment order, the interim compulsory treatment order shall, on the making of the compulsory treatment order, be revoked.

P1group.Title: Care plan: preparation, placing in medical records etc.

Text.Addition: This section applies where a compulsory treatment order is made in respect of a patient.

P2para.Text: As soon as practicable after a patients responsible medical officer is appointed under section 230 of this Act, the responsible medical officer shall

P3para.Text: prepare a plan (any such plan being referred to in this Act as a care plan) relating to the patient; and
ensure that the patients care plan is included in the patients medical records.

P2para.Text: The care plan shall set out

P3para.Text: the medical treatment

P4para.Text: which it is proposed to give; and
which is being given,

P3para.Text: to the patient while the patient is subject to the compulsory treatment order; and
such other information relating to the care of the patient as may be prescribed by regulations.

P2para.Text: Subject to subsection (4)(b) below, a patients responsible medical officer may from time to time amend the patients care plan.
Regulations may prescribe

P3para.Text: circumstances in which a patients responsible medical officer is required to amend the patients care plan;
information in a care plan which may not be amended.

P2para.Text: Where a patients responsible medical officer amends the patients care plan

P3para.Text: the responsible medical officer shall ensure that, as soon as practicable after it is amended, the amended care plan is included in the patients medical records; and
subsections (2) to (4) above and this subsection shall apply as if references to the care plan were references to the amended care plan.

Title.Emphasis: Mandatory reviews by responsible medical officer

P1group.Title: First mandatory review

P2para.Text: This section applies where a compulsory treatment order is made in respect of a patient.

The patients responsible medical officer shall, during the appropriate period, carry out a review in respect of the order (such review being referred to in this Part of this Act as the first review) by complying with the requirements in subsection (3) below.
Those requirements are

P3para.Text: to

P4para.Text: carry out a medical examination of the patient; or
make arrangements for an approved medical practitioner to carry out such a medical examination;

P3para.Text: to consider

P4para.Text: whether the conditions mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (d) of section 64(5) of this Act continue to apply in respect of the patient; and
whether it continues to be necessary for the patient to be subject to a compulsory treatment order; and

P3para.Text: to consult

P4para.Text: the mental health officer;
such persons as are mentioned in subsection (4) below as the responsible medical officer considers appropriate; and
such other persons as the responsible medical officer considers appropriate.

P2para.Text: The persons referred to in subsection (3)(c)(ii) above are

P3para.Text: persons who appear to the responsible medical officer to provide medical treatment of the kind that is set out in the patients care plan;
if any community care services or relevant services are set out in that plan, persons who appear to the responsible medical officer to provide services of that kind;
if any other treatment, care or service is set out in that plan, persons who appear to the responsible medical officer to provide treatment, care or a service of that kind.

P2para.Text: In subsection (2) above, appropriate period means the period of 2 months ending with the day on which the compulsory treatment order ceases to authorise the measures specified in it.

P1group.Title: Further mandatory reviews

P2para.Text: This section applies where a compulsory treatment order is extended

P3para.Text: by a determination under section 86 of this Act; or
by virtue of an order under section 103 of this Act.

P2para.Text: The patients responsible medical officer shall, during the period mentioned in subsection (3) below, carry out a review in respect of the compulsory treatment order (such review being referred to in this Part of this Act as a further review) by complying with the requirements set out in section 77(3) of this Act.

The period referred to in subsection (2) above is the period of 2 months ending with the day on which the compulsory treatment order as extended by the determination, or by virtue of the order under section 103 of this Act, ceases to authorise the measures specified in it.

Title.Emphasis: Revocation of order by responsible medical officer or Commission

P1group.Title: Responsible medical officers duty to revoke order: mandatory reviews

P2para.Text: This section applies where a patients responsible medical officer is carrying out

P3para.Text: the first review of the compulsory treatment order to which the patient is subject; or
a further review of that order.

P2para.Text: If, having regard to any views expressed by persons consulted under section 77(3)(c) of this Act for the purpose of the review being carried out, the responsible medical officer is not satisfied

P3para.Text: that the conditions mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (d) of section 64(5) of this Act continue to apply in respect of the patient; or
that it continues to be necessary for the patient to be subject to a compulsory treatment order,

P2para.Text: the responsible medical officer shall make a determination revoking the compulsory treatment order.
A determination under this section shall be made as soon as practicable after the duty to make it arises.

P1group.Title: Revocation of order: responsible medical officers duty to keep under review

P2para.Text: This section applies where a patient is subject to a compulsory treatment order.

Without prejudice to the duties imposed on the patients responsible medical officer by sections 77(2), 78(2), 79(2) and 93(2) of this Act, the responsible medical officer shall from time to time consider

P3para.Text: whether the conditions mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (d) of section 64(5) of this Act continue to apply in respect of the patient; and
whether it continues to be necessary for the patient to be subject to a compulsory treatment order.

P2para.Text: If, having considered the matters mentioned in paragraphs (a) and (b) of subsection (2) above, the responsible medical officer is not satisfied

P3para.Text: that the conditions mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (d) of section 64(5) of this Act continue to apply in respect of the patient; or
that it continues to be necessary for the patient to be subject to a compulsory treatment order,

P2para.Text: the responsible medical officer shall make a determination revoking the compulsory treatment order.
A determination under this section shall be made as soon as practicable after the duty to make it arises.

P1group.Title: Commissions power to revoke order

P2para.Text: This section applies where a patient is subject to a compulsory treatment order.
If the Commission is satisfied

P3para.Text: that not all of the conditions mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (d) of section 64(5) of this Act continue to apply in respect of the patient; or
that it does not continue to be necessary for the patient to be subject to a compulsory treatment order,

P2para.Text: it may make a determination revoking the compulsory treatment order.

P1group.Title: Revocation of order: notification

P2para.Text: Where a patients responsible medical officer makes a determination under section 79 or 80 of this Act, that officer shall

P3para.Text: give notice of the determination; and
send a statement of the reasons for it,

P2para.Text: to the Commission and to the persons mentioned in subsection (3) below.
Where the Commission makes a determination under section 81 of this Act, it shall

P3para.Text: give notice of the determination; and
send a statement of the reasons for it,

P2para.Text: to the patients responsible medical officer and to the persons mentioned in subsection (3) below.
The persons referred to in subsections (1) and (2) above are

P3para.Text: the patient;
the patients named person;
any guardian of the patient;
any welfare attorney of the patient;
the mental health officer; and
the Tribunal.

P2para.Text: Notice under subsection (1) or (2) above

P3para.Text: to the persons mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (d) of subsection (3) above shall be given as soon as practicable after the determination is made and, in any event, before the expiry of the period of 7 days beginning with the day on which the determination is made; and
to

P4para.Text: the Commission;
the patients responsible medical officer; and
the persons mentioned in paragraphs (e) and (f) of that subsection,

P3para.Text: shall be given before the expiry of the period of 7 days beginning with the day on which the determination is made.

Title.Emphasis: Further steps to be taken where order not revoked

P1group.Title: Mandatory reviews: further steps to be taken where order not revoked

P2para.Text: This section applies where a patients responsible medical officer is carrying out

P3para.Text: the first review of the compulsory treatment order to which the patient is subject; or
a further review of that order.

P2para.Text: If, having regard to any views expressed by persons consulted under section 77(3)(c) of this Act for the purpose of the review being carried out, the patients responsible medical officer is satisfied

P3para.Text: that the conditions mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (d) of section 64(5) of this Act continue to apply in respect of the patient; and
that it continues to be necessary for the patient to be subject to a compulsory treatment order,

P2para.Text: the responsible medical officer shall comply with the requirements in subsection (3) below.
Those requirements are

P3para.Text: to consider whether it will continue to be necessary for the patient to be subject to a compulsory treatment order after the day on which the order to which the patient is subject will cease (unless extended) to authorise the measures specified in it;
to assess the needs of the patient for medical treatment;
to consider

P4para.Text: whether the compulsory treatment order should be varied by modifying the measures, or any recorded matter, specified in it; and
if the order should be varied, what modification is appropriate;

P3para.Text: to consider any views expressed on the matters mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (c) above by persons consulted under section 77(3)(c) of this Act.

Title.Emphasis: Extension of order by responsible medical officer

P1group.Title: Responsible medical officers duty where extension of order appears appropriate

P2para.Text: This section applies where a patients responsible medical officer is carrying out

P3para.Text: the first review of the compulsory treatment order to which the patient is subject; or
a further review of that order.

P2para.Text: If, having regard to any views expressed by persons consulted under section 77(3)(c) of this Act for the purpose of the review being carried out, it appears to the responsible medical officer

P3para.Text: that it will continue to be necessary for the patient to be subject to a compulsory treatment order after the day on which the order will cease (unless extended) to authorise the measures specified in it; and
that the order should not be varied by modifying the measures, or any recorded matter, specified in it,

P2para.Text: the responsible medical officer shall give notice to the mental health officer that the responsible medical officer is proposing to make a determination under section 86 of this Act extending the order.

P1group.Title: Mental health officers duties: extension of order

P2para.Text: The mental health officer shall, as soon as practicable after receiving notice under section 84(2) of this Act, comply with the requirements in subsection (2) below.
Those requirements are

P3para.Text: subject to subsection (3) below, to interview the patient;
to inform the patient

P4para.Text: that the patients responsible medical officer is proposing to make a determination under section 86 of this Act extending the compulsory treatment order to which the patient is subject for the period mentioned in section 86(2) of this Act;
of the patients rights in relation to such a determination; and
of the availability of independent advocacy services under section 259 of this Act;

P3para.Text: to take appropriate steps to ensure that the patient has the opportunity of making use of those services; and
to inform the patients responsible medical officer

P4para.Text: of whether the mental health officer agrees, or disagrees, that the determination that is proposed should be made;
if the mental health officer disagrees, of the reason why that is the case; and
of any other matters that the mental health officer considers relevant.

P2para.Text: If it is impracticable for the mental health officer to comply with the requirement in subsection (2)(a) above, the mental health officer need not do so.

P1group.Title: Responsible medical officers duty to extend order

P2para.Text: If, having regard to

P3para.Text: any views expressed by persons consulted under section 77(3)(c) of this Act for the purpose of the review being carried out; and
any views expressed by the mental health officer under section 85(2)(d) of this Act for the purpose of that review,

P2para.Text: the responsible medical officer is satisfied as to the matters mentioned in section 84(2)(a) and (b) of this Act, the responsible medical officer shall make a determination extending the compulsory treatment order for the period mentioned in subsection (2) below.
The period referred to in subsection (1) above is

P3para.Text: where a determination is made in respect of the first review, the period of 6 months beginning with the day on which the compulsory treatment order will cease (unless extended) to authorise the measures specified in it;
where a determination is made in respect of the first further review, the period of 12 months beginning with the expiry of the period mentioned in paragraph (a) above;

where a determination is made in respect of a subsequent further review, the period of 12 months beginning with the expiry of the period of 12 months for which the order is extended as a result of the immediately preceding further review.

P1group.Title: Determination extending order: notification etc.

P2para.Text: Where a patients responsible medical officer makes a determination under section 86 of this Act, that officer shall, as soon as practicable after the determination is made and, in any event, before the day on which the compulsory treatment order will cease, if it is not extended by the determination, to authorise the measures specified in it, comply with the requirements in subsection (2) below.
Those requirements are

P3para.Text: to prepare a record stating

P4para.Text: the determination;
the reasons for it;
whether the mental health officer agrees, or disagrees, with the determination or has failed to comply with the duty imposed by section 85(2)(d)(i) of this Act;
if the mental health officer disagrees with the determination, the reasons for the disagreement;

(by reference to the appropriate paragraph (or paragraphs) of the definition of mental disorder in section 328(1) of this Act) the type (or types) of mental disorder that the patient has; and if there is a difference between that type (or types) and the type (or types) of mental disorder recorded in the compulsory treatment order in respect of which the determination is made, what that difference is; and
such other matters as may be prescribed by regulations;

P3para.Text: to submit the record to the Tribunal; and
at the same time as the responsible medical officer submits the record to the Tribunal, to give notice of the determination and send a copy of the record

P4para.Text: subject to subsection (3) below, to the patient;
to the patients named person;
to the mental health officer; and
to the Commission.

P2para.Text: If the responsible medical officer considers that there would be a risk of significant harm to the patient, or to others, if a copy of the record were sent to the patient, that officer need not send a copy to the patient.

At the same time as the responsible medical officer submits the record to the Tribunal, that officer shall send to the Tribunal, and to the persons mentioned in subsection (2)(c)(ii) to (iv) above, a statement of the matters mentioned in subsection (5) below.
Those matters are

P3para.Text: whether the responsible medical officer is sending a copy of the record to the patient; and
if the responsible medical officer is not sending a copy of the record to the patient, the reason for not doing so.

Title.Addition: Further information where order extended

Text.Addition: Subsections (2) and (3) below apply where
a mental health officer receives notice of a determination under section 86 of this Act from a patient's responsible medical officer, and
the Tribunal is required by virtue of section 101(2)(a) of this Act to review the determination.
The mental health officer must
prepare a record stating the information mentioned in subsection (4) below,
submit the record to the Tribunal, and
at the same time as submitting the record to the Tribunal, send to the persons mentioned in subsection (6) below
a copy of the record, and
a statement of the matters mentioned in subsection (5) below.

At the same time as submitting the record to the Tribunal, the mental health officer must send a copy of the record to the patient except where the officer considers that doing so carries a risk of significant harm to the patient or others.
The information to be stated in the record is
the name and address of the patient,
if known by the mental health officer, the name and address of
the patient's named person, and
the patient's primary carer,

the things done by the mental health officer in compliance with the requirements in subsection (2) of section 85 of this Act (and, if by virtue of subsection (3) of that section the first-listed one has not been complied with, the reason why compliance with it was impracticable),
so far as relevant to the extension of the compulsory treatment order
the details of the personal circumstances of the patient, and
if known by the mental health officer, the details of any advance statement made by the patient (and not withdrawn by the patient),
the views of the mental health officer on the extension of the compulsory treatment order, and
any other information that the mental health officer considers relevant in relation to the extension of the compulsory treatment order.
The matters referred to in subsection (2)(c) above are
whether the mental health officer is sending a copy of the record to the patient, and
if the mental health officer is not sending a copy of the record to the patient, the reason for not doing so.
For the purposes of subsection (2)(c) above, the persons are
the patient's named person,
the patient's responsible medical officer, and
the Commission.

Title.Emphasis: Extension and variation of order: application by responsible medical officer

P1group.Title: Responsible medical officers duty where extension and variation of order appear appropriate

P2para.Text: This section applies where a patients responsible medical officer is carrying out

P3para.Text: the first review of the compulsory treatment order to which the patient is subject; or
a further review of that order.

P2para.Text: If, having regard to any views expressed by persons consulted under section 77(3)(c) of this Act for the purpose of the review being carried out, it appears to the responsible medical officer

P3para.Text: that it will continue to be necessary for the patient to be subject to a compulsory treatment order after the day on which the order will cease (unless extended) to authorise the measures specified in it; but
that the order should be varied by modifying the measures, or any recorded matter, specified in it,

P2para.Text: the responsible medical officer shall comply with the requirement in subsection (3) below.
That requirement is to give notice to the mental health officer

P3para.Text: that the responsible medical officer is proposing to make an application to the Tribunal under section 92 of this Act for an order under section 103 of this Act

P4para.Text: extending the compulsory treatment order for the period mentioned in subsection (4) below; and
varying that order by modifying the measures, or a recorded matter, specified in it; and

P3para.Text: of the modification of the measures, or any recorded matter, specified in that order that the responsible medical officer is proposing.

P2para.Text: The period referred to in subsection (3) above is

P3para.Text: where the application is made in respect of the first review, the period of 6 months beginning with the day on which the compulsory treatment order will (unless extended) cease to authorise the measures specified in it;
where the application is made in respect of the first further review, the period of 12 months beginning with the expiry of the period mentioned in paragraph (a) above;

where the application is made in respect of a subsequent further review, the period of 12 months beginning with the expiry of the period of 12 months for which the order is extended as a result of the immediately preceding further review.

P1group.Title: Mental health officers duties: extension and variation of order

P2para.Text: The mental health officer shall, as soon as practicable after receiving notice under section 88(3) of this Act, comply with the requirements in subsection (2) below.
Those requirements are

P3para.Text: subject to subsection (3) below, to interview the patient;
to inform the patient of the matters mentioned in subsection (4) below;
to inform the patient of the availability of independent advocacy services under section 259 of this Act;
to take appropriate steps to ensure that the patient has the opportunity of making use of those services; and
to inform the patients responsible medical officer

P4para.Text: of whether the mental health officer agrees, or disagrees, that the application that is proposed should be made;
if the mental health officer disagrees, of the reason why that is the case; and
of any other matters that the mental health officer considers relevant.

P2para.Text: If it is impracticable for the mental health officer to comply with the requirement in subsection (2)(a) above, the mental health officer need not do so.
The matters referred to in subsection (2)(b) above are

P3para.Text: that the patients responsible medical officer is proposing to make an application to the Tribunal under section 92 of this Act for an order

P4para.Text: extending the compulsory treatment order to which the patient is subject for the period mentioned in section 88(4) of this Act; and
varying the compulsory treatment order by modifying the measures or a recorded matter specified in it;

P3para.Text: the modification of the measures or any recorded matter specified in that order that the responsible medical officer is proposing; and
the patients rights in relation to such an application.

P1group.Title: Responsible medical officers duty to apply for extension and variation of order

P2para.Text: If, having regard to

P3para.Text: any views expressed by persons consulted under section 77(3)(c) of this Act for the purpose of the review being carried out; and
any views expressed by the mental health officer under section 89(2)(e) of this Act for the purpose of that review,

P2para.Text: the responsible medical officer is satisfied as to the matters mentioned in section 88(2)(a) and (b) of this Act, the responsible medical officer shall comply with the requirement in subsection (2) below.
That requirement is to make an application to the Tribunal under section 92 of this Act for an order

P3para.Text: extending the compulsory treatment order for the period mentioned in section 88(4) of this Act; and
varying that order by modifying the measures, or a recorded matter, specified in it.

P2para.Text: An application made under section 92 of this Act, by virtue of subsection (1) above, for an order mentioned in subsection (2) above shall be made as soon as practicable after the duty to make it arises.

P1group.Title: Application for extension and variation of order: notification

P1para.Text: Where, by virtue of section 90(1) of this Act, an application is to be made under section 92 of this Act, the patients responsible medical officer shall, as soon as practicable after the duty to make the application arises (and, in any event, before making the application), give notice that the application is to be made to

P3para.Text: the patient;
the patients named person;
any guardian of the patient;
any welfare attorney of the patient;
the mental health officer; and
the Commission.

P1group.Title: Application to Tribunal

P1para.Text: An application under this section to the Tribunal by a patients responsible medical officer for an order extending and varying a compulsory treatment order

P3para.Text: shall state

P4para.Text: the name and address of the patient;
the name and address of the patients named person;
the modification of the measures, or any recorded matter, specified in the compulsory treatment order that is proposed by the responsible medical officer;
the reasons for seeking that modification;
whether the mental health officer agrees, or disagrees, that the application should be made, or has failed to comply with the duty imposed by section 89(2)(e)(i) of this Act; and
if the mental health officer disagrees, the reason for that disagreement; and

P3para.Text: shall be accompanied by such documents as may be prescribed by regulations.

Title.Emphasis: Variation of order: application by responsible medical officer

P1group.Title: Responsible medical officers duties: variation of order

P2para.Text: This section applies where a patient is subject to a compulsory treatment order.

Without prejudice to the duties imposed on the patients responsible medical officer by sections 77(2), 78(2) and 83(2) of this Act, the responsible medical officer shall from time to time consider whether the compulsory treatment order should be varied by modifying the measures, or any recorded matter, specified in it.

If it appears to the responsible medical officer that the compulsory treatment order should be varied as mentioned in subsection (2) above, the responsible medical officer shall, as soon as practicable, comply with the requirements in subsection (4) below.
Those requirements are

P3para.Text: to assess the needs of the patient for medical treatment;
to consider what modification, if any, of the measures, or any recorded matter, specified in the compulsory treatment order is appropriate;
to consult

P4para.Text: the mental health officer; and
such persons as the responsible medical officer considers appropriate.

Text.Addition: If, having regard to any views expressed by persons consulted under subsection (4)(c) above, it continues to appear to the responsible medical officer that the compulsory treatment order should be varied as mentioned in subsection (2) above, the responsible medical officer shall, as soon as practicable, notify the mental health officer

that the responsible medical officer is proposing to make an application to the Tribunal under section 95 of this Act for an order under section 103 of this Act varying the compulsory treatment order; and
the modification of the measures, or any recorded matter, specified in that order that the responsible medical officer is proposing.
The mental health officer shall, as soon as practicable after being notified under subsection (4A) above, comply with the requirements in subsection (4C) below.
Those requirements are
subject to subsection (4D) below, to interview the patient;
to inform the patient of the matters mentioned in subsection (4E) below;
to inform the patient of the availability of independent advocacy services under section 259 of this Act;
to take appropriate steps to ensure that the patient has the opportunity of making use of those services; and
to inform the patients responsible medical officer
of whether the mental health officer agrees, or disagrees, that the application that is proposed should be made;
if the mental health officer disagrees, of the reason why that is the case; and
of any other matters that the mental health officer considers relevant.
If it is impracticable for the mental health officer to comply with the requirement in subsection (4C)(a) above, the mental health officer need not do so.
The matters referred to in subsection (4C)(b) above are

that the patients responsible medical officer is proposing to make an application to the Tribunal under section 95 of this Act for an order varying the compulsory treatment order by modifying the measures or a recorded matter specified in it;
the modification of the measures or any recorded matter specified in that order that the responsible medical officer is proposing; and
the patients rights in relation to such an application.

P2para.Text: If, having regard to any views expressed by persons consulted under subsection (4)(c) aboveand any views expressed by the mental health officer under subsection (4C)(e) above, the responsible medical officer is satisfied that the compulsory treatment order should be varied as mentioned in subsection (2) above, the responsible medical officer shall make an application to the Tribunal under section 95 of this Act for an order under section 103 of this Act varying the compulsory treatment order in that way.
An application made under section 95 of this Act, by virtue of subsection (5) above, for an order mentioned in that subsection shall be made as soon as practicable after the duty to make it arises.

P1group.Title: Application by responsible medical officer for variation of order: notification

P1para.Text: Where, by virtue of section 93(5) of this Act, an application is to be made under section 95 of this Act, the patients responsible medical officer shall, as soon as practicable after the duty to make the application arises (and, in any event, before making the application), give notice that the application is to be made to the persons mentioned in section 91(a) to (f) of this Act.

P1group.Title: Application to Tribunal by responsible medical officer

P1para.Text: An application under this section to the Tribunal by a patients responsible medical officer for an order varying a compulsory treatment order

P3para.Text: shall state

Text.Addition: the matters mentioned in section 92(a)(i) to
of this Act;
whether the mental health officer agrees, or disagrees that the application should be made, or has failed to comply with the duty imposed by section 93(4C)(e)(i) of this Act; and

P4para.Text: if the mental health officer disagrees, the reason for that disagreement.and

P3para.Text: shall be accompanied by such documents as may be prescribed by regulations.

Title.Emphasis: Recorded matters: reference to Tribunal by responsible medical officer

P1group.Title: Recorded matters: reference to Tribunal by responsible medical officer

P2para.Text: This section applies where a patient is subject to a compulsory treatment order which specifies one or more recorded matters.

Without prejudice to the duties imposed on the patients responsible medical officer by sections 77(2), 78(2) and 83(2) of this Act and subject to subsection (6) below, if it appears to the responsible medical officer that any recorded matter specified in the compulsory treatment order is not being provided, the responsible medical officer shall, as soon as practicable, consult

P3para.Text: the mental health officer; and
such other persons as the responsible medical officer considers appropriate.

P2para.Text: If, having regard to any views expressed by persons consulted under subsection (2) above, the responsible medical officer is satisfied that a recorded matter specified in the compulsory treatment order is not being provided, the responsible medical officer shall make a reference to the Tribunal.
A reference under subsection (3) above

P3para.Text: shall state

P4para.Text: the name and address of the patient;
the name and address of the patients named person; and
the reason for making the reference; and

P3para.Text: shall be accompanied by such documents as may be prescribed by regulations.

P2para.Text: A reference under subsection (3) above shall be made as soon as practicable after the duty to make it arises.
Subsections (2) to (5) above do not apply where

P3para.Text: the responsible medical officer is required, by virtue of section 79 or 80 of this Act, to revoke the compulsory treatment order; or
the responsible medical officer is making an application under section 92 or 95 of this Act in respect of the compulsory treatment order.

P1group.Title: Reference to Tribunal under section 96(3): notification

P1para.Text: Where a patients responsible medical officer is required by section 96(3) of this Act to make a reference to the Tribunal, the responsible medical officer shall, as soon as practicable after the duty to make the reference arises, give notice that the reference is to be made to the persons mentioned in section 91(a) to (f) of this Act.

P1group.Title: Reference to Tribunal by Commission

P2para.Text: This section applies where a patient is subject to a compulsory treatment order.
If it appears to the Commission that it is appropriate to do so, it may make a reference to the Tribunal in respect of the compulsory treatment order to which the patient is subject.
Where a reference is to be made under subsection (2) above, the Commission shall, as soon as practicable, give notice that a reference is to be made to

P3para.Text: the patients responsible medical officer; and
the persons mentioned in section 91(a) to (e) of this Act.

P2para.Text: A reference under subsection (2) above shall state

P3para.Text: the name and address of the patient;
the name and address of the patients named person; and
the reason for making the reference.

P1group.Title: Application by patient etc. for revocation of determination extending order

P2para.Text: Where a patients responsible medical officer makes a determination under section 86 of this Act, subject to subsection (3) below, either of the persons mentioned in subsection (2) below may make an application under this section to the Tribunal for an order under section 103 of this Act revoking the determination.
Those persons are

P3para.Text: the patient;
the patients named person.

P2para.Text: Subsection (1) above does not apply where the Tribunal is required, by virtue of section 101 of this Act, to review the determination.

P1group.Title: Application by patient etc. for revocation or variation of order

P2para.Text: This section applies where a patient is subject to a compulsory treatment order.

Either of the persons mentioned in subsection (3) below may, subject to subsections (4) and (6) below, make an application under this section to the Tribunal for an order under section 103 of this Act

P3para.Text: revoking the compulsory treatment order; or
varying that order by modifying

P4para.Text: the measures; or
any recorded matter,

P3para.Text: specified in it.

P2para.Text: Those persons are

P3para.Text: the patient;
the patients named person.

P2para.Text: An application under this section may not be made during the period of 3 months beginning with the making of any of the orders mentioned in subsection (5) below.
Those orders are

P3para.Text: the compulsory treatment order;
an order in respect of the compulsory treatment order made under section 102 of this Act;
an order in respect of the compulsory treatment order made, by virtue of section 92 of this Act, under section 103 of this Act.

P2para.Text: If

P3para.Text: an application under this section for revocation of a compulsory treatment order is refused; or
an application is made under this section for variation of a compulsory treatment order,

P2para.Text: the person who made the application shall not be entitled to make more than one further application under this section in respect of the compulsory treatment order during the period mentioned in subsection (8) below.

If an application under section 99 of this Act for revocation of a determination under section 86 of this Act is refused, the person who made the application shall not be entitled to make more than one application under this section in respect of the compulsory treatment order which is the subject of the determination during the period mentioned in subsection (8) below.
The period referred to in subsections (6) and (7) above is

P3para.Text: where the application mentioned in subsection (6)(a) or (b) or (7) above is made before the expiry of the period of 6 months beginning with the day on which the compulsory treatment order was made, that period of 6 months; or
where that application is made before the expiry of

P4para.Text: the period of 6 months beginning with the expiry of the period mentioned in paragraph (a) above, that period of 6 months; or
any subsequent period of 12 months that begins with, or with an anniversary of, the expiry of the period of 6 months mentioned in sub-paragraph (i) above, that subsequent period of 12 months.

Title.Emphasis: Review by Tribunal of determination extending order

P1group.Title: Tribunals duty to review determination under section 86

P2para.Text: This section applies where a patients responsible medical officer makes a determination under section 86 of this Act.
If

P3para.Text: the record submitted to the Tribunal under section 87(2)(b) of this Act states

P4para.Text: that there is a difference between the type (or types) of mental disorder that the patient has and the type (or types) of mental disorder recorded in the compulsory treatment order in respect of which the determination is made; or
that the mental health officer disagrees with the determination or has failed to comply with the duty imposed by section 85(2)(d)(i) of this Act; or

Text.Substitution: the conditions in subsection (3) are satisfied in relation to the compulsory treatment order to which the determination relates,

P2para.Text: the Tribunal shall review the determination.

Text.Addition: The conditions mentioned in subsection (2)(b) above are
that the order was made 2 or more years before the renewal day;
that this section did not require the Tribunal to review the previous determination made under section 86 of this Act in relation to the order; and
that, in the period of 2 years ending with the day before the renewal day, no application has been
the Tribunal under section 92, 99, 95 or 100 in relation to the order.
In subsection (3) above, the renewal day is the first day on which the order, had it not been extended by the determination, would not authorise the measures specified in it.

P1group.Title: Powers of Tribunal on review under section 101

P2para.Text: On the review of a determination under section 101 of this Act, the Tribunal may make an order under this section

P3para.Text: revoking the determination;
revoking both the determination and the compulsory treatment order;
confirming the determination; or
confirming the determination and varying the compulsory treatment order by modifying

P4para.Text: the measures; or
any recorded matter,

P3para.Text: specified in it.

P2para.Text: Before making a decision under subsection (1) above, the Tribunal shall allow the persons mentioned in subsection (3) below the opportunity

P3para.Text: of making representations (whether orally or in writing); and
of leading, or producing, evidence.

P2para.Text: Those persons are

P3para.Text: the patient;
the patients named person;
any guardian of the patient;
any welfare attorney of the patient;
the mental health officer;
the patients responsible medical officer;
the patients primary carer;
any curator ad litem appointed in respect of the patient by the Tribunal; and
any other person appearing to the Tribunal to have an interest in the determination.

P1group.Title: Powers of Tribunal on application under section 92, 95, 99 or 100

P2para.Text: Where an application is made under section 92 of this Act, the Tribunal may make an order

P3para.Text: extending the compulsory treatment order to which the application relates for the period mentioned in section 88(4) of this Act and varying the compulsory treatment order by modifying

P4para.Text: the measures; or
any recorded matter,

P3para.Text: specified in it;
extending the compulsory treatment order for that period;
refusing the application; or
refusing the application and revoking the compulsory treatment order.

P2para.Text: Where an application is made under section 99 of this Act, the Tribunal may make an order

P3para.Text: revoking the determination to which the application relates;
revoking

P4para.Text: the determination; and
the compulsory treatment order to which the determination relates;

P3para.Text: confirming the determination; or
confirming the determination and varying the compulsory treatment order by modifying

P4para.Text: the measures; or
any recorded matter,

P3para.Text: specified in it.

P2para.Text: Where an application is made under section 100(2)(a) of this Act, the Tribunal may make an order

P3para.Text: revoking the compulsory treatment order to which the application relates;
varying the compulsory treatment order by modifying

P4para.Text: the measures; or
any recorded matter,

P3para.Text: specified in it; or
refusing the application.

P2para.Text: Where an application is made under section 95 or 100(2)(b) of this Act, the Tribunal may make an order

P3para.Text: varying the compulsory treatment order to which the application relates by modifying

P4para.Text: the measures; or
any recorded matter,

P3para.Text: specified in it;
refusing the application; or
refusing the application and revoking that order.

P2para.Text: Before making a decision under any of subsections (1) to (4) above, the Tribunal shall afford the persons mentioned in subsection (6) below the opportunity

P3para.Text: of making representations (whether orally or in writing); and
of leading, or producing, evidence.

P2para.Text: Those persons are

P3para.Text: the persons mentioned in section 102(3)(a) to (h) of this Act; and
any other person appearing to the Tribunal to have an interest in the application.

P1group.Title: Powers of Tribunal on reference under section 96 or 98

P2para.Text: Where a reference is made under section 96 or 98 of this Act, the Tribunal may make an order

P3para.Text: varying the compulsory treatment order in respect of which the reference is made by modifying

P4para.Text: the measures; or
any recorded matter,

P3para.Text: specified in it; or
revoking the compulsory treatment order.

P2para.Text: Before making an order under subsection (1) above, the Tribunal shall allow the persons mentioned in subsection (3) below the opportunity

P3para.Text: of making representations (whether orally or in writing); and
of leading, or producing, evidence.

P2para.Text: Those persons are

P3para.Text: the persons mentioned in section 102(3)(a) to (h) of this Act; and
any other person appearing to the Tribunal to have an interest in the reference.

P1group.Title: Interim extension etc. of order: application under section 92

P2para.Text: This section applies where an application is made under section 92 of this Act.
Subject to section 107 of this Act, on the application of any person having an interest in the proceedings, or ex proprio motu, the Tribunal may, if it considers

P3para.Text: that it will be unable to determine the application before the compulsory treatment order to which the application relates ceases to authorise the measures specified in it; and
that it is appropriate, pending its determining the application, to

P4para.Text: extend the order; or
extend and vary the order by modifying the measures, or any recorded matter, specified in it,

P2para.Text: make an interim order extending, or extending and varying, the compulsory treatment order for such period not exceeding 28 days as may be specified in the order of the Tribunal.

P1group.Title: Interim variation of order: application, reference or review under Chapter

P2para.Text: This section applies where

P3para.Text: an application is made under section 92, 95, 99 or 100 of this Act;
a reference is made under section 96 or 98 of this Act; or
the Tribunal is reviewing a determination under section 101 of this Act.

P2para.Text: Subject to section 107 of this Act, on the application of any person having an interest in the proceedings, or ex proprio motu, the Tribunal may, if it considers that it is appropriate to do so pending its

P3para.Text: determining the application or reference; or
making its decision on the review;

P2para.Text: make an interim order varying the compulsory treatment order by modifying the measures, or any recorded matter, specified in it, for such period not exceeding 28 days as may be specified in the order of the Tribunal.

P1group.Title: Limit on Tribunals power to make interim orders

P1para.Text: The Tribunal may not make an interim order under section 105 or 106 of this Act if the effect of making the order would be that interim orders under either, or both, of those sections would be in force for a continuous period of more than 56 days.

P1group.Title: Tribunals order varying compulsory treatment order

P1para.Text: Where the Tribunal makes

P3para.Text: an order under section 102, 103, 104 or 106 of this Act varying a compulsory treatment order; or
an order under section 103 or 105 of this Act extending and varying such an order,

P1para.Text: the Tribunal shall specify in its order the modifications made by its order to the measures, and any recorded matter, specified in the compulsory treatment order.

P1group.Title: Ancillary powers of Tribunal

P2para.Text: This section applies where

P3para.Text: an application is made to the Tribunal under section 92, 95, 99 or 100 of this Act;
the Tribunal is, under section 101 of this Act, reviewing a determination; or
a reference is made to the Tribunal under section 96 or 98 of this Act.

P2para.Text: Regulations may prescribe circumstances in which the Tribunal may require

P3para.Text: the patients responsible medical officer; or
the mental health officer,

P2para.Text: to prepare and submit to the Tribunal reports on such matters as may be prescribed.

Title.Emphasis: Effect of interim orders on calculation of time periods in Chapter

P1group.Title: Effect of interim orders on calculation of time periods in Chapter

P2para.Text: Subject to subsection (2) below, in calculating, for the purpose of this Chapter, the day on which a compulsory treatment order

P3para.Text: ceases;
will cease; or
would have ceased,

P2para.Text: to authorise the measures specified in it, there shall be left out of account any period for which the order is extended (or extended and varied) by an interim order under section 105 of this Act.
Subsection (1) above does not apply as respects calculating that day for the purpose of that section.

P1group.Title: Meaning of modify

P1para.Text: In this Chapter, any reference to modifying measures, or recorded matters, specified in a compulsory treatment order includes a reference to

P3para.Text: amending those measures or recorded matters;
removing from the order any measure or recorded matter;
adding to the order any measure or recorded matter;
specifying a recorded matter in an order which does not specify a recorded matter.

Title.Emphasis: Failure to attend for medical treatment

P1group.Title: Failure to attend for medical treatment

P2para.Text: Subject to subsection (2) below, where

P3para.Text: a patient is subject to

P4para.Text: a compulsory treatment order; or
an interim compulsory treatment order,

P3para.Text: that imposes on the patient a requirement mentioned in section 66(1)(c) of this Act (the attendance requirement); and
the patient fails to comply with the attendance requirement,

P2para.Text: the patients responsible medical officer may exercise the power conferred by subsection (3) below.
The responsible medical officer may exercise the power conferred by subsection (3) below only if
