P3para.Text: the responsible medical officer has consulted a mental health officer; and
the mental health officer consents to the power being exercised.

P2para.Text: The responsible medical officer may take, or may cause a person authorised for the purpose by the responsible medical officer to take, the patient into custody and convey the patient

P3para.Text: to the place the patient is required to attend by the attendance requirement; or
to any hospital.

P2para.Text: Subject to subsection (5) below, where by virtue of subsection (3) above the patient is conveyed to the place the patient is required to attend or a hospital

P3para.Text: if the order to which the patient is subject authorises the measure mentioned in section 66(1)(b) of this Act, the patient may be detained there for so long as is necessary for the purpose of giving to the patient any medical treatment that could have been given to the patient had the patient complied with the attendance requirement;

if the order to which the patient is subject does not authorise that measure, the patient may be detained there for so long as is necessary to determine whether the patient is capable of consenting to medical treatment and, if so, whether the patient consents to receive any medical treatment.

P2para.Text: The patient may not be detained by virtue of subsection (4) above for more than a period of 6 hours beginning with the arrival of the patient in the place or hospital.

P1group.Title: Non-compliance generally with order

P2para.Text: Where

P3para.Text: a patient is subject to

P4para.Text: a compulsory treatment order; or
an interim compulsory treatment order,

P3para.Text: that does not authorise the detention of the patient in hospital;
the patient fails to comply with any measure authorised by the order; and
subsection (2) or (3) below applies,

P2para.Text: the power conferred by subsection (4) below may be exercised.
This subsection applies if the patients responsible medical officer considers that

P3para.Text: reasonable steps have been taken to contact the patient following the patients failure to comply with the measure;
if contact has been made with the patient, the patient has been afforded a reasonable opportunity to comply with the measure; and
if the patient were to continue to fail to comply with the measure, it is reasonably likely that there would be a significant deterioration in the patients mental health.

P2para.Text: This subsection applies if the patients responsible medical officer considers that

P3para.Text: if the patient were to continue to fail to comply with the measure, it is reasonably likely that there would be a significant deterioration in the patients mental health; and
it is necessary as a matter of urgency that the power conferred by subsection (4) below be exercised.

P2para.Text: The patients responsible medical officer may take, or may cause a person authorised for the purpose by the responsible medical officer to take, the patient into custody and convey the patient to a hospital.

Where the power conferred by subsection (4) above is exercised in relation to a patient, the patient may be detained in hospital for the period of 72 hours beginning with the arrival by virtue of that subsection of the patient in hospital.
As soon as reasonably practicable after the patient has been conveyed to a hospital, the responsible medical officer shall

P3para.Text: carry out a medical examination of the patient; or
make arrangements for an approved medical practitioner to carry out such an examination.

P1group.Title: Compulsory treatment order: detention pending review or application for variation

P2para.Text: Subsection (2) below applies where

P3para.Text: a patient who is subject to an order such as is mentioned in subsection (1)(a)(i) of section 113 of this Act is detained in hospital by virtue of subsection (5) of that section;
the patient has been examined under subsection (6) of that section;
the patients responsible medical officer

P4para.Text: is considering under subsection (2) of section 93 of this Act whether that order should be varied by modifying the measures specified in it; or
by virtue of subsection (5) of that section, is required to make an application to the Tribunal; and

P3para.Text: the patients responsible medical officer considers that if the patient does not continue to be detained in hospital it is reasonably likely that there will be a significant deterioration in the patients mental health.

P2para.Text: Subject to subsections (3) and (4) below, the responsible medical officer may grant a certificate authorising the continued detention in hospital of the patient for the period of 28 days beginning with the granting of the certificate.
The power in subsection (2) above may be exercised only if

P3para.Text: the responsible medical officer has consulted the mental health officer; and
the mental health officer consents to the power being exercised.

P2para.Text: Before granting a certificate under subsection (2) above the responsible medical officer shall, if it is practicable to do so, consult the patients named person.
A certificate under subsection (2) above

P3para.Text: shall state the responsible medical officers reasons for believing that paragraph (d) of subsection (1) applies in the patients case; and
shall be signed by the responsible medical officer.

P1group.Title: Interim compulsory treatment order: detention pending further procedure

P2para.Text: Subsection (2) below applies where

P3para.Text: a patient who is subject to an order such as is mentioned in subsection (1)(a)(ii) of section 113 of this Act is detained in hospital by virtue of subsection (5) of that section;
the patient has been examined under subsection (6) of that section;

the patients responsible medical officer considers that if the patient does not continue to be detained in hospital it is reasonably likely that there will be a significant deterioration in the patients mental health; and
on the expiry of the period of detention authorised by subsection (5) of that section the period for which the order authorises the measures specified in it will not have expired.

P2para.Text: Subject to subsections (3) and (4) below, the responsible medical officer may grant a certificate authorising the continued detention in hospital of the patient for the period beginning with the granting of the certificate and ending with the expiry of the period for which the order authorises the measures specified in it.
The power in subsection (2) above may be exercised only if

P3para.Text: the patients responsible medical officer has consulted a mental health officer; and
the mental health officer consents to the power being exercised.

P2para.Text: Before granting a certificate the responsible medical officer shall, if it is practicable to do so, consult the patients named person.
A certificate under subsection (2) above

P3para.Text: shall state the responsible medical officers reasons for believing that subsection (1)(c) above applies in the patients case; and
shall be signed by the responsible medical officer.

P1group.Title: Certificate under section 114(2) or 115(2): notification

P2para.Text: This section applies where a certificate is granted under section 114(2) or 115(2) of this Act in respect of a patient.
The managers of the hospital in which the patient is detained shall, as soon as practicable after the granting of the certificate, give notice of its granting to

P3para.Text: the patient;
the patients named person;
any guardian of the patient; and
any welfare attorney of the patient.

P2para.Text: The managers of the hospital in which the patient is detained shall, before the expiry of the period of 7 days beginning with the granting of the certificate, give notice of its granting, and send a copy of it, to

P3para.Text: the Tribunal; and
the Commission.

P1group.Title: Certificate under section 114(2): responsible medical officers duty to revoke

P2para.Text: Where

P3para.Text: a patients responsible medical officer grants, by virtue of subsection (1)(c)(i) of section 114 of this Act, a certificate under subsection (2) of that section; and
the responsible medical officer determines that the order should not be varied as mentioned in section 93(2) of this Act,

P2para.Text: the responsible medical officer shall revoke the certificate.
Where

P3para.Text: a patients responsible medical officer grants, by virtue of subsection (1)(c)(ii) of section 114 of this Act, a certificate under subsection (2) of that section; and

the responsible medical officer is not satisfied that if the patient does not continue to be detained in hospital it is reasonably likely that there will be a significant deterioration in the patients mental health,

P2para.Text: the responsible medical officer shall revoke the certificate.

P1group.Title: Certificate under section 115(2): responsible medical officers duty to revoke

P1para.Text: Where

P3para.Text: a patients responsible medical officer grants a certificate under section 115(2) of this Act; and

the responsible medical officer is not satisfied that if the patient does not continue to be detained in hospital it is reasonably likely that there will be a significant deterioration in the patients mental health,

P1para.Text: the responsible medical officer shall revoke the certificate.

P1group.Title: Revocation of certificate granted under section 114(2) or 115(2): notification

P1para.Text: Where a patients responsible medical officer revokes, under section 117 or 118 of this Act, a certificate, the responsible medical officer shall

P3para.Text: as soon as practicable after the revocation, give notice of the revocation to the persons mentioned in subsection (2) of section 116 of this Act; and
before the expiry of the period of 7 days beginning with the revocation, give notice of the revocation to the persons mentioned in subsection (3) of that section.

P1group.Title: Certificates under sections 114(2) and 115(2): patients right to apply to Tribunal

P2para.Text: This section applies where a certificate is granted under section 114(2) or 115(2) of this Act in respect of a patient.

On the application of the patient or the patients named person, the Tribunal shall, if not satisfied that if the patient does not continue to be detained in hospital it is reasonably likely that there will be a significant deterioration in the patients mental health, revoke the certificate.

P1group.Title: Effect of section 113(5) on order

P2para.Text: Subject to subsection (2) below, where a patient is detained in hospital under section 113(5) of this Act, the compulsory treatment order or, as the case may be, interim compulsory treatment order to which the patient is subject shall cease, during the period mentioned in that section, to authorise the measures specified in it.
If the measure mentioned in section 66(1)(b) of this Act is specified in the order, the order shall continue to authorise that measure during the period referred to in subsection (1) above.

Title.Emphasis: Effect of certificate under section 114(2) on order

P1group.Title: Effect of certificate under section 114(2) on order

P2para.Text: Subject to subsection (2) below, where a certificate is granted under section 114(2) of this Act in respect of a patient, the compulsory treatment order to which the patient is subject shall cease, during the period mentioned in that section, to authorise the measures specified in it.
If the measure mentioned in section 66(1)(b) of this Act is specified in the order, the order shall continue to authorise that measure during the period referred to in subsection (1) above.

Title.Emphasis: Effect of certificate under section 115(2) on order

P1group.Title: Effect of certificate under section 115(2) on order

P2para.Text: Subject to subsection (2) below, where a certificate is granted under section 115(2) of this Act in respect of a patient, the interim compulsory treatment order to which the patient is subject shall cease, during the period mentioned in that section, to authorise the measures specified in it.
If the measure mentioned in section 66(1)(b) of this Act is specified in the order, the order shall continue to authorise that measure during the period referred to in subsection (1) above.

P1group.Title: Transfer to other hospital

P2para.Text: This section applies where the detention of a patient in hospital is authorised by

Text.Substitution: a compulsory treatment order, or
an interim compulsory treatment order.

P2para.Text: The managers of the hospital in which the patient is detained may, where the condition mentioned in subsection (3) below is satisfied, transfer the patient to another hospital.
The condition is that the managers of the hospital to which it is proposed to transfer the patient consent to the transfer.

Where the managers of a hospital propose to transfer the patient under subsection (2) above, they shall, subject to subsections (5) and (7) below, give the persons mentioned in subsection (8) below at least 7 days' notice of the transfer.
The managers of a hospital need not give notice under subsection (4) above where it is necessary that the patient be transferred urgently.

Where, by virtue of subsection (5) above, notice is not given under subsection (4) above, the managers of the hospital shall, subject to subsection (7) below, give the persons mentioned in subsection (8) below notice

P3para.Text: where the proposed transfer has not taken place, of the proposed transfer; or
where the transfer has taken place, of the transfer,

P2para.Text: as soon as practicable before, on or, as the case may be, after the transfer.
The managers of the hospital need not give notice to the patient under subsection (4) or, as the case may be, (6) above where the patient consents to the transfer.
The persons referred to in subsections (4) and (6) above are

P3para.Text: the patient;
the patients named person; and
the patients primary carer.

P2para.Text: Where

P3para.Text: notice is given under subsection (4) or (6)(a) above of a proposed transfer under subsection (2) above; and
the proposed transfer does not take place before the end of the period of 3 months beginning with the day on which notice is given,

P2para.Text: the managers of the hospital may transfer the patient as proposed only if subsection (10) below applies.
This subsection applies where

P3para.Text: the condition mentioned in subsection (3) above continues to be satisfied; and
the persons mentioned in subsection (8) above are given at least 7 days' notice of the proposed transfer.

P2para.Text: Subsections (5) to (7) above shall apply to the giving of notice under subsection (10)(b) above as they apply to the giving of notice under subsection (4) above.

Where the patient is transferred under subsection (2) above, the managers of the hospital from which the patient is transferred shall, before the expiry of the period of 7 days beginning with the transfer, give notice to the Commission of the matters mentioned in subsection (13) below.
Those matters are

P3para.Text: the date on which the patient was transferred;
the hospital to which the patient was transferred;
that

P4para.Text: notice was given under subsection (4) above; or
if no such notice was given, the reasons why it was necessary that the patient be transferred urgently; and

P3para.Text: whether notice was given under subsection (6) or (10)(b) above.

P2para.Text: Where the patient is transferred under subsection (2) above, the order in question shall, for the purposes of this Act (other than sections 125 and 126), be taken to specify the hospital to which the patient is transferred.

Title.Addition: Transfer to other hospital unit

Text.Addition: Subsection (2) below applies where
the detention of a patient in hospital is authorised by
a compulsory treatment order, or
an interim compulsory treatment order, and
that order specifies the hospital unit in which the patient is to be detained.
The managers of the hospital in which the patient is detained may transfer the patient to another hospital unit within the same hospital.
In relation to a transfer or proposed transfer under subsection (2) above, section 124(4) to (14) of this Act applies subject to the following modifications
a reference to section 124(2) is to be read as a reference to subsection (2) above,
subsection (10)(a) is to be ignored,
in subsection (12), a reference to the hospital from which the patient is transferred is to be read as a reference to the hospital in which the patient is detained,
in subsections (13)(b) and (14), a reference to the hospital to which the patient is transferred is to be read as a reference to the hospital unit to which the patient is transferred.
For the purposes of this section,
means any part of a hospital which is treated as a separate unit.

P1group.Title: Transfer to hospital other than state hospital: appeal to Tribunal

P2para.Text: This section applies where a patient

P3para.Text: receives notice under subsection (4), (6)(a) or (10)(b) of section 124 of this Act that it is proposed to transfer the patient; or
is transferred under subsection (2) of that section,

P2para.Text: to any hospital other than a state hospital.
The patient, or the patients named person, may, during the period mentioned in subsection (3) below, appeal to the Tribunal against the proposed transfer or, as the case may be, the transfer.
That period is

P3para.Text: in the case of the patient

P4para.Text: where notice is given to the patient before the proposed transfer, the period beginning with the day on which notice is given and ending 28 days after the transfer;
where notice is given to the patient on or after the transfer, the period beginning with the day on which the patient is transferred and ending 28 days after the day on which notice is given; or
where notice is not given to the patient, the period of 28 days beginning with the day on which the patient is transferred;

P3para.Text: in the case of the patients named person

P4para.Text: where notice is given to the patients named person before the proposed transfer, the period beginning with the day on which notice is given and ending 28 days after the transfer; or
where notice is given to the patients named person on or after the transfer, the period of 28 days beginning with the day on which notice is given.

P2para.Text: If, when an appeal under subsection (2) above against a proposed transfer is made to the Tribunal, the proposed transfer has not taken place

P3para.Text: the managers of the hospital shall not transfer the patient as proposed; but
the Tribunal may, if satisfied that, pending the determination of the appeal, the patient should be transferred as proposed, make an order that the patient be so transferred.

P2para.Text: On an appeal under subsection (2) above, the Tribunal may make an order that the proposed transfer not take place or, as the case may be, that the patient be returned to the hospital from which the patient was transferred.

P1group.Title: Transfer to state hospital: appeal to Tribunal

P2para.Text: This section applies where a patient

P3para.Text: receives notice under subsection (4), (6)(a) or (10)(b) of section 124 of this Act that it is proposed to transfer the patient; or
is transferred under subsection (2) of that section,

P2para.Text: to a state hospital.
The patient, or the patients named person, may, during the period mentioned in subsection (3) below, appeal to the Tribunal against the proposed transfer or, as the case may be, the transfer.
That period is

P3para.Text: in the case of the patient

P4para.Text: where notice is given to the patient before the proposed transfer, the period beginning with the day on which notice is given and ending 12 weeks after the transfer;
where notice is given to the patient on or after the transfer, the period beginning with the day on which the patient is transferred and ending 12 weeks after the day on which notice is given; or
where notice is not given to the patient, the period of 12 weeks beginning with the day on which the patient is transferred;

P3para.Text: in the case of the patients named person

P4para.Text: where notice is given to the patients named person before the proposed transfer, the period beginning with the day on which notice is given and ending 12 weeks after the transfer; or
where notice is given to the patients named person on or after the transfer, the period of 12 weeks beginning with the day on which notice is given.

P2para.Text: If, when an appeal under subsection (2) above against a proposed transfer is made to the Tribunal, the proposed transfer has not taken place

P3para.Text: the managers of the hospital shall not transfer the patient as proposed; but
the Tribunal may, if satisfied that, pending determination of the appeal, the patient should be transferred as proposed, make an order that the patient be so transferred.

P2para.Text: On an appeal under subsection (2) above, the Tribunal may, if not satisfied as to the matter mentioned in subsection (6) below, make an order that the proposed transfer not take place or, as the case may be, that the patient be returned to the hospital from which the patient was transferred.
That matter is

P3para.Text: that the patient requires to be detained in hospital under conditions of special security; and
that those conditions of special security can be provided only in a state hospital.

P1group.Title: Suspension of measure authorising detention

P2para.Text: Where

P3para.Text: a patient is subject to a compulsory treatment order that authorises the measure mentioned in section 66(1)(a) of this Act; and
subject to subsection (2) below, the patients responsible medical officer grants a certificate specifying a period ... during which the order shall not authorise that measure,

P2para.Text: the order does not authorise that measure during that period.

Text.Addition: A certificate under subsection (1) above may specify
a single period not exceeding 200 days, or
a series of more than one individual period falling within a particular 6 month period.

Text.Substitution: The total period that an order does not, by reason of certification under subsection (1) above, authorise the measure mentioned in section 66(1)(a) of this Act must not exceed 200 days within any period of 12 months (whenever counted from).

Text.Addition: For the purpose of subsection (2) above
a day does not count towards the total period if the measure is (by reason of such certification) not authorised for a period of 8 hours or less in that day,
a single period (specified in such certification) of more than 8 hours and less than 24 hours, whether in one day or spanning two days, is to count as a whole day towards the total period.

P2para.Text: Where

P3para.Text: a patient is subject to

P4para.Text: an interim compulsory treatment order that authorises the measure mentioned in section 66(1)(a) of this Act; or
an interim order made under section 105 or 106 of this Act, extending, extending and varying or varying, as the case may be, a compulsory treatment order that authorises that measure;; and

P3para.Text: the patients responsible medical officer grants a certificate specifying a period during which the order shall not authorise that measure,

P2para.Text: the order does not authorise that measure during that period.

Text.Addition: A certificate under subsection (3) above may specify
a single period, or
a series of more than one individual period.
The purpose for which a certificate under subsection (1) or (3) above is granted must be recorded in the certificate.

P2para.Text: If the responsible medical officer considers that it is necessary

P3para.Text: in the interests of the patient; or
for the protection of any other person,

P2para.Text: a certificate under subsection (1) or (3) above may include conditions such as are mentioned in subsection (6) below; and any such conditions shall have effect.
Those conditions are

P3para.Text: that, during the period specified in the certificate, the patient be kept in the charge of a person authorised in writing for the purpose by the patients responsible medical officer; and
such other conditions as may be specified by the patients responsible medical officer.

P2para.Text: Where a patients responsible medical officer proposes to grant a certificate under subsection (1) above specifying

P3para.Text: a period of more than 28 days; or
a period which, when taken together with the period specified in any other certificate granted under that subsection, would exceed 28 days,

P2para.Text: the responsible medical officer shall, before granting such a certificate, give notice of the proposal to the persons mentioned in subsection (8) below.
Those persons are

P3para.Text: the patient;
the patients named person;
the patients general medical practitioner; and
the mental health officer.

P2para.Text: Where a certificate is granted under subsection (1) above specifying a period of more than 28 days, the patients responsible medical officer shall, before the expiry of the period of 14 days beginning with the day on which the certificate is granted, give notice of it to the Commission.

P1group.Title: Suspension of other measures

P2para.Text: Where

P3para.Text: a patient is subject to a compulsory treatment order that authorises any of the measures mentioned in section 66(1)(b) to (h) of this Act; and

subject to subsection (2) below, the patients responsible medical officer grants a certificate specifying a period not exceeding 90 days during which the order shall not authorise such of those measures as are specified in the certificate,

P2para.Text: the order does not authorise the measures specified in the certificate during that period.
If the sum of

P3para.Text: the period that the responsible medical officer proposes to specify in a certificate under subsection (1) above; and
the period specified in any other certificate granted under that subsection in respect of the same patient,

P2para.Text: would exceed 90 days, the responsible medical officer may not grant a certificate under that subsection.

Text.Addition: A day is to count as a whole day towards the 90 days mentioned in subsection (2) above if any part of that day falls within the period mentioned in paragraph (a) or (b) of that subsection.

P2para.Text: Where a patients responsible medical officer proposes to grant a certificate under subsection (1) above, the responsible medical officer shall, before granting such a certificate, give notice to the persons mentioned in subsection (4) below of

P3para.Text: the measures and the period that the responsible medical officer proposes to specify in the certificate; and
the responsible medical officers reasons for proposing to specify those measures.

P2para.Text: Those persons are

P3para.Text: the patient;
the patients named person; and
the mental health officer.

P2para.Text: Where a certificate is granted under subsection (1) above, the patients responsible medical officer shall, before the expiry of the period of 14 days beginning with the day on which the certificate is granted, give notice to the Commission of

P3para.Text: the granting of the certificate;
the measures and the period specified in the certificate; and
the responsible medical officers reasons for specifying those measures.

P1group.Title: Certificates under sections 127 and 128: revocation

P2para.Text: Subsection (2) below applies where a certificate is granted under section 127(1) or (3) or 128(1) of this Act.
If the patients responsible medical officer is satisfied that it is necessary

P3para.Text: in the interests of the patient; or
for the protection of any other person,

P2para.Text: that the certificate be revoked, the responsible medical officer may revoke the certificate.

Where the responsible medical officer revokes under subsection (2) above a certificate granted under subsection (1) or (3) of section 127 of this Act, the responsible medical officer shall, as soon as practicable after the revocation, give notice of it to

P3para.Text: the patient;
the patients named person;
the mental health officer;
where a person is authorised for the purposes of subsection (6)(a) of that section, that person; and
the patients general medical practitioner.

P2para.Text: Where the responsible medical officer revokes under subsection (2) above a certificate granted under section 128(1) of this Act, the responsible medical officer shall, as soon as practicable after the revocation, give notice to the persons mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (c) of subsection (3) above of

P3para.Text: the revocation; and
the responsible medical officers reasons for revoking the certificate.

P2para.Text: Where the responsible medical officer revokes under subsection (2) above a certificate granted under section 127(1) or (3) or 128(1) of this Act, the responsible medical officer shall, before the expiry of the period of 14 days beginning with the day on which the certificate is revoked, give notice of the revocation to the Commission.

P1group.Title: Mentally disordered persons subject to criminal proceedings: assessment and treatment

P1para.Text: After section 52 of the 1995 Act there shall be inserted

Title.Emphasis: Remit of mentally disordered persons from district court

P1group.Title: Remit of certain mentally disordered persons from district court to sheriff court

P1para.Text: Where

P3para.Text: a person has been charged in a district court with an offence punishable by imprisonment; and
it appears to the court that the person has a mental disorder,

P1para.Text: the district court shall remit the person to the sheriff in the manner provided by section 7(9) and (10) of this Act.

P1group.Title: Prosecutors power to apply for assessment order

P2para.Text: Where

P3para.Text: a person has been charged with an offence;
a relevant disposal has not been made in the proceedings in respect of the offence; and
it appears to the prosecutor that the person has a mental disorder,

P2para.Text: the prosecutor may apply to the court for an order under section 52D(2) of this Act (in this Act referred to as an assessment order) in respect of that person.

Where the prosecutor applies for an assessment order under subsection (1) above, the prosecutor shall, as soon as reasonably practicable after making the application, inform the persons mentioned in subsection (3) below of the making of the application.
Those persons are

P3para.Text: the person in respect of whom the application is made;
any solicitor acting for the person; and
in a case where the person is in custody, the Scottish Ministers.

P2para.Text: In this section

Para.Text: court means any court, other than a district court, competent to deal with the case; and
relevant disposal means
the liberation in due course of law of the person charged;
the desertion of summary proceedings pro loco et tempore or simpliciter;
the desertion of solemn proceedings simpliciter;
the acquittal of the person charged; or
the conviction of the person charged.

P1group.Title: Scottish Ministers' power to apply for assessment order

P2para.Text: Where

P3para.Text: a person has been charged with an offence;
the person has not been sentenced;
the person is in custody; and
it appears to the Scottish Ministers that the person has a mental disorder,

P2para.Text: the Scottish Ministers may apply to the court for an assessment order in respect of that person.

Where the Scottish Ministers apply for an order under subsection (1) above, they shall, as soon as reasonably practicable after making the application, inform the persons mentioned in subsection (3) below of the making of the application.
Those persons are

P3para.Text: the person in respect of whom the application is made;
any solicitor acting for the person; and
in a case where a relevant disposal has not been made in the proceedings in respect of the offence with which the person is charged, the prosecutor.

P2para.Text: In this section, court and relevant disposal have the same meanings as in section 52B of this Act.

P1group.Title: Assessment order

P2para.Text: This section applies where an application for an assessment order is made under section 52B(1) or 52C(1) of this Act.
If the court is satisfied

P3para.Text: on the written or oral evidence of a medical practitioner, as to the matters mentioned in subsection (3) below; and
that, having regard to the matters mentioned in subsection (4) below, it is appropriate,

P2para.Text: it may, subject to subsection (5) below, make an assessment order authorising the measures mentioned in subsection (6) below and specifying any matters to be included in the report under section 52G(1) of this Act.
The matters referred to in subsection (2)(a) above are

P3para.Text: that there are reasonable grounds for believing

P4para.Text: that the person in respect of whom the application is made has a mental disorder;
that it is necessary to detain the person in hospital to assess whether the conditions mentioned in subsection (7) below are met in respect of the person; and
that if the assessment order were not made there would be a significant risk to the health, safety or welfare of the person or a significant risk to the safety of any other person;

P3para.Text: that the hospital proposed by the medical practitioner is suitable for the purpose of assessing whether the conditions mentioned in subsection (7) below are met in respect of the person;
that, if an assessment order were made, the person could be admitted to such hospital before the expiry of the period of 7 days beginning with the day on which the order is made; and
that it would not be reasonably practicable to carry out the assessment mentioned in paragraph (b) above unless an order were made.

P2para.Text: The matters referred to in subsection (2)(b) above are

P3para.Text: all the circumstances (including the nature of the offence with which the person in respect of whom the application is made is charged or, as the case may be, of which the person was convicted); and
any alternative means of dealing with the person.

P2para.Text: The court may make an assessment order only if the person in respect of whom the application is made has not been sentenced.
The measures are

P3para.Text: in the case of a person who, when the assessment order is made, has not been admitted to the specified hospital, the removal, before the expiry of the period of 7 days beginning with the day on which the order is made, of the person to the specified hospital by

P4para.Text: a constable;

a person employed in, or contracted to provide services in or to, the specified hospital who is authorised by the managers of that hospital to remove persons to hospital for the purposes of this section; or
a specified person;

P3para.Text: the detention, for the period of 28 days beginning with the day on which the order is made, of the person in the specified hospital; and

during the period of 28 days beginning with the day on which the order is made, the giving to the person, in accordance with Part 16 of the Mental Health (Care and Treatment)
(Scotland) Act 2003 (asp 13), of medical treatment.

P2para.Text: The conditions referred to in paragraphs (a)(ii) and (b) of subsection (3) above are

P3para.Text: that the person in respect of whom the application is made has a mental disorder;
that medical treatment which would be likely to

P4para.Text: prevent the mental disorder worsening; or
alleviate any of the symptoms, or effects, of the disorder,

P3para.Text: is available for the person; and
that if the person were not provided with such medical treatment there would be a significant risk

P4para.Text: to the health, safety or welfare of the person; or
to the safety of any other person.

P2para.Text: The court may make an assessment order in the absence of the person in respect of whom the application is made only if

P3para.Text: the person is represented by counsel or a solicitor;
that counsel or solicitor is given an opportunity of being heard; and
the court is satisfied that it is

P4para.Text: impracticable; or
inappropriate,

P3para.Text: for the person to be brought before it.

P2para.Text: An assessment order may include such directions as the court thinks fit for the removal of the person subject to the order to, and detention of the person in, a place of safety pending the persons admission to the specified hospital.
The court shall, as soon as reasonably practicable after making an assessment order, give notice of the making of the order to

P3para.Text: the person subject to the order;
any solicitor acting for the person;
in a case where

P4para.Text: the person has been charged with an offence; and
a relevant disposal has not been made in the proceedings in respect of the offence,

P3para.Text: the prosecutor;
in a case where the person, immediately before the order was made, was in custody, the Scottish Ministers; and
the Mental Welfare Commission.

P2para.Text: In this section

Para.Text: court has the same meaning as in section 52B of this Act;

medical treatment has the meaning given by section 329(1) of the Mental Health (Care and Treatment)
(Scotland) Act 2003 (asp 13);
relevant disposal has the same meaning as in section 52B of this Act; and
specified means specified in the assessment order.

P1group.Title: Assessment order made ex proprio motu: application of section 52D

P2para.Text: Where

P3para.Text: a person has been charged with an offence;
the person has not been sentenced; and
it appears to the court that the person has a mental disorder,

P2para.Text: the court may, subject to subsections (2) and (3) below, make an assessment order in respect of that person.

The court may make an assessment order under subsection (1) above only if it would make one under subsections (2) to (11) of section 52D of this Act; and those subsections shall apply for the purposes of subsection (1) above as they apply for the purposes of subsection (1) of that section, references in those subsections to the person in respect of whom the application is made being construed as references to the person in respect of whom it is proposed to make an assessment order.

An assessment order made under subsection (1) above shall, for the purposes of this Act and the Mental Health (Care and Treatment)
(Scotland) Act 2003 (asp 13), be treated as if made under section 52D(2) of this Act.
In this section, court has the same meaning as in section 52B of this Act.

P1group.Title: Assessment order: supplementary

P2para.Text: If, before the expiry of the period of 7 days beginning with the day on which an assessment order is made

P3para.Text: in the case of a person who, immediately before the order was made, was in custody, it appears to the Scottish Ministers; or
in any other case, it appears to the court,

P2para.Text: that, by reason of emergency or other special circumstances, it is not reasonably practicable for the person to be admitted to the hospital specified in the order, the Scottish Ministers, or, as the case may be, the court, may direct that the person be admitted to the hospital specified in the direction.

Where the court makes a direction under subsection (1) above, it shall, as soon as reasonably practicable after making the direction, inform the person having custody of the person subject to the assessment order of the making of the direction.
Where the Scottish Ministers make a direction under subsection (1) above, they shall, as soon as reasonably practicable after making the direction, inform

P3para.Text: the court;
the person having custody of the person subject to the assessment order; and
in a case where

P4para.Text: the person has been charged with an offence; and
a relevant disposal has not been made in the proceedings in respect of the offence,

P3para.Text: the prosecutor,

P2para.Text: of the making of the direction.
Where a direction is made under subsection (1) above, the assessment order shall have effect as if the hospital specified in the direction were the hospital specified in the order.
In this section

Para.Text: court means the court which made the assessment order; and
relevant disposal has the same meaning as in section 52B of this Act.

P1group.Title: Review of assessment order

P2para.Text: The responsible medical officer shall, before the expiry of the period of 28 days beginning with the day on which the assessment order is made, submit a report in writing to the court

P3para.Text: as to whether the conditions mentioned in section 52D(7) of this Act are met in respect of the person subject to the order; and
as to any matters specified by the court under section 52D(2) of this Act.

P2para.Text: The responsible medical officer shall, at the same time as such officer submits the report to the court, send a copy of such report

P3para.Text: to the person in respect of whom the report is made;
to any solicitor acting for the person;
in a case where

P4para.Text: the person has been charged with an offence; and
a relevant disposal has not been made in the proceedings in respect of the offence,

P3para.Text: to the prosecutor; and
to the Scottish Ministers.

P2para.Text: Subject to subsection (4) below, the court shall, on receiving a report submitted under subsection (1) above, revoke the assessment order and

P3para.Text: subject to subsections (7) and (8) below, make a treatment order; or

commit the person to prison or such other institution to which the person might have been committed had the assessment order not been made or otherwise deal with the person as the court considers appropriate.

P2para.Text: If, on receiving a report submitted under subsection (1) above, the court is satisfied that further time is necessary to assess whether the conditions mentioned in section 52D(7) of this Act are met in respect of the person subject to the assessment order, it may, on one occasion only, make an order extending the assessment order for a period not exceeding 7 days beginning with the day on which the order otherwise would cease to authorise the detention of the person in hospital.
The court may, under subsection (4) above, extend an assessment order in the absence of the person subject to the order only if

P3para.Text: the person is represented by counsel or a solicitor;
that counsel or solicitor is given an opportunity of being heard; and
the court is satisfied that it is

P4para.Text: impracticable; or
inappropriate,

P3para.Text: for the person to be brought before it.

P2para.Text: Where the court makes an order under subsection (4) above, it shall, as soon as reasonably practicable after making the order, give notice of the making of the order to

P3para.Text: the persons mentioned in paragraphs (a) and (b) of subsection (2) above;
in a case where

P4para.Text: the person has been charged with an offence; and
a relevant disposal has not been made in the proceedings in respect of the offence,

P3para.Text: the prosecutor;
the Scottish Ministers; and
the persons responsible medical officer.

P2para.Text: The court shall make a treatment order under subsection (3)(a) above only if it would make one under subsections (2) to (10) of section 52M of this Act; and those subsections shall apply for the purposes of subsection (3)(a) above as they apply for the purposes of that section, references in those subsections to the person in respect of whom the application is made being construed as references to the person in respect of whom it is proposed to make a treatment order.

A treatment order made under subsection (3)(a) above shall, for the purposes of this Act and the Mental Health (Care and Treatment)
(Scotland) Act 2003 (asp 13), be treated as if made under section 52M(2) of this Act.

The responsible medical officer shall, where that officer is satisfied that there has been a change of circumstances since the assessment order was made which justifies the variation of the order, submit a report to the court in writing.
Where a report is submitted under subsection (9) above, the court shall

P3para.Text: if satisfied that the person need not be subject to an assessment order, revoke the order and take any action mentioned in subsection (3)(b) above; or
if not so satisfied

P4para.Text: confirm the order;
vary the order; or
revoke the order and take any action mentioned in subsection (3)(b) above.

P2para.Text: Sections 52D, 52F, 52H and 52J of this Act and subsections (1) to (3) above apply to the variation of an order under subsection (10)(b)(ii) above as they apply to an assessment order.
In this section

Para.Text: court means the court which made the assessment order;
relevant disposal has the same meaning as in section 52B of this Act; and

responsible medical officer means the persons responsible medical officer appointed under section 230 of the Mental Health (Care and Treatment)
(Scotland) Act 2003 (asp 13).

P1group.Title: Early termination of assessment order

P2para.Text: This section applies where

P3para.Text: in the case of a person who, when the assessment order is made, has not been removed to the hospital specified in the order, the period of 7 days beginning with the day on which the order is made has not expired;
in the case of a person

P4para.Text: who, when the assessment order is made, has been admitted to the hospital specified in the order; or
who has been removed under paragraph (a) of subsection (6) of section 52D of this Act to the hospital so specified,

P3para.Text: the period of 28 days beginning with the day on which the order is made has not expired; or

in the case of a person in respect of whom the court has made an order under section 52G(4) of this Act extending the assessment order for a period, the period for which the order was extended has not expired.

P2para.Text: An assessment order shall cease to have effect on the occurrence of any of the following events

P3para.Text: the making of a treatment order in respect of the person subject to the assessment order;
in a case where

P4para.Text: the person subject to the assessment order has been charged with an offence; and
a relevant disposal had not been made in the proceedings in respect of that offence when the order was made,

P3para.Text: the making of a relevant disposal in such proceedings;
in a case where the person subject to the assessment order has been convicted of an offence but has not been sentenced

P4para.Text: the deferral of sentence by the court under section 202(1) of this Act;
the making of one of the orders mentioned in subsection (3) below or
the imposition of any sentence.

P2para.Text: The orders are

P3para.Text: an interim compulsion order;
a compulsion order;
a guardianship order;
a hospital direction;
any order under section 57 of this Act; or
a probation order which includes a requirement imposed by virtue of section 230(1) of this Act.

P2para.Text: In this section, relevant disposal has the same meaning as in section 52B of this Act.

P1group.Title: Power of court on assessment order ceasing to have effect

P2para.Text: Where, otherwise than by virtue of section 52G(3) or (10) or 52H(2) of this Act, an assessment order ceases to have effect the court shall commit the person who was subject to the order to prison or such other institution to which the person might have been committed had the order not been made or otherwise deal with the person as the court considers appropriate.
In this section, court has the same meaning as in section 52B of this Act.

P1group.Title: Prosecutors power to apply for treatment order

P2para.Text: Where

P3para.Text: a person has been charged with an offence;
a relevant disposal has not been made in the proceedings in respect of the offence; and
it appears to the prosecutor that the person has a mental disorder,

P2para.Text: the prosecutor may apply to the court for an order under section 52M of this Act (in this Act referred to as a treatment order) in respect of that person.

Where the prosecutor applies for a treatment order under subsection (1) above, the prosecutor shall, as soon as reasonably practicable after making the application, inform the persons mentioned in subsection (3) below of the making of the application.
Those persons are

P3para.Text: the person in respect of whom the application is made;
any solicitor acting for the person; and
in a case where the person is in custody, the Scottish Ministers.

P2para.Text: In this section, court and relevant disposal have the same meanings as in section 52B of this Act.

P1group.Title: Scottish Ministers' power to apply for treatment order

P2para.Text: Where

P3para.Text: a person has been charged with an offence;
the person has not been sentenced;
the person is in custody; and
it appears to the Scottish Ministers that the person has a mental disorder,

P2para.Text: the Scottish Ministers may apply to the court for a treatment order in respect of that person.

Where the Scottish Ministers apply for an order under subsection (1) above, they shall, as soon as reasonably practicable after making the application, inform the persons mentioned in subsection (3) below of the making of the application.
Those persons are

P3para.Text: the person in respect of whom the application is made;
any solicitor acting for the person; and
in a case where a relevant disposal has not been made in the proceedings in respect of the offence with which the person is charged, the prosecutor.

P2para.Text: In this section, court and relevant disposal have the same meanings as in section 52B of this Act.

P1group.Title: Treatment order

P2para.Text: This section applies where an application for a treatment order is made under section 52K(1) or 52L(1) of this Act.
If the court is satisfied

P3para.Text: on the written or oral evidence of two medical practitioners, as to the matters mentioned in subsection (3) below; and
that, having regard to the matters mentioned in subsection (4) below, it is appropriate,

P2para.Text: it may, subject to subsection (5) below, make a treatment order authorising the measures mentioned in subsection (6) below.
The matters referred to in subsection (2)(a) above are

P3para.Text: that the conditions mentioned in subsection (7) of section 52D of this Act are met in relation to the person in respect of whom the application is made;
that the hospital proposed by the approved medical practitioner and the medical practitioner is suitable for the purpose of giving medical treatment to the person; and
that, if a treatment order were made, such person could be admitted to such hospital before the expiry of the period of 7 days beginning with the day on which the order is made.

P2para.Text: The matters referred to in subsection (2)(b) above are

P3para.Text: all the circumstances (including the nature of the offence with which the person in respect of whom the application is made is charged or, as the case may be, of which the person was convicted); and
any alternative means of dealing with the person.

P2para.Text: The court may make a treatment order only if the person in respect of whom the application is made has not been sentenced.
The measures are

P3para.Text: in the case of a person who, when the treatment order is made, has not been admitted to the specified hospital, the removal, before the expiry of the period of 7 days beginning with the day on which the order is made, of the person to the specified hospital by

P4para.Text: a constable;

a person employed in, or contracted to provide services in or to, the specified hospital who is authorised by the managers of that hospital to remove persons to hospital for the purposes of this section; or
a specified person;

P3para.Text: the detention of the person in the specified hospital; and

the giving to the person, in accordance with Part 16 of the Mental Health (Care and Treatment)
(Scotland) Act 2003 (asp 13), of medical treatment.

P2para.Text: The court may make a treatment order in the absence of the person in respect of whom the application is made only if

P3para.Text: the person is represented by counsel or solicitor;
that counsel or solicitor is given an opportunity of being heard; and
the court is satisfied that it is

P4para.Text: impracticable; or
inappropriate,

P3para.Text: for the person to be brought before it.

P2para.Text: A treatment order may include such directions as the court thinks fit for the removal of the person subject to the order to, and detention of the person in, a place of safety pending the persons admission to the specified hospital.
The court shall, as soon as reasonably practicable after making a treatment order, give notice of the making of the order to

P3para.Text: the person subject to the order;
any solicitor acting for the person;
in a case where

P4para.Text: the person has been charged with an offence; and
a relevant disposal has not been made in the proceedings in respect of the offence,

P3para.Text: the prosecutor;
in a case where the person, immediately before the order was made

P4para.Text: was in custody; or
was subject to an assessment order and, immediately before that order was made, was in custody,

P3para.Text: the Scottish Ministers; and
the Mental Welfare Commission.

P2para.Text: In this section

Para.Text: court has the same meaning as in section 52B of this Act;
medical treatment has the same meaning as in section 52D of this Act; and
specified means specified in the treatment order.

P1group.Title: Treatment order made ex proprio motu: application of section 52M

P2para.Text: Where

P3para.Text: a person has been charged with an offence;
the person has not been sentenced; and
it appears to the court that the person has a mental disorder,

P2para.Text: the court may, subject to subsections (2) and (3) below, make a treatment order in respect of that person.

The court may make a treatment order under subsection (1) above only if it would make one under subsections (2) to (10) of section 52M of this Act; and those subsections shall apply for the purposes of subsection (1) above as they apply for the purposes of subsection (1) of that section, references in those subsections to the person in respect of whom the application is made being construed as references to the person in respect of whom it is proposed to make a treatment order.

A treatment order made under subsection (1) above shall, for the purposes of this Act and the Mental Health (Care and Treatment)
(Scotland) Act 2003 (asp 13), be treated as if made under section 52M(2) of this Act.
In this section, court has the same meaning as in section 52B of this Act.

P1group.Title: Treatment order: supplementary

P2para.Text: If, before the expiry of the period of 7 days beginning with the day on which the treatment order is made

P3para.Text: in the case of a person to whom subsection (2) below applies, it appears to the Scottish Ministers; or
in any other case, it appears to the court,

P2para.Text: that, by reason of emergency or other special circumstances, it is not reasonably practicable for the person to be admitted to the hospital specified in the order, the Scottish Ministers, or, as the case may be, the court, may direct that the person be admitted to the hospital specified in the direction.
This subsection applies to

P3para.Text: a person who is in custody immediately before the treatment order is made; or
a person

P4para.Text: who was subject to an assessment order immediately before the treatment order is made; and
who was in custody immediately before that assessment order was made.

P2para.Text: Where the court makes a direction under subsection (1) above, it shall, as soon as reasonably practicable after making the direction, inform the person having custody of the person subject to the treatment order of the making of the direction.
Where the Scottish Ministers make a direction under subsection (1) above, they shall, as soon as reasonably practicable after making the direction, inform

P3para.Text: the court;
the person having custody of the person subject to the treatment order; and
in a case where

P4para.Text: the person has been charged with an offence; and
a relevant disposal has not been made in the proceedings in respect of the offence,

P3para.Text: the prosecutor,

P2para.Text: of the making of the direction.
Where a direction is made under subsection (1) above, the treatment order shall have effect as if the hospital specified in the direction were the hospital specified in the order.
In this section

Para.Text: court means the court which made the treatment order; and
relevant disposal has the same meaning as in section 52B of this Act.

P1group.Title: Review of treatment order

P2para.Text: The responsible medical officer shall, where that officer is satisfied

P3para.Text: that any of the conditions mentioned in section 52D(7) of this Act are no longer met in respect of the person subject to the treatment order; or
that there has otherwise been a change of circumstances since the order was made which makes the continued detention of the person in hospital by virtue of the order no longer appropriate,

P2para.Text: submit a report in writing to the court.
Where a report is submitted under subsection (1) above, the court shall

P3para.Text: if satisfied that the person need not be subject to the treatment order

P4para.Text: revoke the order; and

commit the person to prison or such other institution to which the person might have been committed had the order not been made or otherwise deal with the person as the court considers appropriate; or

P3para.Text: if not so satisfied

P4para.Text: confirm the order;
vary the order; or
revoke the order and take any action mentioned in paragraph (a)(ii) above.

P2para.Text: Sections 52M, 52P, this section and sections 52R and 52S of this Act apply to the variation of a treatment order under subsection (2)(b)(ii) above as they apply to a treatment order.
In this section

Para.Text: court means the court which made the treatment order; and

responsible medical officer means the persons responsible medical officer appointed under section 230 of the Mental Health (Care and Treatment)
(Scotland) Act 2003 (asp 13).

P1group.Title: Termination of treatment order

P2para.Text: This section applies

P3para.Text: where, in the case of a person who, when the treatment order is made, has not been removed to the hospital specified in the order, the period of 7 days beginning with the day on which the order is made has not expired; or
in the case of a person

P4para.Text: who, when the treatment order is made, has been admitted to the hospital specified in the order; or
who has been removed under paragraph (a) of subsection (6) of section 52M of this Act to the hospital so specified.

P2para.Text: A treatment order shall cease to have effect on the occurrence of any of the following events

P3para.Text: in a case where

P4para.Text: the person subject to the treatment order has been charged with an offence; and
a relevant disposal had not been made in the proceedings in respect of such offence when the order was made,

P3para.Text: the making of a relevant disposal in such proceedings;
in a case where the person subject to the treatment order has been convicted of an offence but has not been sentenced

P4para.Text: the deferral of sentence by the court under section 202(1) of this Act;
the making of one of the orders mentioned in subsection (3) below; or
the imposition of any sentence.

P2para.Text: The orders are

P3para.Text: an interim compulsion order;
a compulsion order;
a guardianship order;
a hospital direction;
any order under section 57 of this Act; or
a probation order which includes a requirement imposed by virtue of section 230(1) of this Act.

P2para.Text: In this section, relevant disposal has the same meaning as in section 52B of this Act.

P1group.Title: Power of court on treatment order ceasing to have effect

P2para.Text: Where, otherwise than by virtue of section 52Q(2) or 52R(2) of this Act, a treatment order ceases to have effect the court shall commit the person who was subject to the order to prison or such other institution to which the person might have been committed had the order not been made or otherwise deal with the person as the court considers appropriate.
In this section, court has the same meaning as in section 52B of this Act.

P1group.Title: Prevention of delay in trials: assessment orders and treatment orders

P2para.Text: Subsections (4) to (9) of section 65 of this Act shall apply in the case of a person committed for an offence until liberated in due course of law who is detained in hospital by virtue of an assessment order or a treatment order as those subsections apply in the case of an accused who is

P3para.Text: committed for an offence until liberated in due course of law; and
detained by virtue of that committal.

P2para.Text: Section 147 of this Act shall apply in the case of a person charged with an offence in summary proceedings who is detained in hospital by virtue of an assessment order or a treatment order as it applies in the case of an accused who is detained in respect of that offence.
Any period during which, under

P3para.Text:
section 221 (as read with sections 222 and 223) of the Mental Health (Care and Treatment)
(Scotland) Act 2003 (asp 13); or
section 224 (as read with sections 225 and 226) of that Act,

P2para.Text: a patients detention is not authorised shall be taken into account for the purposes of the calculation of any of the periods mentioned in subsection (4) below.
Those periods are

P3para.Text: the total periods of 80 days , 110 daysand 140 days referred to ... in ... subsection (4) of section 65 of this Act as applied by subsection (1) above;
those total periods as extended under subsection (5) ... or, on appeal, under subsection (8) of that section as so applied;
the total of 40 days referred to in section 147 of this Act (prevention of delay in trials in summary proceedings) as applied by subsection (2) above; and
that period as extended under subsection (2) of that section or, on appeal, under subsection (3) of that section as so applied.

Title.Emphasis: Effect of assessment and treatment orders on pre-existing mental health orders

P1group.Title: Effect of assessment order and treatment order on pre-existing mental health order

P2para.Text: This section applies where

P3para.Text: a patient is subject to a relevant order; and
an assessment order or a treatment order is made in respect of the patient.

P2para.Text: The relevant order shall... cease to authorise the measures specified in it for the period during which the patient is subject to the assessment order or, as the case may be, treatment order.
In this section, a relevant order means

P3para.Text: an interim compulsory treatment order made under section 65(2) of the 2003 Act; and
a compulsory treatment order made under section 64(4)(a) of that Act.

P1group.Title: Mentally disordered offenders: interim compulsion orders

P1para.Text: For section 53 of the 1995 Act (interim hospital orders), there shall be substituted

P1group.Title: Interim compulsion order

P2para.Text: This section applies where a person (referred to in this section and in sections 53A to 53D of this Act as an offender)

P3para.Text: is convicted in the High Court or the sheriff court of an offence punishable by imprisonment (other than an offence the sentence for which is fixed by law); or
is remitted to the High Court by the sheriff under any enactment for sentence for such an offence.

P2para.Text: If the court is satisfied

P3para.Text: on the written or oral evidence of two medical practitioners

P4para.Text: that the offender has a mental disorder; and
as to the matters mentioned in subsection (3) below; and

P3para.Text: that, having regard to the matters mentioned in subsection (4) below, it is appropriate,

P2para.Text: it may, subject to subsection (7) below, make an order (in this Act referred to as an interim compulsion order) authorising the measures mentioned in subsection (8) below and specifying any matters to be included in the report under section 53B(1) of this Act.
The matters referred to in subsection (2)(a)(ii) above are

P3para.Text: that there are reasonable grounds for believing

P4para.Text: that the conditions mentioned in subsection (5) below are likely to be met in respect of the offender; and
that the offenders mental disorder is such that it would be appropriate to make one of the disposals mentioned in subsection (6) below in relation to the offender;

P3para.Text: that the hospital to be specified in the order is suitable for the purpose of assessing whether the conditions mentioned in subsection (5) below are met in respect of the offender;
that, were an interim compulsion order made, the offender could be admitted to such hospital before the expiry of the period of 7 days beginning with the day on which the order is made; and
that it would not be reasonably practicable for the assessment mentioned in paragraph (b) above to be made unless an order were made.

P2para.Text: The matters referred to in subsection (2)(b) above are

P3para.Text: all the circumstances (including the nature of the offence of which the offender is convicted); and
any alternative means of dealing with the offender.

P2para.Text: The conditions referred to in paragraphs (a)(i) and (b) of subsection (3) above are

P3para.Text: that medical treatment which would be likely to

P4para.Text: prevent the mental disorder worsening; or
alleviate any of the symptoms, or effects, of the disorder,

P3para.Text: is available for the offender;
that if the offender were not provided with such medical treatment there would be a significant risk

P4para.Text: to the health, safety or welfare of the offender; or
to the safety of any other person; and

P3para.Text: that the making of an interim compulsion order in respect of the offender is necessary.

P2para.Text: The disposals are

P3para.Text: both a compulsion order that authorises detention in hospital by virtue of section 57A(8)(a) of this Act and a restriction order; or
a hospital direction.

P2para.Text: An interim compulsion order may authorise detention in a state hospital only if, on the written or oral evidence of the two medical practitioners mentioned in subsection (2)(a) above, it appears to the court

P3para.Text: that the offender requires to be detained in hospital under conditions of special security; and
that such conditions of special security can be provided only in a state hospital.

P2para.Text: The measures are

P3para.Text: in the case of an offender who, when the interim compulsion order is made, has not been admitted to the specified hospital, the removal, before the expiry of the period of 7 days beginning with the day on which the order is made, of the offender to the specified hospital by

P4para.Text: a constable;

a person employed in, or contracted to provide services in or to, the specified hospital who is authorised by the managers of that hospital to remove persons to hospital for the purposes of this section; or
a specified person;

P3para.Text: the detention, for a period not exceeding 12 weeks beginning with the day on which the order is made, of the offender in the specified hospital; and

during the period of 12 weeks beginning with the day on which the order is made, the giving to the offender, in accordance with Part 16 of the Mental Health (Care and Treatment)
(Scotland) Act 2003 (asp 13), of medical treatment.

P2para.Text: An interim compulsion order may include such directions as the court thinks fit for the removal of the offender to, and the detention of the offender in, a place of safety pending the offenders admission to the specified hospital.
The court may make an interim compulsion order in the absence of the offender only if

P3para.Text: the offender is represented by counsel or solicitor;
that counsel or solicitor is given an opportunity of being heard; and
the court is satisfied that it is

P4para.Text: impracticable; or
inappropriate,

P3para.Text: for the offender to be brought before it.

P2para.Text: The court shall, as soon as reasonably practicable after making an interim compulsion order, give notice of the making of the order to

P3para.Text: the person subject to the order;
any solicitor acting for that person;
the Scottish Ministers; and
the Mental Welfare Commission.

P2para.Text: Where a court makes an interim compulsion order in relation to an offender, the court

P3para.Text: shall not, at the same time

P4para.Text: make an order under section 200 of this Act;
impose a fine;
pass sentence of imprisonment;
make a compulsion order;
make a guardianship order;
make a probation order; or
make a community service order,

P3para.Text: in relation of the offender;
may make any other order which it has power to make apart from this section.

P2para.Text: In this section

Para.Text: medical treatment has the same meaning as in section 52D of this Act;
sentence of imprisonment includes any sentence or order for detention; and
specified means specified in the interim compulsion order.

P1group.Title: Interim compulsion order: supplementary

P2para.Text: If, before the expiry of the period of 7 days beginning with the day on which the interim compulsion order is made, it appears to the court, or, as the case may be, the Scottish Ministers, that, by reason of emergency or other special circumstances, it is not reasonably practicable for the offender to be admitted to the hospital specified in the order, the court, or, as the case may be, the Scottish Ministers, may direct that the offender be admitted to the hospital specified in the direction.
Where

P3para.Text: the court makes a direction under subsection (1) above, it shall, as soon as reasonably practicable after making the direction, inform the person having custody of the offender; and
the Scottish Ministers make such a direction, they shall, as soon as reasonably practicable after making the direction, inform

P4para.Text: the court; and
the person having custody of the offender.

P2para.Text: Where a direction is made under subsection (1) above, the interim compulsion order shall have effect as if the hospital specified in the direction were the hospital specified in the order.
In this section, court means the court which made the interim compulsion order.

P1group.Title: Review and extension of interim compulsion order

P2para.Text: The responsible medical officer shall, before the expiry of the period specified by the court under section 53(8)(b) of this Act, submit a report in writing to the court

P3para.Text: as to the matters mentioned in subsection (2) below; and
as to any matters specified by the court under section 53(2) of this Act.

P2para.Text: The matters are

P3para.Text: whether the conditions mentioned in section 53(5) of this Act are met in respect of the offender;
the type (or types) of mental disorder that the offender has; and
whether it is necessary to extend the interim compulsion order to allow further time for the assessment mentioned in section 53(3)(b) of this Act.

P2para.Text: The responsible medical officer shall, at the same time as such officer submits the report to the court, send a copy of such report to

P3para.Text: the offender; and
any solicitor acting for the offender.

P2para.Text: The court may, on receiving the report submitted under subsection (1) above, if satisfied that the extension of the order is necessary, extend the order for such period (not exceeding 12 weeks beginning with the day on which the order would cease to have effect were such an extension not made) as the court may specify.

The court may extend an interim compulsion order under subsection (4) above for a period only if, by doing so, the total period for which the offender will be subject to the order does not exceed 12 months beginning with the day on which the order was first made.
The court may, under subsection (4) above, extend an interim compulsion order in the absence of the offender only if

P3para.Text: the offender is represented by counsel or a solicitor;
that counsel or solicitor is given an opportunity of being heard; and
the court is satisfied that it is

P4para.Text: impracticable; or
inappropriate,

P3para.Text: for the offender to be brought before it.

P2para.Text: Subsections (1) to (9) of this section shall apply for the purposes of an interim compulsion order extended under subsection (4) above as they apply for the purposes of an interim compulsion order, references in those subsections to the period specified by the court under section 53(8)(b) of this Act being construed as references to the period specified by the court under subsection (4) above.
Where a report is submitted under subsection (1) above, the court may, before the expiry of the period specified by the court under section 53(8)(b) of this Act

P3para.Text: revoke the interim compulsion order and make one of the disposals mentioned in section 53(6) of this Act; or

revoke the interim compulsion order and deal with the offender in any way (other than by making an interim compulsion order) in which the court could have dealt with the offender if no such order had been made.

P2para.Text: In this section

Para.Text: court means the court which made the interim compulsion order; and

responsible medical officer means the responsible medical officer appointed in respect of the offender under section 230 of the Mental Health (Care and Treatment)
(Scotland) Act 2003 (asp 13).

P1group.Title: Early termination of interim compulsion order

P2para.Text: An interim compulsion order shall cease to have effect if the court

P3para.Text: makes a compulsion order in relation to the offender;
makes a hospital direction in relation to the offender; or
deals with the offender in some other way, including the imposing of a sentence of imprisonment on the offender.

P2para.Text: In this section, court means the court which made the interim compulsion order.

P1group.Title: Power of court on interim compulsion order ceasing to have effect

P2para.Text: Where, otherwise than by virtue of section 53B(8) or 53C of this Act, an interim compulsion order ceases to have effect the court may deal with the offender who was subject to the order in any way (other than the making of a new interim compulsion order) in which it could have dealt with the offender if no such order had been made.
In this section, court means the court which made the interim compulsion order.

Title.Emphasis: Remand for inquiry into mental condition

P1group.Title: Remand for inquiry into mental condition: time-limit for appeals

P1para.Text: In section 200 of the 1995 Act (remand for inquiry into physical or mental condition), in subsection (9)

P3para.Text: after the word may, where it second occurs, there shall be inserted , at any time during the period when the order for his committal, or, as the case may be, renewal of such order, is in force, ; and
the words within 24 hours of his remand or, as the case may be, committal, shall cease to have effect.

P1group.Title: Mentally disordered offenders: compulsion orders

P1para.Text: After section 57 of the 1995 Act there shall be inserted

P1group.Title: Compulsion order

P2para.Text: This section applies where a person (in this section and in sections 57B to 57D of this Act, referred to as the offender)

P3para.Text: is convicted in the High Court or the sheriff court of an offence punishable by imprisonment (other than an offence the sentence for which is fixed by law); or
is remitted to the High Court by the sheriff under any enactment for sentence for such an offence.

P2para.Text: If the court is satisfied

P3para.Text: on the written or oral evidence of two medical practitioners, that the conditions mentioned in subsection (3) below are met in respect of the offender; and
that, having regard to the matters mentioned in subsection (4) below, it is appropriate,

P2para.Text: it may, subject to subsection (5) below, make an order (in this Act referred to as a compulsion order) authorising, subject to subsection (7) below, for the period of 6 months beginning with the day on which the order is made such of the measures mentioned in subsection (8) below as may be specified in the order.
The conditions referred to in subsection (2)(a) above are

P3para.Text: that the offender has a mental disorder;
that medical treatment which would be likely to

P4para.Text: prevent the mental disorder worsening; or
alleviate any of the symptoms, or effects, of the disorder,

P3para.Text: is available for the offender;
that if the offender were not provided with such medical treatment there would be a significant risk

P4para.Text: to the health, safety or welfare of the offender; or
to the safety of any other person; and

P3para.Text: that the making of a compulsion order in respect of the offender is necessary.

P2para.Text: The matters referred to in subsection (2)(b) above are

P3para.Text: the mental health officers report, prepared in accordance with section 57C of this Act, in respect of the offender;
all the circumstances, including

P4para.Text: the nature of the offence of which the offender was convicted; and
the antecedents of the offender; and

P3para.Text: any alternative means of dealing with the offender.

P2para.Text: The court may, subject to subsection (6) below, make a compulsion order authorising the detention of the offender in a hospital by virtue of subsection (8)(a) below only if satisfied, on the written or oral evidence of the two medical practitioners mentioned in subsection (2)(a) above, that

P3para.Text: the medical treatment mentioned in subsection (3)(b) above can be provided only if the offender is detained in hospital;
the offender could be admitted to the hospital to be specified in the order before the expiry of the period of 7 days beginning with the day on which the order is made; and
the hospital to be so specified is suitable for the purpose of giving the medical treatment to the offender.

P2para.Text: A compulsion order may authorise detention in a state hospital only if, on the written or oral evidence of the two medical practitioners mentioned in subsection (2)(a) above, it appears to the court

P3para.Text: that the offender requires to be detained in hospital under conditions of special security; and
that such conditions of special security can be provided only in a state hospital.

P2para.Text: Where the court

P3para.Text: makes a compulsion order in respect of an offender; and
also makes a restriction order in respect of the offender,

P2para.Text: the compulsion order shall authorise the measures specified in it without limitation of time.
The measures mentioned in subsection (2) above are

P3para.Text: the detention of the offender in the specified hospital;

the giving to the offender, in accordance with Part 16 of the Mental Health (Care and Treatment)
(Scotland) Act 2003 (asp 13), of medical treatment;
the imposition of a requirement on the offender to attend

P4para.Text: on specified or directed dates; or
at specified or directed intervals,

P3para.Text: specified or directed places with a view to receiving medical treatment;
the imposition of a requirement on the offender to attend

P4para.Text: on specified or directed dates; or
at specified or directed intervals,

P3para.Text: specified or directed places with a view to receiving community care services, relevant services or any treatment, care or service;
subject to subsection (9) below, the imposition of a requirement on the offender to reside at a specified place;
the imposition of a requirement on the offender to allow
