whether it continues to be necessary for the patient to be subject to the restriction order.

P2para.Text: If, having considered the matters mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (d) of subsection (2) above, the responsible medical officer is not satisfied that the patient has a mental disorder, the responsible medical officer shall, as soon as practicable after considering those matters, submit to the Scottish Ministers a report complying with the requirements set out in section 183(3) of this Act and including a recommendation that the compulsion order be revoked.
If, having considered the matters mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (d) of subsection (2) above, the responsible medical officer

P3para.Text: is satisfied that the patient has a mental disorder; but
is not satisfied

P4para.Text: that, as a result of the patients mental disorder, it is necessary, in order to protect any other person from serious harm, for the patient to be detained in hospital, whether or not for medical treatment; and

Text.Substitution: either
that the conditions mentioned in paragraphs (b) and (c) of section 182(4) of this Act continue to apply in respect of the patient; or
that it continues to be necessary for the patient to be subject to the compulsion order,

P3para.Text: the responsible medical officer shall, as soon as practicable after considering those matters, submit to the Scottish Ministers a report complying with the requirements set out in section 183(3) of this Act and including a recommendation that the compulsion order be revoked.

P2para.Text: If, having considered the matters mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (d) of subsection (2) above, the responsible medical officer

P3para.Text: is satisfied

P4para.Text: that the conditions mentioned in section 182(4) of this Act continue to apply in respect of the patient; and
that it continues to be necessary for the patient to be subject to the compulsion order; but

P3para.Text: is not satisfied that

P4para.Text: that, as a result of the patients mental disorder, it is necessary, in order to protect any other person from serious harm, for the patient to be detained in hospital, whether or not for medical treatment; and
that it continues to be necessary for the patient to be subject to the restriction order,

P3para.Text: the responsible medical officer shall, as soon as practicable after considering those matters, submit to the Scottish Ministers a report complying with the requirements set out in section 183(3) of this Act and including a recommendation that the restriction order be revoked.

P2para.Text: If, having considered the matters mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (d) of subsection (2) above, the responsible medical officer

P3para.Text: is satisfied

P4para.Text: that the conditions mentioned in section 182(4) of this Act continue to apply in respect of the patient; and
that it continues to be necessary for the patient to be subject to the compulsion order and the restriction order; but

P3para.Text: is not satisfied that, as a result of the patients mental disorder, it is necessary, in order to protect any other person from serious harm, for the patient to be detained in hospital, whether or not for medical treatment,

P2para.Text: the responsible medical officer may submit to the Scottish Ministers a report complying with the requirements set out in section 183(3) of this Act and including a recommendation that the patient be conditionally discharged.
Where the responsible medical officer

P3para.Text: submits a report under subsection (5) above; and
is satisfied that the compulsion order should be varied by modifying the measures specified in it,

P2para.Text: the responsible medical officer shall include in the report a recommendation that the compulsion order be varied in that way.

Title.Emphasis: Reference to Tribunal by Scottish Ministers

P1group.Title: Duty of Scottish Ministers on receiving report from responsible medical officer

P2para.Text: Where a patients responsible medical officer submits to the Scottish Ministers

P3para.Text: a report under section 183(2) of this Act that includes a recommendation; or
a report under section 184 of this Act,

P2para.Text: the Scottish Ministers shall make a reference to the Tribunal in respect of the compulsion order and restriction order to which the patient is subject.
Where a reference is made under subsection (1) above, the Scottish Ministers shall, as soon as practicable, give notice that a reference is to be made to

P3para.Text: the patient;
the patients named person;
any guardian of the patient;
any welfare attorney of the patient;
the patients responsible medical officer;
the mental health officer; and
the Commission.

P2para.Text: A reference under subsection (1) above shall state

P3para.Text: the name and address of the patient;
the name and address of the patients named person; and
the recommendation included in the report submitted by the responsible medical officer.

P1group.Title: Commissions power to require Scottish Ministers to make reference to Tribunal

P2para.Text: This section applies where a patient is subject to a compulsion order and a restriction order.

If it appears to the Commission that it is appropriate to do so, it may, by notice in writing to the Scottish Ministers, require them to make a reference to the Tribunal in respect of the compulsion order and the restriction order to which the patient is subject.
Where, under subsection (2), the Commission gives notice to the Scottish Ministers, the Commission shall include in that notice its reasons for requiring the Scottish Ministers to make the reference.

P1group.Title: Notice under section 186(2): reference to Tribunal

P2para.Text: This section applies where, under section 186(2) of this Act, the Commission gives notice to the Scottish Ministers.

The Scottish Ministers shall, as soon as practicable after receiving notice under section 186(2) of this Act, make a reference to the Tribunal in respect of the compulsion order and restriction order to which the patient is subject.

Where a reference is made under subsection (2) above, the Scottish Ministers shall, as soon as practicable, give notice that the reference is to be or, as the case may be, has been made to the persons mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (g) of section 185(2) of this Act.
A reference under subsection (2) above shall state

P3para.Text: the name and address of the patient;
the name and address of the patients named person; and
the reason given by the Commission in the notice under section 186(2) of this Act for requiring the Scottish Ministers to make the reference.

Title.Emphasis: Scottish Ministers' duty to keep orders under review

P1group.Title: Duty of Scottish Ministers to keep compulsion order and restriction order under review

P2para.Text: This section applies where a patient is subject to a compulsion order and a restriction order.
Without prejudice to the duties imposed on the Scottish Ministers by sections 185(1), 187(2) and 189(2) of this Act, the Scottish Ministers shall from time to time consider

P3para.Text: whether the conditions mentioned in section 182(4) of this Act continue to apply in respect of the patient;

whether, as a result of the patients mental disorder, it is necessary, in order to protect any other person from serious harm, for the patient to be detained in hospital, whether or not for medical treatment;
whether it continues to be necessary for the patient to be subject to the compulsion order; and
whether it continues to be necessary for the patient to be subject to the restriction order.

P2para.Text: If, having considered the matters mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (d) of subsection (2) above, the Scottish Ministers are not satisfied that the patient has a mental disorder, they shall apply to the Tribunal under section 191 of this Act for an order under section 193 of this Act revoking the compulsion order.
If, having considered the matters mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (d) of subsection (2) above, the Scottish Ministers

P3para.Text: are satisfied that the patient has a mental disorder; but
are not satisfied

P4para.Text: that, as a result of the patients mental disorder, it is necessary, in order to protect any other person from serious harm, for the patient to be detained in hospital, whether or not for medical treatment; and

Text.Substitution: either
that the conditions mentioned in paragraphs (b) and (c) of section 182(4) of this Act continue to apply in respect of the patient; or
that it continues to be necessary for the patient to be subject to the compulsion order,

P3para.Text: they shall, as soon as practicable after considering those matters, apply to the Tribunal under section 191 of this Act for an order under section 193 of this Act revoking the compulsion order.

P2para.Text: If, having considered the matters mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (d) of subsection (2) above, the Scottish Ministers

P3para.Text: are satisfied

P4para.Text: that the conditions mentioned in section 182(4) of this Act continue to apply in respect of the patient; and
that it continues to be necessary for the patient to be subject to the compulsion order; but

P3para.Text: are not satisfied

P4para.Text: that, as a result of the patients mental disorder, it is necessary, in order to protect any other person from serious harm, for the patient to be detained in hospital, whether or not for medical treatment; and
that it continues to be necessary for the patient to be subject to the restriction order,

P3para.Text: they shall apply to the Tribunal under section 191 of this Act for an order under section 193 of this Act revoking the restriction order.

P2para.Text: Where the Scottish Ministers

P3para.Text: apply, by virtue of subsection (5) above, for an order revoking the restriction order; and
are satisfied that the compulsion order should be varied by modifying the measures specified in it,

P2para.Text: they shall apply to the Tribunal under section 191 of this Act for an order under section 193 of this Act varying the compulsion order in that way.
If, having considered the matters mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (d) of subsection (2) above, the Scottish Ministers

P3para.Text: are satisfied

P4para.Text: that the conditions mentioned in section 182(4) of this Act continue to apply in respect of the patient; and
that it continues to be necessary for the patient to be subject to the compulsion order and the restriction order; but

P3para.Text: are not satisfied that, as a result of the patients mental disorder, it is necessary, in order to protect any other person from serious harm, for the patient to be detained in hospital, whether or not for medical treatment,

P2para.Text: they may apply to the Tribunal under section 191 of this Act for an order under section 193 of this Act conditionally discharging the patient.

P1group.Title: Reference to Tribunal by Scottish Ministers

P2para.Text: This section applies where a patient is subject to a compulsion order and a restriction order.
If

P3para.Text: during the period of 2 years ending with the relevant day

P4para.Text: no reference under section 185(1) or 187(2) of this Act has been determined by the Tribunal; and
no application under section 191 or 192(2) of this Act has been determined by the Tribunal; and

P3para.Text: during each period of 2 years ending with the anniversary, in every year thereafter, of the relevant day

P4para.Text: no reference such as is mentioned in paragraph (a)(i) above or, subject to subsection (3) below, under this subsection has been determined by the Tribunal; and
no application such as is mentioned in paragraph (a)(ii) above has been determined by the Tribunal,

P3para.Text: the Scottish Ministers shall make a reference to the Tribunal in respect of the compulsion order and restriction order to which the patient is subject.

P2para.Text: The Scottish Ministers shall, in considering, under subsection (2)(b)(i) above, whether a reference has been determined by the Tribunal during any 2 year period, leave out of account any reference made under subsection (2) above that has been determined by it during the first year of that 2 year period.

Where a reference is made under subsection (2) above, the Scottish Ministers shall, as soon as practicable, give notice that a reference is to be or, as the case may be, has been made to the persons mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (g) of section 185(2) of this Act.
A reference under subsection (2) above shall state

P3para.Text: the name and address of the patient;
the name and address of the patients named person; and
the reason for making the reference.

P2para.Text: In subsection (2) above, the relevant day means the day which falls 2 years after the day on which the compulsion order is made.

P1group.Title: Application by Scottish Ministers: notification

P1para.Text: Where, by virtue of section 188 of this Act, an application is to be made under section 191 of this Act, the Scottish Ministers shall, as soon as practicable after the duty to make the application arises, give notice to the persons mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (g) of section 185(2) of this Act that the application is to be or, as the case may be, has been made.

P1group.Title: Application to Tribunal

P1para.Text: An application under this section to the Tribunal by the Scottish Ministers for an order under section 193 of this Act

P3para.Text: shall state

P4para.Text: the name and address of the patient;
the name and address of the patients named person;
the order (or orders) sought;
the modification of the measures specified in the compulsion order that is proposed by the Scottish Ministers; and
the reasons for seeking that modification; and

P3para.Text: shall be accompanied by such documents as may be prescribed by regulations.

P1group.Title: Application to Tribunal by patient and named person

P2para.Text: This section applies where a patient is subject to a compulsion order and a restriction order.
Each of the persons mentioned in subsection (3) below may, subject to subsections (4) and (5) below, make an application under this section to the Tribunal for an order under section 193 of this Act

P3para.Text: conditionally discharging the patient;
revoking the restriction order to which the patient is subject;
revoking the restriction order and varying the compulsion order by modifying the measures specified in it; or
revoking the compulsion order to which the patient is subject.

P2para.Text: Those persons are

P3para.Text: the patient; and
the patients named person.

P2para.Text: An application under this section may not be made

P3para.Text: during the period of 6 months beginning with the making of the compulsion order;
during the period of 3 months beginning with

P4para.Text: the making of an order in respect of the compulsion order made under section 193 of this Act; or
the making, under section 193 of this Act, by the Tribunal of a decision to make no order under that section.

P2para.Text: Neither of the persons mentioned in subsection (3) above may make more than one application under this section during

P3para.Text: the period of 12 months beginning with the day on which the compulsion order was made; or
any subsequent period of 12 months that begins with or with an anniversary of the expiry of the period of 12 months mentioned in paragraph (a) above.

P2para.Text: Where a patients named person makes an application under subsection (2) above, the named person shall give notice to the patient of the making of the application.

P1group.Title: Powers of Tribunal on reference under section 185(1), 187(2) or 189(2) or application under section 191 or 192(2)

P2para.Text: This section applies where

P3para.Text: an application is made under section 191 or 192(2) of this Act; or
a reference is made under section 185(1), 187(2) or 189(2) of this Act.

P2para.Text: If the Tribunal is satisfied

P3para.Text: that the patient has a mental disorder; and

that, as a result of the patients mental disorder, it is necessary, in order to protect any other person from serious harm, for the patient to be detained in hospital, whether or not for medical treatment,

P2para.Text: it shall make no order under this section.
If the Tribunal is not satisfied that the patient has a mental disorder, the Tribunal shall make an order revoking the compulsion order.
If the Tribunal

P3para.Text: is satisfied that the patient has a mental disorder; but
is not satisfied

P4para.Text: that, as a result of the patients mental disorder, it is necessary, in order to protect any other person from serious harm, for the patient to be detained in hospital, whether or not for medical treatment; and

Text.Substitution: either
that the conditions mentioned in paragraphs (b) and (c) of section 182(4) of this Act continue to apply in respect of the patient; or
that it continues to be necessary for the patient to be subject to the compulsion order,

P3para.Text: it shall make an order revoking the compulsion order.

P2para.Text: If the Tribunal

P3para.Text: is satisfied

P4para.Text: that the conditions mentioned in section 182(4) of this Act continue to apply in respect of the patient; and
that it continues to be necessary for the patient to be subject to the compulsion order; but

P3para.Text: is not satisfied

P4para.Text: that, as a result of the patients mental disorder, it is necessary, in order to protect any other person from serious harm, for the patient to be detained in hospital, whether or not for medical treatment; and
that it continues to be necessary for the patient to be subject to the restriction order,

P3para.Text: it shall make an order revoking the restriction order.

P2para.Text: If the Tribunal

P3para.Text: makes an order, under subsection (5) above, revoking the restriction order; and
is satisfied that the compulsion order should be varied by modifying the measures specified in it,

P2para.Text: it shall make an order varying the compulsion order in that way.
If the Tribunal

P3para.Text: is satisfied

P4para.Text: that the conditions mentioned in section 182(4) of this Act continue to apply in respect of the patient; and
that it continues to be necessary for the patient to be subject to the compulsion order and the restriction order; but

P3para.Text: is not satisfied

P4para.Text: that, as a result of the patients mental disorder, it is necessary, in order to protect any other person from serious harm, for the patient to be detained in hospital, whether or not for medical treatment; and
that it is necessary for the patient to be detained in hospital,

P3para.Text: the Tribunal may make an order that the patient be conditionally discharged and impose such conditions on that discharge as it thinks fit.

P2para.Text: Before making a decision under this section the Tribunal shall

P3para.Text: afford the persons mentioned in subsection (9) below the opportunity

P4para.Text: of making representations (whether orally or in writing); and
of leading, or producing, evidence; and

P3para.Text: whether or not any such representations are made, hold a hearing.

P2para.Text: Those persons are

P3para.Text: the patient;
the patients named person;
the patients primary carer;
any guardian of the patient;
any welfare attorney of the patient;
any curator ad litem appointed by the Tribunal in respect of the patient;
the Scottish Ministers;
the patients responsible medical officer;
the mental health officer; and
any other person appearing to the Tribunal to have an interest.

Text.Addition: Where
a person (V) is entitled to make victim's representations before the Tribunal makes a decision under this section, and
V has not been afforded the opportunity of making representations under subsection (8),
before making a decision about what (if any) conditions to impose on the patient's conditional discharge under subsection (7), the Tribunal must have regard to any victim's representations made by

P2para.Text: Nothing in section 102 (state hospitals) of the National Health Service (Scotland) Act 1978 (c. 29) prevents or restricts the detention of a patient in a state hospital as a result of a decision of the Tribunal not to make any order under this section.

P1group.Title: Tribunals powers etc. when varying compulsion order

P1para.Text: Where the Tribunal makes an order under section 193(6) of this Act varying a compulsion order, the Tribunal shall specify in its order the modifications made by its order to the measures specified in the compulsion order.

P1group.Title: Deferral of conditional discharge

P1para.Text: Where the Tribunal makes an order under section 193(7) of this Act conditionally discharging a patient, it may defer that discharge until such arrangements as appear to the Tribunal to be necessary for that purpose have been made.

Title.Emphasis: Effect of modification or revocation of orders

P1group.Title: General effect of orders under section 193

P2para.Text: Where the Tribunal makes an order under section 193 of this Act

P3para.Text: revoking a compulsion order;
revoking a restriction order;
conditionally discharging a patient; or
varying a compulsion order by modifying the measures specified in it,

P2para.Text: the order shall not have effect until the occurrence of the first to occur of the events mentioned in subsection (2) below.
Those events are

P3para.Text: the expiry of the appeal period, no appeal having been lodged within that period; and
where an appeal has been lodged within the appeal period

P4para.Text: the receipt by both the Court of Session and the managers of the hospital specified in the compulsion order of notice from the Scottish Ministers that they do not intend to move the Court of Session to make an order under section 323 of this Act;
the refusal by the Court of Session to make such an order; and
the recall of any such order or the expiry of its effect.

P2para.Text: In subsection (2) above

Para.Text: appeal means an appeal under section 322 of this Act; and
appeal period means, in relation to an appeal, the period, prescribed by regulations made under section 324(7) of this Act, within which the appeal has to be lodged in order to be competent.

P1group.Title: Effect of revocation of compulsion order

P1para.Text: Where the Tribunal makes an order under section 193(3) or (4) of this Act revoking a compulsion order, the restriction order to which the patient is subject shall cease to have effect.

P1group.Title: Effect of revocation of restriction order

P2para.Text: This section applies where the Tribunal

P3para.Text: makes an order under subsection (5) of section 193 of this Act revoking the restriction order to which the patient is subject; but
does not make an order under subsection (3) or (4) of that section revoking the compulsion order to which the patient is subject.

P2para.Text: Part 9 of this Act shall apply to the patient as if the compulsion order to which the patient is subject were a relevant compulsion order made on the day on which the order revoking the restriction order has effect in accordance with section 196 of this Act.
In this section, relevant compulsion order has the meaning given by section 137(1) of this Act.

P1group.Title: Meaning of modify

P1para.Text: In this Chapter, any reference to modifying the measures specified in a compulsion order includes a reference to

P3para.Text: amending those measures;
removing from the order any measure; or
adding to the order any measure.

P1group.Title: Variation of conditions imposed on conditional discharge

P2para.Text: This section applies where

P3para.Text: a patient has been conditionally discharged by the Tribunal under section 193(7) of this Act; and
the Tribunal imposed conditions on that discharge under that section.

P2para.Text: The Scottish Ministers may, if satisfied that it is necessary, vary such of the conditions imposed by the Tribunal under section 193(7) of this Act as they think fit.

Text.Addition: Before varying any conditions under subsection (2), the Scottish Ministers must have regard to any victim's representations.

P2para.Text: Where the Scottish Ministers vary, under subsection (2) above, conditions imposed by the Tribunal under section 193(7) of this Act, the Scottish Ministers shall, as soon as practicable, give notice of that variation to

P3para.Text: the patient;
the patients named person;
the patients responsible medical officer; and
the mental health officer.

P1group.Title: Appeal to Tribunal against variation of conditions imposed on conditional discharge

P2para.Text: Where the Scottish Ministers vary, under section 200(2) of this Act, conditions imposed by the Tribunal under section 193(7) of this Act on a patient who has been conditionally discharged under that section, the persons mentioned in subsection (2) below may, before the expiry of the period of 28 days beginning with the day on which notice is given under section 200(3) of this Act, appeal against the variation of those conditions to the Tribunal.
Those persons are

P3para.Text: the patient; and
the patients named person.

P2para.Text: Where an appeal is made to the Tribunal under subsection (1) above, section 193 of this Act shall apply as if the patient had applied under section 192 of this Act for an order conditionally discharging the patient.

P1group.Title: Recall of patients from conditional discharge

P2para.Text: This section applies to a patient conditionally discharged by the Tribunal under section 193(7) of this Act.
If the Scottish Ministers are satisfied that it is necessary for the patient to be detained in hospital, they may, by warrant, recall the patient to hospital.

P1group.Title: Effect of recall from conditional discharge

P1para.Text: Where the Scottish Ministers recall a patient to hospital under section 202 of this Act, if the hospital specified in the warrant is not the hospital specified in the compulsion order to which the patient is subject, that order shall have effect as if the hospital specified in the warrant were the hospital specified in the order.

P1group.Title: Appeal to Tribunal against recall from conditional discharge

P2para.Text: Where a patient has been recalled to hospital under section 202 of this Act, each of the persons mentioned in subsection (2) below may, before the expiry of the period of 28 days beginning with the day on which the patient returns or is returned to hospital, appeal against that recall to the Tribunal.
Those persons are

P3para.Text: the patient; and
the patients named person.

P2para.Text: Where an appeal is made to the Tribunal under subsection (1) above, section 193 of this Act shall apply as if the patient had applied under section 192 of this Act for an order conditionally discharging the patient.

Part.Title: Hospital directions and transfer for treatment directions

P1group.Title: Mental health officers duty to identify named person

P2para.Text: This section applies where

P3para.Text: a hospital direction; or
a transfer for treatment direction,

P2para.Text: is made in respect of a patient.
The mental health officer shall, as soon as practicable after the direction is made, take such steps as are reasonably practicable to ascertain the name and address of the patients named person.

P1group.Title: Review of hospital direction and transfer for treatment direction

P2para.Text: This section applies where a patient is subject to

P3para.Text: a hospital direction; or
a transfer for treatment direction.

P2para.Text: The patients responsible medical officer shall, during the period of 2 months ending with the relevant day, carry out a review in respect of the direction by complying with the requirements set out in subsection (3) below.
Those requirements are

P3para.Text: to

P4para.Text: carry out a medical examination of the patient; or
make arrangements for an approved medical practitioner to carry out such a medical examination;

P3para.Text: to consider

P4para.Text: whether the conditions mentioned in subsection (4) below continue to apply in respect of the patient;

whether, as a result of the patients mental disorder, it is necessary, in order to protect any other person from serious harm, for the patient to be detained in hospital, whether or not for medical treatment; and
whether it continues to be necessary for the patient to be subject to the direction; and

P3para.Text: to consult

P4para.Text: the mental health officer; and
such other persons as the responsible medical officer considers appropriate.

P2para.Text: Those conditions are

P3para.Text: that the patient has a mental disorder;
that medical treatment which would be likely to

P4para.Text: prevent the mental disorder worsening; or
alleviate any of the symptoms, or effects, of the disorder,

P3para.Text: is available for the patient; and
that if the patient were not provided with such medical treatment there would be a significant risk

P4para.Text: to the health, safety or welfare of the patient; or
to the safety of any other person.

P2para.Text: In subsection (2) above, the relevant day means

P3para.Text: the day which falls 12 months after the day on which the direction is made; or
where that relevant day has passed, the day falling on the same day in every year thereafter.

P1group.Title: Responsible medical officers report following review of direction

P2para.Text: This section applies where a patients responsible medical officer carries out a review under section 206(2) of this Act.
The responsible medical officer shall, as soon as practicable after carrying out that review, submit a report in accordance with subsection (3) below to the Scottish Ministers.
That report shall record the responsible medical officers views as to

P3para.Text: whether the conditions mentioned in section 206(4) of this Act continue to apply in respect of the patient;

whether, as a result of the patients mental disorder, it is necessary, in order to protect any other person from serious harm, for the patient to be detained in hospital, whether or not for medical treatment; and
whether it continues to be necessary for the patient to be subject to the direction.

P2para.Text: If, after having regard to any views expressed by persons consulted under section 206(3)(c) of this Act, the responsible medical officer is not satisfied that the patient has a mental disorder, the responsible medical officer shall include in the report submitted to the Scottish Ministers under subsection (2) above a recommendation that the direction be revoked.
If, after having regard to any views expressed by persons consulted under section 206(3)(c) of this Act, the responsible medical officer

P3para.Text: is satisfied that the patient has a mental disorder; but
is not satisfied

P4para.Text: that, as a result of the patients mental disorder, it is necessary, in order to protect any other person from serious harm, for the patient to be detained in hospital, whether or not for medical treatment; and

Text.Substitution: either
that the conditions mentioned in paragraph (b) and (c) of section 206(4) of this Act continue to apply in respect of the patient; or
that it continues to be necessary for the patient to be subject to the direction,

P3para.Text: the responsible medical officer shall include in the report submitted to the Scottish Ministers under subsection (2) above a recommendation that the direction be revoked.

Title.Emphasis: Responsible medical officers duty to keep directions under review

P1group.Title: Responsible medical officers duty to keep directions under review

P2para.Text: This section applies where a patient is subject to

P3para.Text: a hospital direction; or
a transfer for treatment direction.

P2para.Text: Without prejudice to the duty imposed on the patients responsible medical officer by section 206(2) of this Act, the responsible medical officer shall from time to time consider

P3para.Text: whether the conditions mentioned in section 206(4) of this Act continue to apply in respect of the patient;

whether, as a result of the patients mental disorder, it is necessary, in order to protect any other person from serious harm, for the patient to be detained in hospital, whether or not for medical treatment; and
whether it continues to be necessary for the patient to be subject to the direction.

P2para.Text: If, having considered the matters mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (c) of subsection (2) above, the responsible medical officer is not satisfied that the patient has a mental disorder, the responsible medical officer shall, as soon as practicable after considering those matters, submit to the Scottish Ministers a report complying with the requirements set out in section 207(3) of this Act and including a recommendation that the direction be revoked.
If, having considered the matters mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (c) of subsection (2) above, the responsible medical officer

P3para.Text: is satisfied that the patient has a mental disorder; but
is not satisfied

P4para.Text: that, as a result of the patients mental disorder, it is necessary, in order to protect any other person from serious harm, for the patient to be detained in hospital, whether or not for medical treatment; and

Text.Substitution: either
that the conditions mentioned in paragraph (b) and (c) of section 206(4) of this Act continue to apply in respect of the patient; or
that it continues to be necessary for the patient to be subject to the direction,

P3para.Text: the responsible medical officer shall, as soon as practicable after considering those matters, submit to the Scottish Ministers a report complying with the requirements set out in section 207(3) of this Act and including a recommendation that the direction be revoked.

Title.Emphasis: Reference to Tribunal by Scottish Ministers

P1group.Title: Commissions power to require Scottish Ministers to make reference to Tribunal

P2para.Text: This section applies where a patient is subject to

P3para.Text: a hospital direction; or
a transfer for treatment direction.

P2para.Text: If it appears to the Commission that it is appropriate to do so, it may, by notice in writing to the Scottish Ministers, require them to make a reference to the Tribunal in respect of the direction to which the patient is subject.
Where, under subsection (2), the Commission gives notice to the Scottish Ministers, the Commission shall include in that notice its reasons for requiring the Scottish Ministers to make the reference.

P1group.Title: Duty of Scottish Ministers on receiving report from responsible medical officer

P2para.Text: This section applies where a patients responsible medical officer submits to the Scottish Ministers

P3para.Text: a report under section 207(2) of this Act that includes a recommendation; or
a report under section 208(3) or (4) of this Act.

P2para.Text: If, having considered the matters mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (c) of section 212(2) of this Act, the Scottish Ministers

P3para.Text: are not satisfied that the patient has a mental disorder; or
are so satisfied but are not satisfied

P4para.Text: that, as a result of the patients mental disorder, it is necessary, in order to protect any other person from serious harm, for the patient to be detained in hospital, whether or not for medical treatment; and

Text.Substitution: either
that the conditions mentioned in paragraph (b) and (c) of section 206(4) of this Act continue to apply in respect of the patient; or
that it continues to be necessary for the patient to be subject to the direction,

P2para.Text: the Scottish Ministers shall revoke the direction to which the patient is subject.
Where the Scottish Ministers do not, under subsection (2) above, revoke the direction to which the patient is subject, they shall make a reference to the Tribunal in respect of the direction.
Where a reference is made under subsection (3) above, the Scottish Ministers shall, as soon as practicable, give notice that a reference is to be made to

P3para.Text: the patient;
the patients named person;
any guardian of the patient;
any welfare attorney of the patient;
the patients responsible medical officer;
the mental health officer; and
the Commission.

P2para.Text: A reference under subsection (3) above shall state

P3para.Text: the name and address of the patient;
the name and address of the patients named person; and
the recommendation made by the responsible medical officer.

P2para.Text: Nothing in section 102 (state hospitals) of the National Health Service (Scotland) Act 1978 (c. 29) prevents or restricts the detention of a patient in a state hospital as a result of a decision under this section by the Scottish Ministers not to revoke the direction to which the patient is subject.

P1group.Title: Notice under section 209(2): reference to Tribunal

P2para.Text: This section applies where, under section 209(2) of this Act, the Commission gives notice to the Scottish Ministers.

The Scottish Ministers shall, as soon as practicable after receiving notice under section 209(2) of this Act, make a reference to the Tribunal in respect of the direction to which the patient is subject.

Where a reference is made under subsection (2) above, the Scottish Ministers shall, as soon as practicable, give notice that a reference is to be made to the persons mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (g) of section 210(4) of this Act.
A reference under subsection (2) above shall state

P3para.Text: the name and address of the patient;
the name and address of the patients named person; and
the reason given by the Commission in the notice under section 209(2) of this Act for requiring the Scottish Ministers to make the reference.

Title.Emphasis: Scottish Ministers' duty to keep directions under review

P1group.Title: Duty of Scottish Ministers to keep directions under review

P2para.Text: This section applies where a patient is subject to

P3para.Text: a hospital direction; or
a transfer for treatment direction.

P2para.Text: Without prejudice to the duties imposed on the Scottish Ministers by sections 210(2) and (3), 211(2) and 213(2) of this Act, the Scottish Ministers shall from time to time consider

P3para.Text: whether the conditions mentioned in section 206(4) of this Act continue to apply in respect of the patient;

whether, as a result of the patients mental disorder, it is necessary, in order to protect any other person from serious harm, for the patient to be detained in hospital, whether or not for medical treatment; and
whether it continues to be necessary for the patient to be subject to the direction.

P2para.Text: If, having considered the matters mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (c) of subsection (2) above, the Scottish Ministers are not satisfied that the patient has a mental disorder, they shall revoke the direction.
If, having considered the matters mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (c) of subsection (2) above, the Scottish Ministers

P3para.Text: are satisfied that the patient has a mental disorder; but
are not satisfied

P4para.Text: that, as a result of the patients mental disorder, it is necessary, in order to protect any other person from serious harm, for the patient to be detained in hospital, whether or not for medical treatment; and

Text.Substitution: either
that the conditions mentioned in paragraph (b) and (c) of section 206(4) of this Act continue to apply in respect of the patient; or
that it continues to be necessary for the patient to be subject to the direction,

P3para.Text: they shall revoke the direction.

P2para.Text: Nothing in section 102 (state hospitals) of the National Health Service (Scotland) Act 1978 (c. 29) prevents or restricts the detention of a patient in a state hospital as a result of a decision under this section by the Scottish Ministers not to revoke the direction to which the patient is subject.

P1group.Title: Reference to Tribunal by Scottish Ministers

P2para.Text: This section applies where a patient is subject to

P3para.Text: a hospital direction; or
a transfer for treatment direction.

P2para.Text: If

P3para.Text: during the period of 2 years ending with the relevant day

P4para.Text: no reference under section 210(3) or 211(2) of this Act has been determined by the Tribunal; and
no application under section 214(2) of this Act has been determined by the Tribunal; and

P3para.Text: during each period of 2 years ending with the anniversary, in every year thereafter, of the relevant day

P4para.Text: no reference such as is mentioned in paragraph (a)(i) above or, subject to subsection (3) below, under this subsection has been determined by the Tribunal; and
no application such as is mentioned in paragraph (a)(ii) above has been determined by the Tribunal,

P3para.Text: the Scottish Ministers shall make a reference to the Tribunal in respect of the direction to which the patient is subject.

P2para.Text: The Scottish Ministers shall, in considering, under subsection (2)(b)(i) above, whether a reference has been determined by the Tribunal during any 2 year period, leave out of account any reference made under subsection (2) above that has been determined by it during the first year of that 2 year period.

Where a reference is made under subsection (2) above, the Scottish Ministers shall, as soon as practicable, give notice that a reference is to be made to the persons mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (g) of section 210(4) of this Act.
A reference under subsection (2) above shall state

P3para.Text: the name and address of the patient;
the name and address of the patients named person; and
the reason for making the reference.

P2para.Text: In subsection (2) above, the relevant day means the day which falls 2 years after the day on which the direction is made.

P1group.Title: Application to Tribunal by patient and named person

P2para.Text: This section applies where a patient is subject to

P3para.Text: a hospital direction; or
a transfer for treatment direction.

P2para.Text: Each of the persons mentioned in subsection (3) below may, subject to subsections (4) to (6) below, make an application under this section to the Tribunal for the revocation of the direction to which the patient is subject.
Those persons are

P3para.Text: the patient; and
the patients named person.

P2para.Text: Where a patient is subject to a hospital direction, an application under this section may not be made before the expiry of the period of 6 months beginning with the day on which the direction was made.
Where a patient is subject to a transfer for treatment direction, an application under this section

P3para.Text: may be made during the period of 12 weeks beginning with the day on which the direction is made; but
otherwise may not be made before the expiry of the period of 6 months beginning with the day on which the direction was made.

P2para.Text: Neither of the persons mentioned in subsection (3) above may make more than one application under this section during

P3para.Text: the period of 12 months beginning with the day on which the direction was made; or
any subsequent period of 12 months that begins with or with an anniversary of the expiry of the period of 12 months mentioned in paragraph (a) above.

P2para.Text: Where a patients named person makes an application under subsection (2) above, the named person shall give notice to the patient of the making of the application.

P1group.Title: Powers of Tribunal on reference under section 210(3), 211(2) or 213(2) or on application under section 214(2)

P2para.Text: This section applies where

P3para.Text: a reference is made under section 210(3), 211(2) or 213(2) of this Act; or
an application is made under section 214(2) of this Act.

P2para.Text: If the Tribunal is satisfied

P3para.Text: that the patient has a mental disorder; and

that, as a result of the patients mental disorder, it is necessary, in order to protect any other person from serious harm, for the patient to be detained in hospital, whether or not for medical treatment,

P2para.Text: it shall make no direction to the Scottish Ministers under this section.
If the Tribunal is not satisfied that the patient has a mental disorder, it shall direct the Scottish Ministers to revoke the direction to which the patient is subject.
If the Tribunal

P3para.Text: is satisfied that the patient has a mental disorder; but
is not satisfied

P4para.Text: that, as a result of the patients mental disorder, it is necessary, in order to protect any other person from serious harm, for the patient to be detained in hospital, whether or not for medical treatment; and

Text.Substitution: either
that the conditions mentioned in paragraph (b) and (c) of section 206(4) of this Act continue to apply in respect of the patient; or
that it continues to be necessary for the patient to be subject to the direction,

P3para.Text: the Tribunal shall direct the Scottish Ministers to revoke the direction to which the patient is subject.

P2para.Text: The Scottish Ministers shall, if directed to do so by the Tribunal under subsection (3) or (4) above, revoke the direction to which the patient is subject.
Before making a decision under this section, the Tribunal shall

P3para.Text: afford the persons mentioned in subsection (7) below the opportunity

P4para.Text: of making representations (whether orally or in writing); and
of leading, or producing, evidence; and

P3para.Text: whether or not any such representations are made, hold a hearing.

P2para.Text: Those persons are

P3para.Text: the patient;
the patients named person;
the patients primary carer;
any guardian of the patient;
any welfare attorney of the patient;
any curator ad litem appointed in respect of the patient by the Tribunal;
the Scottish Ministers;
the patients responsible medical officer;
the mental health officer; and
any other person appearing to the Tribunal to have an interest.

P2para.Text: Nothing in section 102 (state hospitals) of the National Health Service (Scotland) Act 1978 (c. 29) prevents or restricts the detention of a patient in a state hospital as a result of a decision under this section by the Tribunal not to direct the Scottish Ministers to revoke the direction to which the patient is subject.

P1group.Title: Effect of revocation of direction

P2para.Text: This section applies where, under section 210(2), 212(3) or (4) or 215(5) of this Act, the Scottish Ministers revoke

P3para.Text: a hospital direction; or
a transfer for treatment direction.

P2para.Text: Where the Scottish Ministers revoke a direction they shall direct that the patient be admitted to a prison, institution or other place in which the patient might have been detained had the patient not been detained in hospital by virtue of the direction.
The direction shall cease to have effect on the patients admission to the prison, institution or place to which the patient is admitted by virtue of the direction under subsection (2) above.

Title.Emphasis: Termination of direction on release of patient

P1group.Title: Termination of hospital direction on release of patient

P2para.Text: This section applies where a patient is subject to

P3para.Text: a hospital direction; or
a transfer for treatment direction.

P2para.Text: Where a patient is released under Part 1 of the Prisoners and Criminal Proceedings (Scotland) Act 1993 (c. 9) or otherwise the direction to which the patient is subject shall cease to have effect.

P1group.Title: Transfer of patients between hospitals

P2para.Text: This section applies where a patient is subject to

P3para.Text: a compulsion order and a restriction order;
a hospital direction; or
a transfer for treatment direction.

P2para.Text: The managers of the hospital in which the patient is detained may, where the conditions mentioned in subsection (3) below are satisfied, transfer the patient to another hospital.
Those conditions are

P3para.Text: that the managers of the hospital to which it is proposed to transfer the patient; and
the Scottish Ministers,

P2para.Text: consent to the transfer.

Where the managers of a hospital propose to transfer a patient under subsection (2) above, they shall, subject to subsections (5) and (7) below, give the persons mentioned in subsection (8) below at least 7 days' notice of the transfer.
The managers of a hospital need not give notice under subsection (4) above where it is necessary that the patient be transferred urgently.

Where, by virtue of subsection (5) above, no notice is given under subsection (4) above, the managers of the hospital shall, subject to subsection (7) below, give the persons mentioned in subsection (8) below notice

P3para.Text: where the proposed transfer has not taken place, of the proposed transfer; or
where the transfer has taken place, of the transfer,

P2para.Text: as soon as practicable before, on or, as the case may be, after the transfer.
The managers of the hospital need not give notice under subsection (4) or (6) above to the patient where the patient consents to the transfer.
The persons referred to in subsections (4) and (6) above and (10)(b) below are

P3para.Text: the patient; and
the patients named person.

P2para.Text: Where

P3para.Text: notice is given under subsection (4) or (6)(a) above of a proposed transfer under subsection (2) above; and
the proposed transfer does not take place before the end of the period of 3 months beginning with the day on which notice is given,

P2para.Text: the managers of the hospital may transfer the patient as proposed only if subsection (10) below applies.
This subsection applies where

P3para.Text: the conditions mentioned in subsection (3) above continue to be satisfied; and
the persons mentioned in subsection (8) above are given at least 7 days' notice of the proposed transfer.

P2para.Text: Subsections (5) to (7) above shall apply to the giving of notice under subsection (10)(b) above as they apply to the giving of notice under subsection (4) above.

Where the patient is transferred under subsection (2) above, the managers of the hospital from which the patient is transferred shall, before the expiry of the period of 7 days beginning with the transfer, give notice to the Commission of the matters mentioned in subsection (13) below.
Those matters are

P3para.Text: the date on which the patient was transferred;
the hospital to which the patient was transferred;
that

P4para.Text: notice was given under subsection (4) above; or
if no such notice was given, the reasons why it was necessary that the patient be transferred urgently; and

P3para.Text: whether notice was given under subsection (6) or (10)(b) above.

P2para.Text: Where a patient is transferred under subsection (2) above, the compulsion order, hospital direction or, as the case may be, transfer for treatment direction to which the patient is subject shall, for the purposes of this Act (other than sections 219 and 220), be taken to specify the hospital to which the patient is transferred.

Title.Addition: Transfer of patient from specified hospital unit

Text.Addition: Subsection (2) below applies where
a patient is subject to
a compulsion order and a restriction order,
a hospital direction, or
a transfer for treatment direction, and
that order or (as the case may be) direction specifies the hospital unit in which the patient is to be detained.
If the condition in subsection (3) below is satisfied, the managers of the hospital in which the patient is detained may transfer the patient to another hospital unit within the same hospital.
The condition is that the Scottish Ministers consent to the transfer.
In relation to a transfer or proposed transfer under subsection (2) above, section 218(4) to (14) of this Act applies subject to the following modifications
a reference to section 218(2) is to be read as a reference to subsection (2) above,
in subsection (10)(a), a reference to section 218(3) is to be read as a reference to subsection (3) above,
in subsection (12), a reference to the hospital from which the patient is transferred is to be read as a reference to the hospital in which the patient is detained,
in subsections (13)(b) and (14), a reference to the hospital to which the patient is transferred is to be read as a reference to the hospital unit to which the patient is transferred.
For the purposes of this section,
means any part of a hospital which is treated as a separate unit.

P1group.Title: Appeal to Tribunal against transfer under section 218 to hospital other than state hospital

P2para.Text: This section applies where

P3para.Text: a patient

P4para.Text: receives notice under subsection (4), (6)(a) or (10)(b) of section 218 of this Act that it is proposed to transfer the patient; or
is transferred under subsection (2) of that section,

P3para.Text: to any hospital other than a state hospital; and

the hospital to which the patient is, or is proposed to be, transferred is not specified in the compulsion order, hospital direction or, as the case may be, transfer for treatment direction to which the patient is subject.

P2para.Text: The patient, or the patients named person, may, during the period mentioned in subsection (3) below, appeal to the Tribunal against the proposed transfer or, as the case may be, the transfer.
That period is

P3para.Text: in the case of the patient

P4para.Text: where notice is given to the patient before the proposed transfer, the period beginning with the day on which notice is given and ending 28 days after the transfer;
where notice is given to the patient on or after the transfer, the period beginning with the day on which the patient is transferred and ending 28 days after the day on which notice is given; or
where notice is not given to the patient, the period of 28 days beginning with the day on which the patient is transferred;

P3para.Text: in the case of the patients named person

P4para.Text: where notice is given to the patients named person before the proposed transfer, the period beginning with the day on which notice is given and ending 28 days after the transfer; or
where notice is given to the patients named person on or after the transfer, the period of 28 days beginning with the day on which notice is given.

P2para.Text: If, when an appeal under subsection (2) above against a proposed transfer is made to the Tribunal, the proposed transfer has not taken place

P3para.Text: the managers of the hospital shall not transfer the patient as proposed; but
the Tribunal may, if satisfied that, pending the determination of the appeal, the patient should be transferred as proposed, make an order that the patient be so transferred.

P2para.Text: On an appeal under subsection (2) above, the Tribunal may make an order that the proposed transfer not take place or, as the case may be, that the patient be returned to the hospital from which the patient was transferred.

P1group.Title: Appeal to Tribunal against transfer under section 218 to state hospital

P2para.Text: This section applies where

P3para.Text: a patient

P4para.Text: receives notice under subsection (4), (6)(a) or (10)(b) of section 218 of this Act that it is proposed to transfer the patient; or
is transferred under subsection (2) of that section,

P3para.Text: to a state hospital; and

the state hospital to which the patient is, or is proposed to be, transferred is not specified in the compulsion order, hospital direction or, as the case may be, transfer for treatment direction to which the patient is subject.

P2para.Text: The patient, or the patients named person, may, during the period mentioned in subsection (3) below, appeal to the Tribunal against the proposed transfer or, as the case may be, the transfer.
That period is

P3para.Text: in the case of the patient

P4para.Text: where notice is given to the patient before the proposed transfer, the period beginning with the day on which notice is given and ending 12 weeks after the transfer;
where notice is given to the patient on or after the transfer, the period beginning with the day on which the patient is transferred and ending 12 weeks after the day on which notice is given; or
where notice is not given to the patient, the period of 12 weeks beginning with the day on which the patient is transferred;

P3para.Text: in the case of the patients named person

P4para.Text: where notice is given to the patients named person before the proposed transfer, the period beginning with the day on which notice is given and ending 12 weeks after the transfer; or
where notice is given to the patients named person on or after the transfer, the period of 12 weeks beginning with the day on which notice is given.

P2para.Text: If, when an appeal under subsection (2) above against a proposed transfer is made to the Tribunal, the proposed transfer has not taken place

P3para.Text: the managers of the hospital shall not transfer the patient as proposed; but
the Tribunal may, if satisfied that, pending determination of the appeal, the patient should be transferred as proposed, make an order that the patient be so transferred.

P2para.Text: On an appeal under subsection (2) above, the Tribunal may, if not satisfied as to the matter mentioned in subsection (6) below, make an order that the proposed transfer not take place or, as the case may be, that the patient be returned to the hospital from which the patient was transferred.
That matter is

P3para.Text: that the patient requires to be detained in hospital under conditions of special security; and
that those conditions of special security can be provided only in a state hospital.

P1group.Title: Assessment order: suspension of measure authorising detention

P2para.Text: This section applies where a patient is subject to an assessment order.

Subject to subsection (3) below, where the patients responsible medical officer grants a certificate specifying a period during which the assessment order to which the patient is subject shall not authorise the detention of the patient in hospital, the order does not authorise that detention during that period.

Text.Addition: A certificate under subsection (2) above may specify
a single period, or
a series of more than one individual period.

P2para.Text: The patients responsible medical officer may grant a certificate under subsection (2) above only with the consent of the Scottish Ministers.

Text.Addition: Subsection (3) above does not require the consent of the Scottish Ministers if the granting of the certificate is for the purpose of enabling the patient to
attend a hearing in criminal proceedings against the patient, or
meet a medical or dental appointment made for the patient.
The purpose for which a certificate under subsection (2) above is granted must be recorded in the certificate.

P2para.Text: If the responsible medical officer considers that it is necessary

P3para.Text: in the interests of the patient; or
for the protection of any other person,

P2para.Text: a certificate under subsection (2) above may include conditions such as are mentioned in subsection (6) below; and any such conditions shall have effect.
Those conditions are

P3para.Text: that, during the period specified in the certificate, the patient be kept in the charge of a person authorised in writing for the purpose by the patients responsible medical officer; and
such other conditions as may be specified by the patients responsible medical officer.

P1group.Title: Certificate under section 221: revocation by responsible medical officer

P2para.Text: Subsection (2) below applies where a certificate is granted under section 221(2) of this Act.
If the patients responsible medical officer is satisfied that it is necessary

P3para.Text: in the interests of the patient; or
for the protection of any other person,

P2para.Text: that the certificate be revoked, the responsible medical officer may revoke the certificate.
Where, under subsection (2) above, the responsible medical officer revokes a certificate, the responsible medical officer shall, as soon as practicable after the revocation, give notice of it to

P3para.Text: the patient;
where a person is authorised for the purposes of section 221(6)(a) of this Act, that person; and
the Scottish Ministers.

P1group.Title: Certificate under section 221: revocation by Scottish Ministers

P2para.Text: Subsection (2) below applies where a certificate is granted under section 221(2) of this Act.
If the Scottish Ministers are satisfied that it is necessary

P3para.Text: in the interests of the patient; or
for the protection of any other person,

P2para.Text: that the certificate be revoked, the Scottish Ministers may revoke the certificate.
Where, under subsection (2) above, the Scottish Ministers revoke a certificate, they shall, as soon as practicable after the revocation, give notice of it to

P3para.Text: the patient;
the patients responsible medical officer; and
where a person is authorised for the purposes of section 221(6)(a) of this Act, that person.

P1group.Title: Patients subject to certain other orders and directions: suspension of measure authorising detention

P2para.Text: This section applies where a patient is subject to

P3para.Text: a treatment order;
an interim compulsion order;

Text.Addition: a temporary compulsion order;

P3para.Text: a compulsion order and a restriction order;
a hospital direction; or
a transfer for treatment direction.

P2para.Text: Subject to subsections (3) and (4) below, where the patients responsible medical officer grants a certificate specifying a period ... during which the order or direction to which the patient is subject shall not authorise the detention of the patient in hospital, the order or direction does not authorise that detention during that period.

Text.Addition: A certificate under subsection (2) above may specify
a single period not exceeding 90 days, or
a series of more than one individual period falling within a particular 3 month period.

P2para.Text: The patients responsible medical officer may grant a certificate under subsection (2) above only with the consent of the Scottish Ministers.

Text.Addition: In the case of a treatment order, an interim compulsion order or a temporary compulsion order, subsection (3) above does not require the consent of the Scottish Ministers if the granting of the certificate is for the purpose of enabling the patient to
attend a hearing in criminal proceedings against the patient, or
meet a medical or dental appointment made for the patient.

Text.Substitution: The total period that an order or direction does not, by reason of certification under subsection (2) above, authorise the detention of a patient in hospital must not exceed 200 days within any period of 12 months (whenever counted from).

Text.Addition: For the purpose of subsection (4) above
a day does not count towards the total period if the detention is (by reason of such certification) not authorised for a period of 8 hours or less in that day,

a single period (specified in such certification) of more than 8 hours and less than 24 hours, whether in one day or spanning two days, is to count as a whole day towards the total period.. Specification of hospital units
The purpose for which a certificate under subsection (2) above is granted must be recorded in the certificate.

P2para.Text: If the responsible medical officer considers that it is necessary

P3para.Text: in the interests of the patient; or
for the protection of any other person,

P2para.Text: a certificate under subsection (2) above may include conditions such as are mentioned in subsection (7) below; and any such conditions shall have effect.

Text.Addition: Before deciding what conditions such as are mentioned in subsection (7) below to include in a certificate under subsection (2) above (if any), the responsible medical officer must have regard to any victim's representations.

P2para.Text: Those conditions are

P3para.Text: that, during the period specified in the certificate, the patient be kept in the charge of a person authorised in writing for the purpose by the patients responsible medical officer; and
such other conditions as may be specified by the patients responsible medical officer.

P2para.Text: Where a patients responsible medical officer proposes to grant a certificate under subsection (2) above specifying

P3para.Text: a period of more than 28 days; or
a period which, when taken together with the period specified in any other certificate granted under that subsection, would exceed 28 days,

P2para.Text: the responsible medical officer shall, before granting such a certificate, give notice of the proposal to the persons mentioned in subsection (9) below.
Those persons are

P3para.Text: the patient;
the patients named person;
the patients general medical practitioner; and
the mental health officer.

P2para.Text: Where a certificate is granted under subsection (2) above specifying a period of more than 28 days, the patients responsible medical officer shall, before the expiry of the period of 14 days beginning with the day on which the certificate is granted, give notice of the granting of the certificate to the Commission.

P1group.Title: Certificate under section 224: revocation by responsible medical officer

P2para.Text: Subsection (2) below applies where a certificate is granted under 224(2) of this Act.
If the patients responsible medical officer is satisfied that it is necessary

P3para.Text: in the interests of the patient; or
for the protection of any other person,

P2para.Text: that the certificate be revoked, the responsible medical officer may revoke the certificate.
Where, under subsection (2) above, the responsible medical officer revokes a certificate, the responsible medical officer shall, as soon as practicable after the revocation, give notice of it to

P3para.Text: the patient;
the patients named person;
in a case where the certificate specified a period of more than 28 days, the patients general medical practitioner;
where a person is authorised for the purposes of section 224(7)(a) of this Act, that person;
the mental health officer; and
the Scottish Ministers.

P2para.Text: Where, under subsection (2) above, the responsible medical officer revokes a certificate granted under section 224(2) of this Act that specified a period of more than 28 days, the responsible medical officer shall, before the expiry of the period of 14 days beginning with the day on which the certificate is revoked, give notice of the revocation to the Commission.

P1group.Title: Certificate under section 224: revocation by Scottish Ministers

P2para.Text: Subsection (2) below applies where a certificate is granted under section 224(2) of this Act.
If the Scottish Ministers are satisfied that it is necessary

P3para.Text: in the interests of the patient; or
for the protection of any other person,

P2para.Text: that the certificate be revoked, the Scottish Ministers may revoke the certificate.
Where, under subsection (2) above, the Scottish Ministers revoke a certificate, they shall, as soon as practicable after the revocation, give notice of it to

P3para.Text: the patient;
the patients named person;
in a case where the certificate specified a period of more than 28 days, the patients general medical practitioner;
the patients responsible medical officer;
the mental health officer; and
where a person is authorised for the purposes of section 224(7)(a) of this Act, that person.

P2para.Text: Where, under subsection (2) above, the Scottish Ministers revoke a certificate granted under section 224(2) of this Act that specified a period of more than 28 days, they shall, before the expiry of the period of 14 days beginning with the day on which the certificate is revoked, give notice of the revocation to the Commission.

P1group.Title: Assessment of needs for community care services etc.

P2para.Text: Where

P3para.Text: a patient is a person for whom a local authority are under a duty or have a power to provide, or secure the provision of, community care services;

it appears to the mental health officer that, for the purposes of this Act or the 1995 Act, the patient should be assessed under subsection (1)(a) of section 12A of the Social Work (Scotland) Act 1968 (c. 49); and
the mental health officer notifies the local authority that the patient may be in need of community care services,

P2para.Text: the patient shall for the purposes of that section be deemed to appear to the local authority to be a person who may be in need of any such services.
In section 23(3) of the Children (Scotland) Act 1995 (c. 36) (local authoritys duty to carry out, in response to request by parent or guardian, assessment of needs of child)

P3para.Text: after by, where it first occurs, there shall be inserted
after guardian, there shall be inserted
a mental health officer (as defined in section 329 of the Mental Health (Care and Treatment) (Scotland) Act 2003 (asp 13)) who

P4para.Text: has responsibility under that Act or the Criminal Procedure (Scotland) Act 1995 (c. 46) for a childs case; and
makes the request for the purposes of either of those Acts,

P1group.Title: Request for assessment of needs: duty on local authorities and Health Boards

P2para.Text: Where

P3para.Text: a

P4para.Text: local authority receive a request in writing for the needs of a person to be assessed under section 12A(1)(a) of the Social Work (Scotland) Act 1968 (c. 49); or
Health Board receives a request in writing for the needs of a person for services which are provided by Health Boards in respect of mentally disordered persons to be assessed; and

P3para.Text: any of the circumstances mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (c) of subsection (2) below apply,

P2para.Text: the authority or, as the case may be, the Board shall comply with the requirement in subsection (3) below.
The circumstances referred to in subsection (1)(b) above are

P3para.Text: that the request bears

P4para.Text: to be made by a mentally disordered person; and
to be a request for the needs of that person to be assessed;

P3para.Text: that the request bears

P4para.Text: to be made by the primary carer, or named person, of a mentally disordered person; and
to be a request for the needs of the mentally disordered person to be assessed; and

P3para.Text: though the request does not bear to be made as mentioned in paragraph (a) or (b) above, it appears to the local authority or, as the case may be, the Health Board that the request

P4para.Text: is a request for the needs of a mentally disordered person to be assessed; and
is made by that person, or by that persons primary carer or named person.

P2para.Text: The requirement referred to in subsection (1) above is to give notice, before the expiry of the period of 14 days beginning with the day on which the request is received, to the person who made the request

P3para.Text: of whether

P4para.Text: the local authority intend; or
the Health Board intends,

P3para.Text: to undertake the assessment; and
if the intention is not to undertake the assessment, of the reason why that is the case.

Part.Title: Preliminary duties on making of orders etc.

P1group.Title: Designation of mental health officer responsible for patients case

P2para.Text: The relevant local authority

P3para.Text: shall, as soon as is reasonably practicable after a relevant event occurs in respect of a patient, ensure that a mental health officer is designated as the mental health officer having responsibility for the patients case; and
shall ensure that, so long as the patient is subject to a certificate, order or direction mentioned in section 232 of this Act, a mental health officer is designated as such mental health officer.

P2para.Text: The relevant local authority having responsibility under subsection (1) above may at any time designate

P3para.Text: for all purposes; or
for a particular purpose or for particular circumstances,

P2para.Text: a mental health officer in place of the mental health officer designated under that subsection.
In this section, relevant local authority means

P3para.Text: as respects the making of an order mentioned in section 232 of this Act which does not authorise the detention of the patient in hospital, the local authority for the area in which the patient resides;

as respects the granting of a certificate or the making of a direction mentioned in that section, or the making of an order mentioned in that section which authorises the detention of the patient in hospital

P4para.Text: the local authority for the area in which the patient was resident immediately before the relevant event occurred; or
where the patient was not resident in Scotland immediately before the relevant event occurred, the local authority for the area in which the hospital is situated.

P1group.Title: Appointment of patients responsible medical officer

P2para.Text: As soon as is reasonably practicable after the occurrence of an appropriate act in relation to a patient, the relevant managers shall appoint an approved medical practitioner to be the patients responsible medical officer.
Where, immediately before the occurrence of an appropriate act, a patient has a responsible medical officer, the person appointed under subsection (1) above may be that person.
The relevant managers having responsibility under subsection (1) above may at any time

P3para.Text: appoint an approved medical practitioner to be the patients responsible medical officer in place of the existing responsible medical officer;
authorise an approved medical practitioner to act (whether for a particular purpose or in particular circumstances) in place of the patients responsible medical officer.

P2para.Text: In this section

Para.Text: appropriate act means
a relevant event;
the granting of an emergency detention certificate;
the making of a temporary compulsion order ...;
the variation of
a compulsory treatment order; or
a compulsion order;
transfer to another hospital under section 124(2), 125(4)(b), 126(4), 218(2), 219(4)(b) or 220(4)(b) of this Act;
return to a hospital under section 125(5), 126(5), 219(5) or 220(5) of this Act; and
relevant managers means

in a case where the appropriate act falls within any of paragraphs (a) to (c) of the definition of that expression above, the managers of the hospital in which the patient is detained or, as the case may be, which is specified in the order;

in a case where the appropriate act falls within paragraph (d) of that definition, the managers of the hospital specified in the order following modification under section 102, 103, 104, 106, 166, 167, 169, 171 or, as the case may be, 193(6) of this Act;

in a case where the appropriate act falls within paragraph (e) of that definition, the managers of the hospital to which the patient is transferred under any of the provisions mentioned in that paragraph; and

in a case where the appropriate act falls within paragraph (f) of that definition, the managers of the hospital to which the patient is returned under any of the provisions mentioned in that paragraph.

P1group.Title: Social circumstances report: mental health officers duties

P2para.Text: Subject to subsection (2) below, where a relevant event occurs in respect of a patient, the mental health officer shall, before the expiry of the period of 21 days beginning with the day on which the event occurs

P3para.Text: prepare in respect of the patient a social circumstances report; and
send a copy of the report to

P4para.Text: the patients responsible medical officer; and
the Commission.

P2para.Text: If in any case the mental health officer considers that a social circumstances report would serve little, or no, practical purpose, the mental health officer

P3para.Text: need not comply with subsection (1) above; but
shall, before the expiry of the period mentioned in that subsection

P4para.Text: record the reasons for deciding that any such report would serve little, or no, practical purpose; and
send a statement of those reasons to the patients responsible medical officer and to the Commission.

P2para.Text: In this section, social circumstances report means a report setting out such information as may be prescribed by regulations.

P1group.Title: Meaning of relevant event

P1para.Text: In this Part of this Act, relevant event means

P3para.Text: the granting of a short-term detention certificate;
the making of

P4para.Text: an interim compulsory treatment order;
a compulsory treatment order;
an assessment order;
a treatment order;
an interim compulsion order;
a compulsion order;
a hospital direction; or
a transfer for treatment direction.

P1group.Title: Designated medical practitioners

P2para.Text: The Commission shall compile and maintain a list of medical practitioners who appear to the Commission to have such

P3para.Text: qualifications; and
experience,

P2para.Text: as the Commission considers appropriate for the purposes of discharging the functions conferred on designated medical practitioners by virtue of this Part of this Act.
A medical practitioner included for the time being in the list mentioned in subsection (1) above is referred to in this Act as a designated medical practitioner.
The Commission shall ensure that the list mentioned in subsection (1) above includes child specialists.
A designated medical practitioner may, for the purposes of discharging any functions conferred by virtue of this Part of this Act

P3para.Text: interview a patient at any reasonable time and require any such interview to be conducted in private;
carry out a medical examination of a patient in private at any reasonable time; and
require any person holding medical records of a patient to produce such records for inspection by the designated medical practitioner.

P2para.Text: A designated medical practitioner shall undertake such training as the Commission may require.

The Commission shall pay to designated medical practitioners for or in connection with the discharge of the functions conferred on them by virtue of this Part of this Act such fees, expenses and allowances as may be prescribed by regulations.

Title.Emphasis: Safeguards for certain surgical operations etc.

P1group.Title: Certain surgical operations etc.

P2para.Text: The types of medical treatment mentioned in subsection (2) below may be given to a patient only in accordance with section 235 or 236 of this Act.
The types of medical treatment referred to in subsection (1) above are

P3para.Text: any surgical operation for destroying

P4para.Text: brain tissue; or
the functioning of brain tissue; and

P3para.Text: such other types of medical treatment as may be specified in regulations for the purposes of this section.

P2para.Text: Before making regulations under subsection (2)(b) above the Scottish Ministers shall consult such persons as they consider appropriate.

P1group.Title: Treatment mentioned in section 234(2): patients capable of consenting

P2para.Text: Medical treatment mentioned in section 234(2) of this Act is given to a patient in accordance with this section if the requirements set out in subsections (2) and (3) below are satisfied.
Subject to subsection (6) below, the first requirement is that a designated medical practitioner who is not the patients responsible medical officer certifies in writing that

P3para.Text: the patient is capable of consenting to the treatment;
the patient consents in writing to the treatment; and
having regard to the likelihood of its alleviating, or preventing a deterioration in, the patients condition, it is in the patients best interests that the treatment should be given to the patient.

P2para.Text: The second requirement is that two other persons (not being medical practitioners) appointed by the Commission for the purposes of this subsection certify in writing that

P3para.Text: the patient is capable of consenting to the treatment; and
