the patient consents in writing to the treatment.

P2para.Text: A person appointed for the purposes of subsection (3) above may

P3para.Text: interview the patient at any reasonable time; and
require any such interview to be conducted in private.

P2para.Text: If the patient withdraws consent to the treatment (in writing or otherwise) at any time before its completion, this section shall then apply as if the remainder of the treatment were a separate treatment.
Where

P3para.Text: the patient is a child; and
the patients responsible medical officer is not a child specialist,

P2para.Text: the first requirement is that the matters mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (c) of subsection (2) above are certified in writing by a designated medical practitioner who is a child specialist.

References in subsections (2) and (6)(b) above to a patients responsible medical officer include, in any case where a patient does not have a responsible medical officer, references to the medical practitioner primarily responsible for treating the patient.

P1group.Title: Treatment mentioned in section 234(2): patients incapable of consenting

P2para.Text: Medical treatment mentioned in section 234(2) of this Act is given to a patient in accordance with this section if

P3para.Text: the requirements set out in subsections (2) to (4) below are satisfied; and
the patient does not resist or object to the treatment.

P2para.Text: Subject to subsection (6) below, the first requirement is that a designated medical practitioner who is not the patients responsible medical officer certifies in writing that

P3para.Text: the patient is incapable of consenting to the treatment;
the patient does not object to the treatment; and
having regard to the likelihood of its alleviating, or preventing a deterioration in, the patients condition, it is in the patients best interests that the treatment should be given to the patient.

P2para.Text: The second requirement is that two persons (not being medical practitioners) appointed by the Commission for the purposes of this subsection certify in writing that

P3para.Text: the patient is incapable of consenting to the treatment; and
the patient does not object to the treatment.

P2para.Text: The third requirement is that on the application of the patients responsible medical officer, the Court of Session has made an order declaring that the treatment may lawfully be given.
The Court of Session may make an order such as is mentioned in subsection (4) above only if it is satisfied that

P3para.Text: having regard to the likelihood of its alleviating, or preventing a deterioration in, the patients condition, it is in the patients best interests that the treatment should be given to the patient; and
the patient does not object to the treatment.

P2para.Text: Where the patient is a child, the first requirement is that the matters mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (c) of subsection (2) above are certified

P3para.Text: where the patients responsible medical officer is a child specialist, by a medical practitioner approved for the purposes of this subsection by the Commission;
where the patients responsible medical officer is not a child specialist, by a child specialist who is on the list maintained under section 233(1) of this Act.

P2para.Text: References in subsections (2), (4) and (6) above to a patients responsible medical officer include, in any case where a patient does not have a responsible medical officer, references to the medical practitioner primarily responsible for treating the patient.

P1group.Title: Electro-convulsive therapy etc.

P2para.Text: This section applies where the giving of medical treatment to a patient is authorised by virtue of this Act or the 1995 Act.
Subject to section 243 of this Act, the types of medical treatment mentioned in subsection (3) below may be given to the patient only in accordance with section 238 or 239 of this Act.
The types of medical treatment referred to in subsection (2) above are

P3para.Text: electro-convulsive therapy; and
such other types of medical treatment as may be specified in regulations for the purposes of this section.

P2para.Text: Before making regulations under subsection (3)(b) above the Scottish Ministers shall consult such persons as they consider appropriate.

P1group.Title: Treatment mentioned in sections 237(3) and 240(3): patients capable of consenting and not refusing consent

P2para.Text: Subject to subsection (3) below, medical treatment mentioned in section 237(3) or 240(3) of this Act is given to a patient in accordance with this section if the patients responsible medical officer or a designated medical practitioner certifies in writing that

P3para.Text: the patient is capable of consenting to the treatment;
the patient consents in writing to the treatment;
the giving of medical treatment to the patient is authorised by virtue of this Act or the 1995 Act; and
having regard to the likelihood of its alleviating, or preventing a deterioration in, the patients condition, it is in the patients best interests that the treatment should be given.

P2para.Text: If the patient withdraws consent to the treatment (in writing or otherwise) at any time before its completion, this section shall then apply as if the remainder of the treatment were a separate treatment.
Where the patient is a child, any certificate under subsection (1) above shall be given by a child specialist.

P1group.Title: Treatment mentioned in section 237(3): patients incapable of consenting

P2para.Text: Subject to subsections (2) to (4) below, medical treatment mentioned in section 237(3) of this Act is given to a patient in accordance with this section if a designated medical practitioner who is not the patients responsible medical officer certifies in writing that

P3para.Text: the patient is incapable of understanding the nature, purpose and likely effects of the treatment;
the giving of medical treatment to the patient is authorised by virtue of this Act or the 1995 Act; and
having regard to the likelihood of its alleviating, or preventing a deterioration in, the patients condition, it is in the patients best interests that the treatment should be given.

P2para.Text: Where the patient resists or objects to the treatment, certification under subsection (1) above is effective only if, instead of certifying the matter mentioned in paragraph (c) of that subsection, the designated medical practitioner certifies that

P3para.Text: the patient resists or objects to the treatment; but
it is necessary to give the treatment to the patient for a purpose mentioned in any of paragraphs (a) to (c) of section 243(3) of this Act and specified in the certificate.

P2para.Text: Where the patient is a child, certification under subsection (1) above is effective only if done

P3para.Text: where the patients responsible medical officer is a child specialist, by a medical practitioner approved for the purposes of this subsection by the Commission;
where the patients responsible medical officer is not a child specialist, by a child specialist who is on the list maintained under section 233(1) of this Act.

P2para.Text: Where the patient is not in hospital, subsection (1) above does not authorise the giving of medical treatment by force to the patient.

P1group.Title: Treatments given over period of time etc.

P2para.Text: This section applies where the giving of medical treatment to a patient is authorised by virtue of this Act or the 1995 Act.

Subject to subsection (4) below and to section 243 of this Act, the types of treatment mentioned in subsection (3) below, when given as treatment for mental disorder or in consequence of the patient having a mental disorder, may be given to the patient only in accordance with section 238 or 241 of this Act.
The types of treatment referred to in subsection (2) above are

P3para.Text: any medicine (other than the surgical implantation of hormones) given for the purpose of reducing sex drive;
any other medicine;
provision, without the consent of the patient and by artificial means, of nutrition to the patient; and
such other types of treatment as may be specified in regulations for the purposes of this section.

P2para.Text: Subsection (2) above does not apply to the giving of medicine in a relevant period until 2 months have passed since the patient was first in the relevant period given any medicine that was not, when given, a treatment specified under subsection (3)(d) above or section 234(2)(b) or 237(3)(b) of this Act.
The Scottish Ministers may by order amend subsection (4) above for the purpose of substituting a period specified in the order for (as the case may be)

P3para.Text: the period of 2 months mentioned in that subsection; or
the period that is for the time being mentioned in that subsection in place of that period of 2 months.

P2para.Text: For the purposes of subsection (4) above

Para.Text: medicine does not include medicine such as is mentioned in paragraph (a) of subsection (3) above or any treatment specified in regulations under paragraph (d) of that subsection; and
relevant period, in relation to a patient, means any period during which the giving of medical treatment to the patient is authorised by virtue of this Act or the 1995 Act.

P2para.Text: Before making regulations under subsection (3)(d) above the Scottish Ministers shall consult such persons as they consider appropriate.

P1group.Title: Treatment mentioned in section 240(3): patients refusing consent or incapable of consenting

P2para.Text: Subject to subsections (3) and (4) below, medical treatment mentioned in section 240(3) of this Act is given in accordance with this section if a designated medical practitioner who is not the patients responsible medical officer certifies in writing that

P3para.Text: the patient

P4para.Text: does not consent to the treatment; or
is incapable of consenting to the treatment;

P3para.Text: the giving of medical treatment to the patient is authorised by virtue of this Act or the 1995 Act; and
having regard to the likelihood of its alleviating, or preventing a deterioration in, the patients condition, it is in the patients best interests that the treatment should be given.

P2para.Text: If the condition mentioned in subsection (1)(a)(i) above applies, the designated medical practitioner shall

P3para.Text: if the reason for refusal of consent is known, have regard to the reason for the refusal; and
if the designated medical practitioner is of the opinion that the treatment should be given, include in any certificate under subsection (1) above a statement of the reason for that opinion.

P2para.Text: Where the patient is a child, the certification of the matters mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (c) of subsection (1) above is effective only if done

P3para.Text: where the patients responsible medical officer is a child specialist, by a medical practitioner approved for the purposes of this subsection by the Commission;
where the patients responsible medical officer is not a child specialist, by a child specialist who is on the list maintained under section 233(1) of this Act.

P2para.Text: Where the patient is not in hospital, subsection (1) above does not authorise the giving of medical treatment by force to the patient.

P1group.Title: Treatment not mentioned in section 234(2), 237(3) or 240(3)

P2para.Text: This section applies where the giving of medical treatment to a patient is authorised by virtue of this Act or the 1995 Act.
Subject to subsection (6) below and to sections 234(1), 237(2), 240(2) and 243 of this Act, medical treatment may be given to the patient only in accordance with subsection (3) or (4) below.
If the patient

P3para.Text: is capable of consenting to the treatment; and
consents in writing to the treatment,

P2para.Text: medical treatment is given to the patient in accordance with this subsection if the treatment is given by, or under the direction of, the patients responsible medical officer.
If the patient

P3para.Text: is capable of consenting to the treatment but

P4para.Text: does not consent; or
consents otherwise than in writing; or

P3para.Text: is incapable of consenting to the treatment,

P2para.Text: medical treatment is given to the patient in accordance with this subsection if the requirements in subsection (5) below are satisfied.
Those requirements are

P3para.Text: after having regard

P4para.Text: in a case where subsection (4)(a)(i) above applies, to the reason for not consenting (if it has been disclosed to the patients responsible medical officer);
to any views expressed by the patient;
to any views expressed by the patients named person;
to any advance statement made by the patient; and
to the likelihood of the treatments alleviating, or preventing a deterioration in, the patients condition,

P3para.Text: the responsible medical officer determines that it is in the patients best interests that the treatment be given;

in the case of a patient subject to an assessment order, an approved medical practitioner who is not the patients responsible medical officer determines, after having regard to the matters mentioned in sub-paragraphs (i) to (v) of paragraph (a) above, that it is in the patients best interests that the treatment be given;
the treatment is given by, or under the direction of, the patients responsible medical officer;
the patients responsible medical officer records in writing the reasons for giving the treatment; and

in the case of a patient subject to an assessment order, the approved medical practitioner who makes the determination referred to in paragraph (b) above records in writing the reasons for that determination.

P2para.Text: Where the patient is not in hospital, subsection (4) above does not authorise the giving of medical treatment by force to the patient.

Title.Emphasis: Urgent medical treatment where patient detained in hospital

P1group.Title: Urgent medical treatment

P2para.Text: This section applies where the detention in hospital of a patient is authorised by virtue of

P3para.Text: this Act; or
the 1995 Act.

P2para.Text: Where it is necessary as a matter of urgency for medical treatment to be given to the patient for any of the purposes mentioned in subsection (3) below, the treatment may, subject to subsections (4) and (5) below, be given notwithstanding that the patient

P3para.Text: does not consent; or
is incapable of consenting,

P2para.Text: to the treatment.
The purposes are

P3para.Text: saving the patients life;
preventing serious deterioration in the patients condition;
alleviating serious suffering on the part of the patient; and
preventing the patient from

P4para.Text: behaving violently; or
being a danger to the patient or to others.

P2para.Text: Subsection (2) above authorises the giving of medical treatment

P3para.Text: for a purpose mentioned in any of paragraphs (b) to (d) of subsection (3) above only if the treatment is not likely to entail unfavourable, and irreversible, physical or psychological consequences;
for a purpose mentioned in paragraph (c) or (d) of that subsection only if the treatment does not entail significant physical hazard to the patient.

P2para.Text: Subsection (2) above does not authorise the giving of electro-convulsive therapy if the patient is capable of consenting but does not consent to the treatment.

Where the patient is given medical treatment by virtue of subsection (2) above, the patients responsible medical officer shall, before the expiry of the period of 7 days beginning with the day on which such treatment is given (or first given), give notice to the Commission of

P3para.Text: the type of treatment given; and
the purpose mentioned in subsection (3) above for which it was given.

Title.Emphasis: Additional safeguards for certain informal patients

P1group.Title: Scottish Ministers' power to make provision in relation to treatment for certain informal patients

P1para.Text: Regulations may prescribe conditions that must be satisfied before types of medical treatment specified in the regulations may be given to patients

P3para.Text: who are under 16 years of age; and
in respect of whom the giving of medical treatment is not authorised by virtue of this Act or the 1995 Act.

P1group.Title: Certificates under sections 235, 236, 239 and 241

P2para.Text: This section applies to certificates under sections 235, 236, 239 and 241 of this Act.
A certificate shall contain such particulars as may be prescribed by regulations.
Before giving a certificate, the person giving it shall consult

P3para.Text: subject to subsection (4) below

P4para.Text: the patient; ...
the patients named person; and

Text.Addition: any guardian of the patient; and
any welfare attorney of the patient;

P3para.Text: such person or persons as appear to the person giving the certificate to be principally concerned with the patients medical treatment.

P2para.Text: The person giving a certificate need not consult any person such as is mentioned in paragraph (a) of subsection (3) above in any case where it is impracticable to do so.
A person who gives a certificate shall, before the expiry of the period of 7 days beginning with the day on which the certificate is given, send a copy of it to the Commission.

P1group.Title: Certificates under section 238

P2para.Text: A certificate under section 238 of this Act shall contain such particulars as may be prescribed by regulations.

Text.Addition: A person who gives a certificate under section 238 of this Act shall, before the expiry of the period of 7 days beginning with the day on which the certificate is given, send a copy of it to the Commission.

P1group.Title: Scope of consent or certificate under sections 235, 236, 238, 239 and 241

P1para.Text: Any

P3para.Text: consent; or
certificate,

P1para.Text: given under section 235, 236, 238, 239 or 241 of this Act may relate to a plan of treatment under which (whether during a specified period or otherwise) one or more of the types of treatment to which the consent or certificate relates is to be given to the patient.

P1group.Title: Sections 235, 236, 238, 239 and 241: review of treatment etc.

P2para.Text: Where medical treatment is given to a patient by virtue of section 235, 236,238, 239 or 241 of this Act, the patients responsible medical officer shall

P3para.Text: on the next occasion after the giving of the treatment on which the patients responsible medical officer submits a record to the Tribunal under section 87(2)(b) of this Act or, as the case may be, makes an application to the Tribunal under section 92 of this Act; or
at such other time as the patients responsible medical officer is required to do so by the Commission,

P2para.Text: submit to the Commission a report as to the treatment given and the patients condition.

The Commission may at any time by notice to the patients responsible medical officer revoke, with effect from such time as may be specified in the notice, a certificate given under section 235(2) or (3), 236(2) or (3), 238(1), 239 or 241(1) of this Act.
A time specified in a notice under subsection (2) above may not be earlier than the time of the notice.

P1group.Title: Interpretation of Part

P1para.Text: In this Part

Para.Text: child means a person who has not attained the age of 18 years; and
child specialist means a medical practitioner who has such qualifications or experience in relation to children as the Commission may determine from time to time.

P1group.Title: Nomination of named person

P2para.Text: Where a person who has attained the age of 16 years (a nominator) nominates in accordance with subsection (2) below another person who has attained that age to be the nominators named person, that person is, subject to subsections (2A), (3) and (6) below, the nominators named person.
A person is nominated in accordance with this subsection if

P3para.Text: the nomination is signed by the nominator;
the nominators signature is witnessed by a prescribed person;
the prescribed person certifies that, in the opinion of the prescribed person, the nominator

P4para.Text: understands the effect of nominating a person to be the nominators named person; and
has not been subjected to any undue influence in making the nomination.

P2para.Text: A nomination under subsection (1) above is valid only if

P3para.Text: a docket to the nomination states that the person nominated has consented to the nomination,
the docket is signed by the nominated person, ...

P2para.Text: A nomination under subsection (1) above may be revoked by the nominator in accordance with subsection (4) below.
The nomination of a named person is revoked in accordance with this subsection if

P3para.Text: the revocation is signed by the nominator;
the nominators signature is witnessed by a prescribed person;
the prescribed person certifies that, in the opinion of the prescribed person, the nominator

P4para.Text: understands the effect of revoking the appointment of a person as named person; and
has not been subjected to any undue influence in making the revocation.

P2para.Text: The nomination of a named person shall be effective notwithstanding the nominators becoming, after making the nomination, incapable.
A person nominated under subsection (1) above ceases to be the nominators named person by giving notice to

P3para.Text: the nominator; and
the local authority for the area in which the nominator resides,

P2para.Text: to that effect.
In this section

Para.Text: incapable means incapable by reason of mental disorder or of inability to communicate because of physical disability; but a person shall not fall within this definition by reason only of a lack or deficiency in a faculty of communication if that lack or deficiency can be made good by human or mechanical aid (whether of an interpretative nature or otherwise); and
prescribed person means a person of a class prescribed by regulations.

P1group.Title: Named person where no person nominated or nominated person declines to act
Named person in relation to child

P2para.Text: The named person of a person who has not attained the age of 16 years (the child) shall be

P3para.Text: subject to subsection (2) below, in a case where a relevant person has parental rights and parental responsibilities in relation to the child, that person;
in a case where the child is in the care of a local authority by virtue of a care order made under section 31 of the Children Act 1989 (c. 41), that authority; or
in any other case, where the childs primary carer has attained the age of 16 years, that person.

P2para.Text: Subject to subsection (3) below, where two or more relevant persons have parental rights and parental responsibilities in relation to the child, the named person of the child shall be

P3para.Text: if those persons agree that one of them is to be the named person of the child, that person; or
if those persons do not so agree, the one of them

P4para.Text: who provides, on a regular basis, all, or most, of the care for, and support to, the child;
in a case where the child is in hospital, who provided all, or most, of that care for, and support to, the child before the child was admitted to hospital.

P2para.Text: If

P3para.Text: one of therelevant persons who has parental rights and parental responsibilities in relation to the child is a local authority; and

the local authority has those rights and responsibilities by virtue of an order under section 86(1) of the Children (Scotland) Act 1995 (c. 36) (orders transferring parental rights and parental responsibilities),

P2para.Text: the local authority shall be the childs named person.
In this section

Para.Text: parental responsibilities, in relation to a child, has the meaning given by section 1(3) of the Children (Scotland) Act 1995 (c. 36); ...
parental rights, in relation to a child, has the meaning given by section 2(4) of that Act.

Text.Substitution: ; and
relevant person means
a local authority; or
a person who has attained the age of 16 years.

P1group.Title: Declaration in relation to named person
Meaning of nearest relative

P2para.Text: In this Act, nearest relative, in relation to a person (the relevant person), means

P3para.Text: subject to subsection (3) below, in a case where only one person falls within the list set out in subsection (2) below, that person;

subject to subsections (3) and (4) below, in a case where two or more persons fall within that list, the person falling within the paragraph first appearing in the list set out in subsection (2) below.

P2para.Text: The list mentioned in subsection (1) above is

P3para.Text: the relevant persons spouse;or civil partner
a person such as is mentioned in subsection (7) below;
the relevant persons child;
the relevant persons parent;
the relevant persons brother or sister;
the relevant persons grandparent;
the relevant persons grandchild;
the relevant persons uncle or aunt;
the relevant persons niece or nephew;
the person mentioned in subsection (8) below.

P2para.Text: If the relevant persons spouseor civil partner

P3para.Text: is permanently separated (either by agreement or under an order of a court) from the relevant person; or
has deserted, or has been deserted by, the relevant person and the desertion continues,

P2para.Text: subsection (2)(a) above shall be disregarded for the purposes of subsection (1) above.
Where two or more persons fall within the paragraph first appearing on the list set out in subsection (2) above, the nearest relative shall be

P3para.Text: if those persons agree that one of them should be the nearest relative, that person; or
if those persons do not so agree, the person determined in accordance with the following rules

P4para.Text: brothers and sisters of the whole blood shall be preferred over brothers and sisters of the half-blood; and
the elder or eldest, as the case may be, shall be preferred.

P2para.Text: A relevant persons nearest relative may decline to be the named person of the relevant person by giving notice to

P3para.Text: the relevant person; and
the local authority for the area in which the relevant person resides,

P2para.Text: to that effect.
For the purposes of subsection (2) above

P3para.Text: a relationship of the half-blood shall, subject to subsection (4)(b)(i) above, be treated as a relationship of the whole blood;
the stepchild of a person shall be treated as the child of that person;
if the relevant person is ordinarily resident in the United Kingdom, the Channel Islands or the Isle of Man, any person who is not so resident shall be disregarded; and
any person who is under 16 years of age shall be disregarded.

P2para.Text: The person referred to in subsection (2)(b) above is a person who

P3para.Text: is living with the relevant person

P4para.Text: as husband and wife; or
in a relationship which has the characteristics of the relationship between civil partners; and

P3para.Text: has been living with the relevant person for a period of at least 6 months or, if the relevant person is for the time being in hospitalor in a care home service, had been living with the relevant person for such period when the relevant person was admitted to hospitalor to a care home service.

P2para.Text: The person referred to in subsection (2)(j) above is a person who

P3para.Text: is living with the relevant person and has been living with the relevant person for a period of at least 5 years; or
if the relevant person is in hospitalor in a care home service, had been living with the relevant person for such period when the relevant person was admitted to hospitalor to a care home service.

P1group.Title: Named person: mental health officers duties etc.

P2para.Text: Subsection (2) below applies where

P3para.Text: a mental health officer is discharging any function by virtue of this Act or the 1995 Act in relation to a patient; and
it is necessary for the purposes of the discharge of the function to establish whether the patient has a named person.

P2para.Text: The mental health officer shall take such steps as are reasonably practicable

P3para.Text: to establish whether the patient has a named person; and
if so, to ascertain who that person is.

P2para.Text: Where by virtue of subsection (2) above

P3para.Text: the mental health officer

P4para.Text: establishes that the patient has a named person; and
ascertains the name of that person (the apparent named person); but

P3para.Text: the mental health officer considers that it is inappropriate for the apparent named person to be the patients named person,

P2para.Text: the mental health officer shall apply to the Tribunal for an order under section 257 of this Act.
Where

P3para.Text: a mental health officer is discharging any function by virtue of this Act in relation to a patient; and
it appears to the mental health officer

P4para.Text: that the patient has a named person (the apparent named person) but the mental health officer considers that it is inappropriate for the apparent named person to be the patients named person,

P3para.Text: the mental health officer may apply to the Tribunal for an order under section 257 of this Act.

Title.Emphasis: Applications to Tribunal by patient etc.

P1group.Title: Named person: application by patient etc.

P2para.Text: Where

P3para.Text: a person mentioned in subsection (2) below (the applicant) considers that though the patient has a named person it is inappropriate that that person be the patients named person; or
circumstances of such description as may be prescribed by regulations exist,

P2para.Text: the applicant may apply to the Tribunal for an order under section 257 of this Act in relation to the patient.
Those persons are

P3para.Text: the patient;
the patients responsible medical officer;
if the patient is a child, any person who has parental responsibilities in relation to the patient;
if the patient is in hospital, the managers of the hospital;
any welfare attorney of the patient;
any guardian of the patient;
any relative of the patient; and
any other person having an interest in the welfare of the patient.

P2para.Text: In subsection (2)(c) above, child and parental responsibilities have the same meanings as they have in Part I of the Children (Scotland) Act 1995 (c. 36).

P1group.Title: Named person: Tribunals powers

P2para.Text: Where

P3para.Text: an application is made under section 255(6) or (7)(b)(ii) or 256(1)(b) of this Act; and
the Tribunal is satisfied that it is inappropriate for the named person (the acting named person) to be the patients named person,

P2para.Text: the Tribunal may, subject to subsection (4) below, make an order as allowed by subsection (3A).
Where an application is made under section 256(1)(c) of this Act, the Tribunal may, subject to subsection (4) or (5) below, make such order as it thinks fit.

Text.Addition: For the purpose of subsection (2), this subsection allows an order
in any case, to declare that the acting named person is not the named person,
if the patient has not attained the age of 16 years, to appoint the person specified in the order to be the patient's named person in place of the acting named person.

P2para.Text: It shall not be competent for the Tribunal to make an order under this section appointing a person who has not attained the age of 16 years to be a patients named person.

Text.Addition: An order under this section appointing a person to be a patient's named person may be made only if
a document, signed by the person, states that the person has consented to being the patient's named person, and
the person's signature is witnessed by someone.
A person appointed by an order under this section to be a patient's named person ceases to be the patient's named person by giving notice to that effect to
the Tribunal,
the patient, and
the local authority for the area in which the patient resides.

Emphasis.Addition: Ability to act if no named person

Title.Addition: Ability to act if no named person

Text.Addition: This section applies if
a patient does not have a named person,
the patient has attained the age of 16 years, and
the patient is incapable in relation to a decision as to whether to initiate an application or appeal in the patient's case.
In subsection (1)(c) above,
has the same meaning as in section 250 of this Act.

Each of the persons listed in subsection (9)(a) to (d) below has authority to initiate an application or appeal that may be made by the patient under section 50(1), 99(1), 100(2), 120(2), 125(2), 126(2), 163(1), 164(2),

Each of the persons listed in subsection (9)(a) and (b) below has authority to obtain any notice or information that is to be provided under section 54(3), 60(1), 87(2)(c), 124(4) or (6), 127(7), 128(3), 129(3) or (4), 153(2)(c), 200(3), 218(4), (6) or (10)(b), 224(8), 225(3) or 226(3) of this Act.

The reference in subsection (3) above to section 264(2), 268(2), 320(2), 321(1) or 322(2) of this Act does not apply in relation to a guardian or a welfare attorney of the patient (as that person is already entitled to make an application or appeal under that section).
In the application of subsection (4) above
the reference to section 87(2)(c) or 153(2)(c) relates only to notice of the determination mentioned in that section (and not also to a copy of the record mentioned in that section),

the reference to section 128(3) or 129(4) relates to a responsible medical officer's reasons only if that officer is satisfied that it is appropriate to give notice of them to a guardian or a welfare attorney of the patient (having regard to the need to ensure the patient's wellbeing and confidentiality).

Neither of the persons listed in subsection (9)(c) or (d) below has authority to act in relation to a patient by virtue of this section if the patient has made a written declaration precluding the person (or all persons) from so acting.

Subsections (2) to (5) and (7) of section 250 of this Act apply to a declaration mentioned in subsection (7) above as they apply to a nomination to which subsection (1) of that section relates (with that section to be read accordingly).
The listed persons are
any guardian of the patient,
any welfare attorney of the patient,
the patient's primary carer (if any),
the patient's nearest relative.

P1group.Title: Interpretation of Chapter

P1para.Text: In this Chapter, other than section 252, person means a natural person.

P1group.Title: Advocacy

P2para.Text: Every person with a mental disorder shall have a right of access to independent advocacy; and accordingly it is the duty of

P3para.Text: each local authority, in collaboration with the (or each) relevant Health Board; and
each Health Board, in collaboration with the (or each) relevant local authority,

P2para.Text: to secure the availability, to persons in its area who have a mental disorder, of independent advocacy services and to take appropriate steps to ensure that those persons have the opportunity of making use of those services.

Each relevant Health Board and local authority shall, for the purposes of subsection (1) above, collaborate with the local authority or, as the case may be, Health Board in relation to which it is the relevant Board or authority.
For the purposes of subsections (1) and (2) above

P3para.Text: a Health Board is, in relation to a local authority, a relevant Health Board if its area or part of its area is the same as or is included in the area of the local authority; and
a local authority is, in relation to a Health Board, a relevant local authority if its area or part of its area is the same as or is included in the area of the Health Board.

P2para.Text: In subsection (1) above, advocacy services are services of support and representation made available for the purpose of enabling the person to whom they are available to have as much control of, or capacity to influence, that persons care and welfare as is, in the circumstances, appropriate.
For the purposes of subsection (1) above, advocacy services are independent if they are to be provided by a person who is none of the following

P3para.Text: a local authority;
a Health Board;
a National Health Service trust;
a member of

P4para.Text: the local authority;
the Health Board;
a National Health Service trust,

P3para.Text: in the area of which the person to whom those services are made available is to be provided with them;
a person who

P4para.Text: in pursuance of arrangements made between that person and a Health Board, is giving medical treatment to;
in pursuance of those arrangements, is providing, under the National Health Service (Scotland) Act 1978 (c. 29), treatment, care or services for; or

in pursuance of arrangements made between that person and a local authority, is providing, under Part II of the Social Work (Scotland) Act 1968 (c. 49)
(promotion of social welfare) or any of the enactments specified in section 5(1B) of that Act, services for,

P3para.Text: the person to whom the advocacy services are made available;

in relation to a patient detained in a state hospital or a person who (by virtue of any of the means specified in subsection (11)(b) below) is no longer detained there, the State Hospitals Board for Scotland or a member of that Board.

P2para.Text: In subsection (5)(d) above the reference to the area of a National Health Service trust is a reference to the Health Board area in which the trust discharges its functions.

It is the duty of the State Hospitals Board for Scotland (the State Hospitals Board) to secure the availability to persons who are patients detained in a state hospital of the services referred to in subsection (1) above and, in relation to those persons, to take the steps there referred to.
It is the duty of

P3para.Text: the State Hospitals Board, in collaboration with each relevant local authority and Health Board; and
each relevant local authority and Health Board, in collaboration with the State Hospitals Board,

P2para.Text: to secure the availability to relevant persons of the services referred to in subsection (1) above, and, in relation to those persons, to take the steps there referred to.
Each relevant local authority and Health Board shall, for the purposes of subsection (8)(a) above, collaborate with the State Hospitals Board and with each other.
The State Hospitals Board shall, for the purposes of subsection (8)(b) above, collaborate with each relevant local authority and Health Board.
For the purposes of subsections (8) to (10) above

P3para.Text: a local authority or Health Board is a relevant local authority or, as the case may be, Health Board if there is residing in its area a relevant person;
a relevant person is a person with a mental disorder who, having been detained as a patient in a state hospital, is (by virtue of section 127 or 193(7) of this Act) no longer detained there.

Title.Addition: Information gathering

Text.Addition: Each of the bodies mentioned in subsection (2) below must give the Commission such information as the Commission may from time to time seek on how the body
has, during a period of at least 2 years specified by the Commission, been exercising the functions conferred on the body by section 259 of this Act, and
intends, during a period of at least 2 years specified by the Commission, to exercise the functions conferred on the body by section 259 of this Act.
The bodies are
a local authority,
a Health Board,
the State Hospitals Board for Scotland.

P1group.Title: Provision of information to patient

P2para.Text: This section applies where a patient

P3para.Text: is detained in hospital by virtue of

P4para.Text: this Act; or
the 1995 Act; or

P3para.Text: though not detained in hospital, is subject to

P4para.Text: an emergency detention certificate;
a short-term detention certificate;
a compulsory treatment order;
an interim compulsory treatment order;
an assessment order;
a treatment order;
a hospital direction;
a transfer for treatment direction;
an interim compulsion order; or
a compulsion order.

P2para.Text: The appropriate person shall

P3para.Text: take all reasonable steps

P4para.Text: to ensure that the patient understands the relevant matters at each of the times mentioned in subsection (3) below;

to ensure that the patient is supplied with material appropriate to the patients needs (and in a form that is appropriate to those needs and permanent) from which the patient may refresh the patients understanding of those matters; and
to inform the patient of the availability under section 259 of this Act of independent advocacy services at each of those times; and

P3para.Text: take appropriate steps to ensure that the patient has the opportunity of making use of those services.

P2para.Text: Those times are

P3para.Text: as soon as practicable after

P4para.Text: where the patient is detained in hospital, the beginning of such detention; or
where the patient is not so detained, the making of the order;

P3para.Text: as soon as practicable after any occasion on which the patient reasonably requests to be informed of those matters; and
such other times as may be prescribed by regulations.

P2para.Text: Where material is supplied to the patient under subsection (2)(a)(ii) above, the appropriate person shall, as soon as practicable after such material is supplied, take all reasonable steps to ensure that the patients named person is supplied with a copy of such material in a form that is appropriate to the persons needs.
In this section

Para.Text: the appropriate person means
where the patient is detained in hospital, the managers of the hospital;

where by virtue of a certificate granted under any provision of this Act, the authorisation to detain the patient in a hospital is suspended, the managers of the hospital in which, but for the certificate, the patient would be authorised to be detained;
in any other case, the managers of the hospital specified in the order; and
the relevant matters means
the provision of this Act or the 1995 Act by virtue of which
the patient is being detained; or
the order has effect;
the consequences of the operation of that provision;
the powers that the patients responsible medical officer and the Tribunal each has in relation to revoking that provision;
any right to make an application, or appeal, to the Tribunal that the patient has by virtue of that provision;
the powers exercisable by the Tribunal in the event of any such right being exercised;
how the patient may exercise any such right;
the functions that the Commission has that appear to be relevant to the patients case;
how the patient may obtain legal assistance as respects any such right.

P1group.Title: Provision of assistance to patient with communication difficulties

P2para.Text: This section applies where

P3para.Text: a patient is detained in hospital by virtue of

P4para.Text: this Act; or
the 1995 Act; or

P3para.Text: though not detained in hospital, a patient is subject to

P4para.Text: an emergency detention certificate;
a short-term detention certificate;
a compulsory treatment order;
an interim compulsory treatment order;
an assessment order;
a treatment order;
a hospital direction;
a transfer for treatment direction;
an interim compulsion order; or
a compulsion order,

P3para.Text: and the patient has difficulty in communicating or generally communicates in a language other than English.

P2para.Text: The appropriate person shall take all reasonable steps to secure that, for the purpose of enabling the patient to communicate during each of the events mentioned in subsection (3) below

P3para.Text: arrangements appropriate to the patients needs are made; or
the patient is provided with assistance, or material, appropriate to the patients needs.

P2para.Text: Those events are

P3para.Text: any medical examination of the patient carried out for the purpose of assessing the patients mental disorder;
any review under this Act or the 1995 Act of the patients detention; or
any proceedings before the Tribunal relating to the patient.

P2para.Text: As soon as practicable after taking any steps under subsection (2) above, the appropriate person shall make a written record of the steps.
In this section the appropriate person has the meaning given by section 260(5) of this Act.

Title.Addition: Help with communication at medical examination
etc.

Text.Addition: Subsection (2) below applies where
a medical examination or interview referred to in subsection (4)(a) or (b) below is to be carried out, and
the subject of it
has difficulty in communicating, or
generally communicates in a language other than English.
The appropriate person must take all reasonable steps to secure that, for the purpose of enabling the subject of the medical examination or interview to communicate during it
arrangements appropriate to the subject's needs are made, or
the subject is provided with assistance, or material, appropriate to those needs.
As soon as practicable after taking any steps under subsection (2) above, the appropriate person must make a written record of the steps.
This subsection refers to
a medical examination by virtue of section 36(1)(a), 44(1)(a), 57(2) or 136(2) of this Act,
an interview by virtue of
section 45(1)(a) or 61(2)(a) of this Act, or
section 57C(2)(a) or 59B(2)(a) of the 1995 Act.
In subsections (2) and (3) above,
means
in relation to a medical examination by virtue of section 136(2) of this Act, the Scottish Ministers,
in relation to a medical examination by virtue of any of the other sections of this Act mentioned in subsection (4)(a) above
if it is to be carried out at a hospital, the managers of the hospital,
if it is to be carried out elsewhere, the medical practitioner carrying it out,
in relation to an interview referred to in subsection (4)(b) above
if it is to be carried out at a hospital, the managers of the hospital,
if it is to be carried out elsewhere, the mental health officer carrying it out.

P1group.Title: Access to medical practitioner for purposes of medical examination

P2para.Text: This section applies where a patient is detained in hospital by virtue of

P3para.Text: this Act; or
the 1995 Act.

P2para.Text: A duly authorised medical practitioner may, for any of the purposes mentioned in subsection (3) below, visit the patient at any reasonable hour and carry out a medical examination of the patient in private.
Those purposes are

P3para.Text: advising the patient or, as the case may be, the patients named person about the making of applications to the Tribunal in respect of the patient under this Act; and
providing to the patient or, as the case may be, the patients named person information as respects the condition of the patient for the purpose of

P4para.Text: any such application (or proposed application); or
any other proceedings before the Tribunal in respect of the patient in which the patient or, as the case may be, the patients named person is taking part (or considering whether to take part).

P2para.Text: For the purposes of subsection (2) above and subject to subsection (5) below, a medical practitioner is duly authorised if authorised for the purposes of this section by

P3para.Text: the patient; or
the patients named person.

P2para.Text: Authorisation given for the purposes of this section by the patients named person may be rescinded by the patient at any time when the patient is not incapable.
In subsection (5) above, incapable has the same meaning as in section 250(7) of this Act.

P1group.Title: Inspection of records by medical practitioner

P2para.Text: A duly authorised medical practitioner may, for any of the purposes mentioned in subsection (3) below, require any person holding records relating to

P3para.Text: the detention of; or
medical treatment given at any time to,

P2para.Text: a patient whose detention in hospital is authorised by virtue of this Act or the 1995 Act to produce them for inspection by the medical practitioner.

A duly authorised medical practitioner may, for any of the purposes mentioned in subsection (3) below, require any person holding records relating to medical treatment given at any time to a patient who is subject to

P3para.Text: a compulsory treatment order; or
a compulsion order,

P2para.Text: that does not authorise the detention of the patient in hospital to produce them for inspection by the medical practitioner.
Those purposes are

P3para.Text: advising the patient or, as the case may be, the patients named person about the making of applications to the Tribunal in respect of the patient under this Act;
providing to the patient or, as the case may be, the patients named person information as respects the condition of the patient for the purpose of

P4para.Text: any such application (or proposed application); or
any other proceedings before the Tribunal in respect of the patient in which the patient or, as the case may be, the patients named person is taking part (or considering whether to take part).

P2para.Text: For the purposes of subsections (1) and (2) above and subject to subsection (5) below, a medical practitioner is duly authorised if authorised for the purposes of this section by

P3para.Text: the patient; or
the patients named person.

P2para.Text: Authorisation given for the purposes of this section by the patients named person may be rescinded by the patient at any time when the patient is not incapable.
In subsection (5) above, incapable has the same meaning as in section 250(7) of this Act.

Chapter.Title: Detention in conditions of excessive security

P1group.Title: Detention in conditions of excessive security: state hospitals

P2para.Text: This section applies where a patients detention in a state hospital is authorised by

P3para.Text: a compulsory treatment order;
a compulsion order;
a hospital direction; or
a transfer for treatment direction;

P2para.Text:
and whether or not a certificate under section 127(1)
(either as enacted or as applied by section 179(1) of this Act) or 224(2) of this Act has effect in relation to the patient.

On the application of any of the persons mentioned in subsection (6) below, the Tribunal may, if satisfied that the patient does not require to be detained under conditions of special security that can be provided only in a state hospital, make an order

P3para.Text: declaring that the patient is being detained in conditions of excessive security; and
specifying a period, not exceeding 3 months and beginning with the making of the order, during which the duties under subsections (3) to (5) below shall be performed.

P2para.Text: Where the Tribunal makes an order under subsection (2) above in respect of a relevant patient, the relevant Health Board shall identify a hospital

P3para.Text: which is not a state hospital;
which the Board and the Scottish Ministers, and its managers if they are not the Board, agree is a hospital in which the patient could be detained in appropriate conditions; and
in which accommodation is available for the patient.

P2para.Text: Where the Tribunal makes an order under subsection (2) above in respect of a patient who is not a relevant patient, the relevant Health Board shall identify a hospital

P3para.Text: which is not a state hospital;
which the Board considers, and its managers if they are not the Board agree, is a hospital in which the patient could be detained in appropriate conditions; and
in which accommodation is available for the patient.

P2para.Text: Where the Tribunal makes an order under subsection (2) above in respect of a patient, the relevant Health Board shall, as soon as practicable after identifying a hospital under subsection (3) or, as the case may be, (4) above, give notice to the managers of the state hospital of the name of the hospital so identified.
The persons referred to in subsection (2) above are

P3para.Text: the patient;
the patients named person;
any guardian of the patient;
any welfare attorney of the patient; and
the Commission.

P2para.Text: An application may not be made under subsection (2) above

P3para.Text: if the compulsory treatment order that authorises the patients detention in hospital has not been extended;
during the period of 6 months beginning with the making of the compulsion order that authorises the patients detention in hospital; or
before the expiry of the period of 6 months beginning with the making of

P4para.Text: the hospital direction; or
the transfer for treatment direction,

P3para.Text: that authorises the patients detention in hospital.

Text.Addition: An application may not be made under subsection (2) above unless it is accompanied by a report prepared by
practitioner which
states that in the practitioner's opinion the patient does not require to be detained under conditions of special security that can be provided only in a state hospital, and
sets out the practitioner's reasons for being of that opinion.

P2para.Text: No more than one application may be made under subsection (2) above in respect of the same patient

P3para.Text: during the period of 12 months beginning with the day on which the order, or direction, authorising the patients detention in hospital is made;
during any subsequent period of 12 months that begins with, or with an anniversary of, the expiry of the period mentioned in paragraph (a) above.

P2para.Text: Before determining an application under subsection (2) above, the Tribunal shall

P3para.Text: afford the persons mentioned in subsection (10) below the opportunity

P4para.Text: of making representations (whether orally or in writing); and
of leading, or producing, evidence; and

P3para.Text: whether or not any such representations are made, hold a hearing.

P2para.Text: Those persons are

P3para.Text: the patient;
the patients named person;
the relevant Health Board;
the patients responsible medical officer;
the managers of the state hospital in which the patient is detained;
the mental health officer;
any guardian of the patient;
any welfare attorney of the patient;
any curator ad litem appointed by the Tribunal in respect of the patient;
the Commission;
in the case of a relevant patient, the Scottish Ministers; and
any other person appearing to the Tribunal to have an interest in the application.

P1group.Title: Order under section 264: further provision

P2para.Text: This section applies where

P3para.Text: an order is made under section 264(2) of this Act in respect of a patient; and
the order is not recalled under section 267 of this Act;

P2para.Text:
and whether or not a certificate under section 127(1)
(either as enacted or as applied by section 179(1) of this Act) or 224(2) of this Act has effect in relation to the patient.

If the relevant Health Board fails, during the period specified in the order, to give notice to the Tribunal that the patient has been transferred to another hospital, there shall be a hearing before the Tribunal.

Where such a hearing is held, the Tribunal may, if satisfied that the patient does not require to be detained under conditions of special security that can be provided only in a state hospital, make an order

P3para.Text: declaring that the patient is being detained in conditions of excessive security; and
specifying

P4para.Text: a period of 28 days; or
such longer period not exceeding 3 months as the Tribunal thinks fit,

P3para.Text: beginning with the day on which the order is made during which the duties under subsections (4) to (6) below shall be performed.

P2para.Text: Where the Tribunal makes an order under subsection (3) above in respect of a relevant patient, the relevant Health Board shall identify a hospital

P3para.Text: which is not a state hospital;
which the Board and the Scottish Ministers, and its managers if they are not the Board, agree is a hospital in which the patient could be detained in appropriate conditions; and
in which accommodation is available for the patient.

P2para.Text: Where the Tribunal makes an order under subsection (3) above in respect of a patient who is not a relevant patient, the relevant Health Board shall identify a hospital

P3para.Text: which is not a state hospital;
which the Board considers, and its managers if they are not the Board agree, is a hospital in which the patient could be detained in appropriate conditions; and
in which accommodation is available for the patient.

P2para.Text: Where the Tribunal makes an order under subsection (3) above in respect of a patient, the relevant Health Board shall, as soon as practicable after identifying a hospital under subsection (4) or, as the case may be, (5) above, give notice to the managers of the state hospital of the name of the hospital so identified.
Before making an order under subsection (3) above, the Tribunal shall afford the persons mentioned in section 264(10) of this Act the opportunity

P3para.Text: of making representations (whether orally or in writing); and
of leading, or producing, evidence.

P1group.Title: Order under section 265: further provision

P2para.Text: This section applies where an order is made under section 264(2) or 265(3) of this Act in respect of a patient.
On the application of any of the persons mentioned in subsection (4) below, the Tribunal

P3para.Text: shall, if satisfied that the patient requires to be detained under conditions of special security that can be provided only in a state hospital, recall the order;
may, on any other grounds, recall the order.

P2para.Text: Where the order is recalled, the relevant Health Board ceases to be subject to the duties under section 264(3) to (5) or 265(4) to (6) to which it became subject by virtue of the making of the order.
The persons referred to in subsection (2) above are

P3para.Text: the relevant Health Board;
in the case of a relevant patient, the Scottish Ministers;
in the case of a patient who is not a relevant patient, the patients responsible medical officer.

P2para.Text: Before determining an application under subsection (2) above, the Tribunal shall

P3para.Text: afford the persons mentioned in section 264(10) of this Act the opportunity

P4para.Text: of making representations (whether orally or in writing); and
of leading, or producing, evidence; and

P3para.Text: whether or not any such representations are made, hold a hearing.

P1group.Title: Detention in conditions of excessive security: hospitals other than state hospitals

P2para.Text: This section applies where a ... patients detention in a qualifying hospital is authorised by

P3para.Text: a compulsory treatment order;
a compulsion order;
a hospital direction; or
a transfer for treatment direction;

P2para.Text:
and whether or not a certificate under section 127(1)
(either as enacted or as applied by section 179(1) of this Act) or 224(2) of this Act has effect in relation to the patient.

On the application of any of the persons mentioned in subsection (6) below, the Tribunal may, if satisfied that the test specified in regulations made under section 271A(2) of this Act is met in relation to the patient, make an order

P3para.Text: declaring that the patient is being detained in conditions of excessive security; and
specifying a period, not exceeding 3 months and beginning with the making of the order, during which the duties under subsections (3) to (5) below shall be performed.

P2para.Text: Where the Tribunal makes an order under subsection (2) above in respect of a relevant patient, the relevant Health Board shall identify a hospital

P3para.Text: which is not a state hospital;

which the Board and the Scottish Ministers, and its managers if they are not the Board, agree is a hospital in which the patient could be detained in conditions that would not involve the patient being subject to a level of security that is excessive in the patients case; and
in which accommodation is available for the patient.

P2para.Text: Where the Tribunal makes an order under subsection (2) above in respect of a patient who is not a relevant patient, the relevant Health Board shall identify a hospital

P3para.Text: which is not a state hospital;

which the Board considers, and its managers if they are not the Board agree, is a hospital in which the patient could be detained in conditions that would not involve the patient being subject to a level of security that is excessive in the patients case; and
in which accommodation is available for the patient.

P2para.Text: Where the Tribunal makes an order under subsection (2) above in respect of a patient, the relevant Health Board shall, as soon as practicable after identifying a hospital under subsection (3) or, as the case may be, (4) above, give notice of the name of the hospital so identified to the managers of the hospital in which the patient is detained.
The persons referred to in subsection (2) above are

P3para.Text: the ... patient;
the ... patients named person;
any guardian of the ... patient;
any welfare attorney of the ... patient; and
the Commission.

P2para.Text: An application may not be made under subsection (2) above

P3para.Text: if the compulsory treatment order that authorises the patients detention in hospital has not been extended;
during the period of 6 months beginning with the making of the compulsion order that authorises the patients detention in hospital; or
before the expiry of the period of 6 months beginning with the making of

P4para.Text: the hospital direction; or
the transfer for treatment direction,

P3para.Text: that authorises the patients detention in hospital.

Text.Addition: An application may not be made under subsection (2) above unless it is accompanied by a report prepared by
practitioner which
states that in the practitioner's opinion the test specified in regulations made under section 271A(2) of this Act is met in relation to the patient, and
sets out the practitioner's reasons for being of that opinion.

P2para.Text: No more than one application may be made under subsection (2) above in respect of the same patient

P3para.Text: during the period of 12 months beginning with the day on which the order, or direction, authorising the patients detention in hospital is made;
during any subsequent period of 12 months that begins with, or with an anniversary of, the expiry of the period mentioned in paragraph (a) above.

P2para.Text: Before determining an application under subsection (2) above, the Tribunal shall

P3para.Text: afford the persons mentioned in subsection (10) below the opportunity

P4para.Text: of making representations (whether orally or in writing); and
of leading, or producing, evidence; and

P3para.Text: whether or not any such representations are made, hold a hearing.

P2para.Text: Those persons are

P3para.Text: the ... patient;
the ... patients named person;
the relevant Health Board;
the ... patients responsible medical officer;
the managers of the hospital in which the patient is detained;
the mental health officer;
any guardian of the ... patient;
any welfare attorney of the ... patient;
any curator ad litem appointed by the Tribunal in respect of the ... patient;
the Commission;
in the case of a relevant patient, the Scottish Ministers; and
any other person appearing to the Tribunal to have an interest in the application.

P1group.Title: Order under section 268: further provision

P2para.Text: This section applies where

P3para.Text: an order is made under section 268(2) of this Act in respect of a ... patient; and
the order is not recalled under section 271 of this Act;

P2para.Text:
and whether or not a certificate under section 127(1)
(either as enacted or as applied by section 179(1) of this Act) or 224(2) of this Act has effect in relation to the patient.

If the relevant Health Board fails, during the period specified in the order, to give notice to the Tribunal that the ... patient has been transferred to another hospital, there shall be a hearing before the Tribunal.
Where such a hearing is held, the Tribunal may, if satisfied that the test specified in regulations made under section 271A(2) of this Act is met in relation to the patient, make an order

P3para.Text: declaring that the patient is being detained in conditions of excessive security; and
specifying

P4para.Text: a period of 28 days; or
such longer period not exceeding 3 months as the Tribunal thinks fit,

P3para.Text: beginning with the day on which the order is made during which the duties under subsections (4) to (6) below shall be performed.

P2para.Text: Where the Tribunal makes an order under subsection (3) above in respect of a relevant patient, the relevant Health Board shall identify a hospital

P3para.Text: which is not a state hospital;

which the Board and the Scottish Ministers, and its managers if they are not the Board, agree is a hospital in which the patient could be detained in conditions that would not involve the patient being subject to a level of security that is excessive in the patients case; and
in which accommodation is available for the patient.

P2para.Text: Where the Tribunal makes an order under subsection (3) above in respect of a patient who is not a relevant patient, the relevant Health Board shall identify a hospital

P3para.Text: which is not a state hospital;

which the Board considers, and its managers if they are not the Board agree, is a hospital in which the patient could be detained in conditions that would not involve the patient being subject to a level of security that is excessive in the patients case; and
in which accommodation is available for the patient.

P2para.Text: Where the Tribunal makes an order under subsection (3) above in respect of a patient, the relevant Health Board shall, as soon as practicable after identifying a hospital under subsection (4) or, as the case may be, (5) above, give notice of the name of the hospital so identified to the managers of the hospital in which the patient is detained.
Before making an order under subsection (3) above, the Tribunal shall afford the persons mentioned in section 268(10) of this Act the opportunity

P3para.Text: of making representations (whether orally or in writing); and
of leading, or producing, evidence.

P1group.Title: Order under section 269: further provision

P2para.Text: This section applies where an order is made under section 268(2) or 269(3) of this Act in respect of a ... patient.
On the application of any of the persons mentioned in subsection (4) below, the Tribunal

P3para.Text: shall, if satisfied that the test specified in regulations made under section 271A(2) of this Act is not met in relation to the patient, recall the order;
may, on any other grounds, recall the order.

P2para.Text: Where the order is recalled, the relevant Health Board ceases to be subject to the duties under section 268(3) to (5) or 269(4) to (6) to which it became subject by virtue of the making of the order.
The persons referred to in subsection (2) above are

P3para.Text: the relevant Health Board;
in the case of a relevant patient, the Scottish Ministers;
in the case of a patient who is not a relevant patient, the patients responsible medical officer.

P2para.Text: Before determining an application under subsection (2) above, the Tribunal shall

P3para.Text: afford the persons mentioned in section 268(10) of this Act the opportunity

P4para.Text: of making representations (whether orally or in writing); and
of leading, or producing, evidence; and

P3para.Text: whether or not any such representations are made, hold a hearing.

Title.Addition: Regulation-making powers

Text.Addition: A hospital is a
for the purposes of sections 268 to 271 of this Act if
it is not a state hospital, and
it is specified, or is of a description specified, in regulations.
Regulations may specify the test for the purposes of sections 268(2), 269(3) and 271(2)(a) of this Act.
Regulations under subsection (2) above specifying the test

must include as a requirement for the test to be met in relation to a patient that the Tribunal be satisfied that detention of the patient in the hospital in which the patient is being detained involves the patient being subject to a level of security that is excessive in the patient's case, and
may include further requirements for the test to be met in relation to a patient.
Regulations may make provision about when, for the purposes of
any regulations made under subsection (2) above, and
sections 268 to 271 of this Act,
a patient's detention in a hospital is to be taken to involve the patient being subject to a level of security that is excessive in the patient's case.

Regulations may modify sections 264 and 268 of this Act so as to provide that a person must meet criteria besides being a medical practitioner in order to prepare a report for the purpose of subsection (7A) in each of those sections.

P1group.Title: Proceedings for specific performance of statutory duty

P2para.Text: The duties imposed by virtue of

Text.Substitution: an order under section 264(2) of this Act, or
an order under section 268(2) of this Act,

P2para.Text: shall not be enforceable by proceedings for specific performance of a statutory duty under section 45(b) of the Court of Session Act 1988 (c. 36).
Without prejudice to the rights of any other person, the duties imposed by virtue of

Text.Substitution: an order under section 265(3) of this Act, or
an order under section 269(3) of this Act,

P2para.Text: shall be enforceable by proceedings by the Commission for specific performance of a statutory duty under section 45(b) of that Act of 1988.

P1group.Title: Interpretation of Chapter

P2para.Text: In this Chapter

Para.Text: relevant Health Board means, in relation to a patient of such description as may be specified in regulations, the Health Board, or Special Health Board
of such description as may be so specified; or
determined under such regulations; and

Text.Substitution: means a patient whose detention in hospital is authorised by
if the patient is also subject to a restriction order, a compulsion order,
a hospital direction, or
a transfer for treatment direction.

Text.Addition: In this Chapter, a reference to a hospital may be read as a reference to a hospital unit.
For the purposes of this Chapter,
means any part of a hospital which is treated as a separate unit.

P1group.Title: Code of practice

P2para.Text: The Scottish Ministers shall, in accordance with this section, draw up, give effect to and publish a code of practice giving guidance to any person discharging functions by virtue of this Actor Part VI (mental disorder) of the 1995 Act as to

P3para.Text: the discharge of such of those functions; and
such matters arising in connection with the discharge of those functions,

P2para.Text: as they think fit.
The Scottish Ministers shall, before giving effect to a code of practice drawn up under subsection (1) above

P3para.Text: consult such persons as they think fit; and
lay a draft of the code before the Scottish Parliament.

P2para.Text: A code of practice drawn up under subsection (1) above shall be given effect by being

P3para.Text: confirmed by order made; and
brought into force on a day appointed,

P2para.Text: by the Scottish Ministers.

Any person discharging functions by virtue of this Actor Part VI (mental disorder) of the 1995 Act shall have regard (so far as they are applicable to the discharge of those functions by that person) to the provisions of any code of practice published under subsection (1) above for the time being in force.
The references in subsections (1) and (4) above to a person discharging functions by virtue of this Actor Part VI (mental disorder) of the 1995 Act do not include references to

P3para.Text: any court;

Text.Addition: a prosecutor;

P3para.Text: the Tribunal; and
the Commission.

P2para.Text: The Scottish Ministers may, from time to time, revise the whole or part of any code of practice published under subsection (1) above; and if a code is so revised, the Scottish Ministers shall publish the revised code.
Subsections (2) to (6) above apply to a code of practice revised under subsection (6) above as they apply to a code of practice published under subsection (1) above.

P1group.Title: Advance statements: making and withdrawal

P2para.Text: An advance statement is a statement complying with subsection (2) below and specifying

P3para.Text: the ways the person making it wishes to be treated for mental disorder;
the ways the person wishes not to be so treated,

P2para.Text: in the event of the persons becoming mentally disordered and the persons ability to make decisions about the matters referred to in paragraphs (a) and (b) above being, because of that, significantly impaired.
An advance statement complies with this subsection if

P3para.Text: at the time of making it, the person has the capacity of properly intending the wishes specified in it;
it is in writing;
it is subscribed by the person making it;

that persons subscription of it is witnessed by a person (the witness) who is within the class of persons prescribed by regulations for the purposes of this paragraph and who signs the statement as a witness to that subscription; and
the witness certifies in writing on the document which comprises the statement that, in the witnesss opinion, the person making the statement has the capacity referred to in paragraph (a) above.

P2para.Text: An advance statement may be withdrawn by the person who made it by a withdrawal complying with this subsection; and a withdrawal so complies if

P3para.Text: at the time of making it the person has the capacity properly to intend to withdraw the statement; and
it is made by means of a document which, were it an advance statement, would comply with paragraphs (b) to (e) of subsection (2) above.

P1group.Title: Advance statements: effect

P2para.Text: If the Tribunal is satisfied as to the matters set out in subsection (2) below, it shall, in making any decision in respect of a patient who is a person who has made and not withdrawn an advance statement, have regard to the wishes specified in the statement.
Those matters are

P3para.Text: that, because of mental disorder, the ability of the person who made the advance statement to make decisions about the matters referred to in paragraphs (a) and (b) of subsection (1) of section 275 of this Act is significantly impaired;
that the statement complies with subsection (2) of that section;

that any measures or treatment which might or will be authorised by virtue of the decision referred to in subsection (1) above or might or will, by virtue of that decision, no longer be authorised correspond to any wishes specified in the statement; and

that, since the person made the statement, there has been no change of circumstances which, were the person to have been considering making the statement at the time the Tribunal is making the decision referred to in subsection (1) above, would have been likely to cause the person not to make the statement or to make a substantially different one.

P2para.Text: A person giving medical treatment authorised by virtue of this Act or the 1995 Act to a patient who is a person

P3para.Text: who has made and not withdrawn an advance statement; and
whose ability to make decisions about the matters referred to in paragraphs (a) and (b) of subsection (1) of section 275 of this Act is, because of mental disorder, significantly impaired,

P2para.Text: shall have regard to the wishes specified in the advance statement.

Before making a decision under section 236(2)(c), 239(1)(c) or 241(1)(c) of this Act in relation to a patient who is a person who has made and not withdrawn an advance statement, a designated medical practitioner shall have regard to the wishes specified in the statement.

For the purposes of subsections (1) and (2) above and (in the case where medical treatment is to or might be given to a patient otherwise than by virtue of any such decision as is referred to in subsection (1) above or is to be given to the patient by virtue of such a decision which was made in ignorance of the existence or the withdrawal of an advance statement) of subsections (3) and (4) above

P3para.Text: an advance statement shall be taken to comply with subsection (2) of section 275 of this Act; and
a withdrawal of an advance statement shall be taken to comply with subsection (3) of that section,

P2para.Text: unless the contrary appears.
For the purposes of subsections (3) and (4) above in the case where the medical treatment is authorised by virtue of a decision such as is referred to in subsection (1) above

P3para.Text: an advance statement shall be taken to comply with subsection (2) of section 275 of this Act; and
a withdrawal of an advance statement shall be taken to comply with subsection (3) of that section,

P2para.Text: if the Tribunal was satisfied when making the decision that the statement or, as the case may be, the withdrawal so complies.
If, in respect of a patient who is a person who has made and not withdrawn an advance statement

P3para.Text: the Tribunal makes such a decision as is referred to in subsection (1) above authorising measures which conflict with the wishes specified in the statement;
a person having functions under this Act gives medical treatment authorised by virtue of this Act or the 1995 Act to the person and that treatment conflicts with those wishes;
a designated medical practitioner makes such a decision as is referred to in subsection (4) above and it conflicts with those wishes; or

such measures, treatment or decision which could have been so authorised, given or, as the case may be, made are not so authorised or is not so given or made, with the consequence that there is a conflict with those wishes,

P2para.Text: then the Tribunal, person having those functions or, as the case may be, designated medical practitioner shall comply with the requirements set out in subsection (8) below.
Those requirements are

P3para.Text: recording in writing the circumstances in which those measures were or treatment or decision was authorised, given or made or, as the case may be, not authorised, given or made, and the reasons why;
supplying

P4para.Text: the person who made the statement;
that persons named person;
that persons welfare attorney;
that persons guardian; and
the Commission,

P3para.Text: with a copy of that record; and
placing a copy of that record with that persons medical records.

Title.Addition: Advance statements to be put with medical records

Text.Addition: Subsection (2) below applies where a Health Board receives a copy of an advance statement, or a copy of a document withdrawing an advance statement, from
the person who made the statement, or
any individual acting with the person's authority in relation to the statement.
The Health Board must
place a copy of the statement or document with the person's medical records, and
inform the Commission
that a copy of the statement or document is held with the person's medical records, and
of the premises at which the medical records are kept (and the personal and administrative details essential for identifying the records as the person's).

Title.Addition: Advance statements to be registered by the Commission

Text.Addition: Where the Commission receives information by virtue of section 276A(2) of this Act, the Commission must enter the information in a register of advance statements maintained by it (and mark the date on which the entry is made).
The Commission must allow an entry in the register to be inspected at a reasonable time
by the person whose medical records are referred to in the entry,
with respect to treatment of the person for mental disorder, by any individual acting on the person's behalf,
for the purpose of making decisions or taking steps with respect to the treatment of the person for a mental disorder, by
a mental health officer dealing with the person's case,
