the person's responsible medical officer,
the Health Board responsible for the person's treatment.

Title.Addition: Publicising support for making advance statements

Text.Addition: A Health Board is to publicise any support that it offers for
making or withdrawing an advance statement,
sending a copy of an advance statement, or a copy of a document withdrawing an advance statement, to a Health Board.
A Health Board must give the Commission such information as the Commission may from time to time seek on what the Health Board is doing in order to comply with subsection (1) above.

P1group.Title: Education of persons who have mental disorder

P2para.Text: The Education (Scotland) Act 1980 (c. 44) shall be amended as follows.

In section 14(1)
(education for children unable to attend school by reason of extraordinary circumstances or prolonged ill-health), in paragraph (b) after ill-health there is inserted or a pupils being subject to any measures authorised by virtue of the Mental Health (Care and Treatment)
(Scotland) Act 2003 (asp 13) or authorised, in consequence of the pupils mental disorder, by virtue of the Criminal Procedure (Scotland) Act 1995 (c. 46) .

In section 131(2)
(persons to whom duties and powers under the Act do not extend), in paragraph (a) after court there is inserted (other than an order so made under the Mental Health (Care and Treatment)
(Scotland) Act 2003 (asp 13)) .

P1group.Title: Duty to mitigate adverse effect of compulsory measures on parental relations

P2para.Text: Subsection (2) below applies

P3para.Text: where

P4para.Text: a child is subject to any measures authorised by virtue of this Act or authorised, in consequence of the childs mental disorder, by virtue of the 1995 Act; and
the measures will or will be likely to impair the personal relations or diminish direct contact between the child and any person with parental responsibilities in relation to the child; or

P3para.Text: where

P4para.Text: a person with parental responsibilities in relation to a child is subject to any measures authorised by virtue of this Act or authorised, in consequence of the persons mental disorder, by virtue of the 1995 Act; and
the measures will or will be likely to impair the personal relations or diminish direct contact between that person and the child.

P2para.Text: Every person having functions by virtue of this Act which include responsibility for the administration of any of the measures mentioned in subsection (1) above shall take such steps as are practicable and appropriate to mitigate the impairment or diminution referred to in that subsection or, as the case may be, the likelihood of that impairment or diminution.
In this section, child and parental responsibilities have the same meanings as they have in Part I of the Children (Scotland) Act 1995 (c. 36).

P1group.Title: Information for research

P2para.Text: A person having functions by virtue of this Act shall, on being required to do so by the Scottish Ministers

P3para.Text: provide them or any other person specified in the requirement with such relevant information as is so specified; and
do so in any such form as may be so specified.

P2para.Text: The Scottish Ministers may, under subsection (1) above, require the provision of relevant information only if, in their opinion, it is needed by them (or, as the case may be, the other person specified in the requirement) for purposes mentioned in Article 84A of the UK GDPR (research, archives and statistics).

Information need not be provided under this section if, were it evidence which might be given in proceedings in any court in Scotland, the person having that evidence could not be compelled to give it in such proceedings.
Where information required under subsection (1) above

P3para.Text: is, or refers to, information about a natural person and would identify or enable the identification of the person; and
can reasonably be provided under subsection (1) above so as not to identify or enable the identification of the person,

P2para.Text: it shall be so provided.
Where

P3para.Text: the person required under subsection (1) above to provide the information is under a duty of confidentiality in respect of that information; and
the person cannot provide the information without breaching the duty,

P2para.Text: the information shall not be provided unless the person to whom the duty is owed has consented to its provision.

On receipt of information provided under this section, the Scottish Ministers (or any other person provided under this section with the information) may, for the purposes referred to in subsection (2) above, do any, or all, of the following

P3para.Text: process the information;
collate it;
publish it or reports based on it.

P2para.Text: Regulations may provide as to the procedure to be followed in making requirements under this section for information and in providing it.
Where information recorded otherwise than in legible form is required to be provided under this section, it shall be provided in legible form.
For the purposes of this section

P3para.Text: information is relevant if it is information as to the operation of this Act; and

a person is under a duty of confidentiality in respect of information although the person could notwithstanding that duty be compelled to give evidence as to that information in proceedings in a court in Scotland.

Text.Substitution: In this section,
has the meaning given in section 3(10) of the Data Protection Act 2018.

P1group.Title: Restriction of Scottish Ministers' power to delegate management of state hospitals

P1para.Text: In section 102 of the National Health Service (Scotland) Act 1978 (c. 29) (provision and management of state hospitals)

P3para.Text: in subsection (4), paragraph (a) and the word or immediately following it; and
subsection (5),

P1para.Text: shall cease to have effect.

P1group.Title: Correspondence of certain persons detained in hospital

P2para.Text: A postal packet which is

P3para.Text: addressed to any person by a specified person; and
delivered by the specified person for dispatch,

P2para.Text: may, where subsection (2) or (3) below applies, be withheld from the relevant carrier by the managers of the hospital in which the specified person is detained.
This subsection applies if the person in question has requested that communications addressed to such person by the specified person should be withheld.
This subsection applies if

P3para.Text: the postal packet is not addressed to a person mentioned in subsection (5) below; and
the managers of the hospital consider that the postal packet is likely

P4para.Text: to cause distress to the person in question or any other person who is not on the staff of the hospital; or
to cause danger to any person.

P2para.Text: Any request for the purposes of subsection (2) above shall be made in writing to

P3para.Text: the managers of the hospital concerned;
the responsible medical officer; or
the Scottish Ministers.

P2para.Text: The persons referred to in subsection (3)(a) above are

P3para.Text: any Minister of the Crown or the Scottish Ministers;
any member of either House of Parliament or member of the Scottish Parliament, National Assembly for Wales or Northern Ireland Assembly;
any member of the European Parliament elected for the United Kingdom;
the Commission or any of its members;
the Parliamentary Commissioner for Administration;
the Scottish Public Services Ombudsman;
a local authority;
any judge or clerk of court;
the Tribunal;
the managers of the hospital in which the specified person is detained;
a Health Board;
a Special Health Board;

Text.Addition: Healthcare Improvement Scotland;

P3para.Text: a National Health Service trust;

any person who, to the knowledge of the managers of the hospital in which the specified person is detained, is providing independent advocacy services to the specified person under section 259 of this Act;
any legally qualified person instructed by the specified person to act as the specified persons legal adviser;
the European Court of Human Rights; and
such other persons as may be specified in regulations.

P2para.Text: A postal packet which

P3para.Text: is addressed to a specified person; and
is not sent by or on behalf of any person mentioned in subsection (5) above,

P2para.Text: may be withheld from the specified person by the managers of the hospital in which the specified person is detained if, in their opinion, it is necessary to do so in the interests of the health or safety of the specified person or for the protection of any other person.
The managers of a hospital may inspect and open any postal packet for the purposes of determining

P3para.Text: whether it is a postal packet to which subsection (1) or (6) above applies; and
if it is, whether it should be withheld under the subsection in question.

P2para.Text: The power to withhold a postal packet under subsection (1) or (6) above includes power to withhold anything contained in such packet.
In this section

Para.Text: postal packet has the meaning given by section 125 of the Postal Services Act 2000 (c. 26);
relevant carrier means
the postal operator (as defined in that section of that Act); or
the person other than a person mentioned in paragraph (a) above,
who is to receive or collect the postal packet for the purpose of its being conveyed and delivered; and
specified person means a person who
is detained in a hospital; and
meets such other conditions, or in relation to whom such other conditions are met, as may be specified in regulations.

P1group.Title: Correspondence: supplementary

P2para.Text: If a postal packet or anything contained in it is withheld under subsection (1) or (6) of section 281 of this Act, the managers of the hospital shall record that fact in writing.
If a postal packet or anything contained in it is withheld under

P3para.Text: subsection (1) of section 281 of this Act by virtue of subsection (3) of that section; or
subsection (6) of that section,

P2para.Text: the managers of the hospital shall, before the expiry of the period of 7 days beginning with the withholding of the packet or anything contained in it, give notice to the Commission of the matters mentioned in subsection (3) below.
Those matters are

P3para.Text: the name of the specified person;
the nature of the postal packet or contents withheld; and
the reason for withholding the postal packet or contents.

P2para.Text: If a postal packet or anything contained in it is withheld under

P3para.Text: subsection (1) of section 281 of this Act by virtue of subsection (3) of that section; or
subsection (6) of that section,

P2para.Text: the managers of the hospital shall, before the expiry of the period of 7 days beginning with the withholding of the packet or anything contained in it, give notice to the persons mentioned in subsection (5) below of the fact that the postal packet or anything contained in it has been withheld and the effect of section 283 of this Act.
Those persons are

P3para.Text: the specified person; and
in a case where the packet is withheld as mentioned in paragraph (b) of subsection (4) above, the person by whom the packet was sent (if known).

P2para.Text: The functions under section 281 of this Act and this section of the managers of a hospital shall be discharged on their behalf by a person on the staff of the hospital appointed by them for that purpose; and different persons may be so appointed to discharge different functions.
Regulations may

P3para.Text: make provision with respect to the exercise of the powers conferred by section 281 of this Act;

make provision for that section and this section to apply as if references to postal packets included references to written communications by the means specified in the regulations, with such modifications as may be so specified.

P2para.Text: In this section

Para.Text: postal packet has the same meaning as in section 281 of this Act; and
specified person has the same meaning as in that section.

P1group.Title: Review of decision to withhold postal packet

P2para.Text: This section applies where a relevant item is withheld under

P3para.Text: subsection (1) of section 281 of this Act by virtue of subsection (3) of that section; or
subsection (6) of that section.

P2para.Text: On an application

P3para.Text: in the case where a relevant item is withheld as mentioned in paragraph (a) of subsection (1) above, by the specified person; or
in the case where a relevant item is withheld as mentioned in paragraph (b) of that subsection, by

P4para.Text: the specified person; or
the person by whom the postal packet was sent,

P3para.Text: the Commission shall review the decision to withhold the relevant item.

P2para.Text: Any application under subsection (2) above shall be made before the expiry of the period of 6 months beginning with the day on which the person making the application receives notice under section 282(4) of this Act.
On an application under subsection (2) above the Commission may direct that the relevant item should not be withheld; and the managers of the hospital concerned shall comply with any such direction.
Regulations may make provision with respect to the making of applications under subsection (2) above.
Regulations under subsection (5) above may in particular make provision as to the production to the Commission of relevant items.
In this section

Para.Text: postal packet has the same meaning as in section 281 of this Act;
relevant item means a postal packet or anything contained in it; and
specified person has the same meaning as in that section.

P1group.Title: Certain persons detained in hospital: use of telephones

P2para.Text: Regulations may make provision for or in connection with regulating the use of telephones by such persons detained in hospital as may be specified in the regulations (specified persons).
Provision under subsection (1) above may in particular

P3para.Text: confer rights on specified persons to use telephones;
make the entitlement to, or exercise of, any such rights subject to conditions imposed by or under regulations;
restrict, or prohibit, the use of telephones by specified persons;
authorise the managers of a hospital to intercept, or arrange for the interception of, telephone calls

P4para.Text: to specified persons; or
made by specified persons;

P3para.Text: require the managers of a hospital to make, and maintain, records of such matters as may be specified in the regulations;
require the managers of a hospital to inform persons specified in the regulations of matters so specified;
confer power on the Commission to give to the managers of a hospital directions as to matters of any description specified in the regulations;
require the managers of a hospital to comply with any directions given to them by virtue of paragraph (g) above.

P2para.Text: The conditions mentioned in subsection (2)(b) above include in particular conditions as to payment of call charges for calls made by or on behalf of specified persons.
Regulations under this section may not authorise the interception of a telephone call made by a specified person to a person mentioned in subsection (6) below unless

P3para.Text: the person has requested the interception of telephone calls made by the specified person to the person; or
the telephone call is or would be unlawful for any reason other than one arising from provision made by virtue of this section.

P2para.Text: Regulations under this section may not authorise the interception of a telephone call made to a specified person by a person mentioned in subsection (6) below unless the telephone call is or would be unlawful for any reason other than one arising from provision made by virtue of this section.
The persons referred to in subsections (4) and (5) above are

P3para.Text: any of the persons mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (i), (k) to (n) and (p) of section 281(5) of this Act;
the managers of the hospital in which the specified person is detained;
a legally qualified person instructed by the specified person to act as the specified persons legal adviser; and
such other person as may be specified by the regulations.

P2para.Text: In this section intercept, in relation to a telephone call, includes

P3para.Text: listen to, record or otherwise monitor; and
interrupt, cut short, divert or prevent from being connected.

P2para.Text: For the purposes of this section, a telephone call is made when the telephone number of the person being called has been dialled.

P1group.Title: Directions as to implementation of regulations under section 284(1)

P2para.Text: The Scottish Ministers may give to the managers of a hospital directions as to the implementation by those managers of regulations made under section 284(1) of this Act; and the managers shall comply with any such directions.

The Scottish Ministers may require the managers of a hospital to provide them with a statement setting out such information as respects the implementation of the regulations by those managers as the Scottish Ministers may specify.

P1group.Title: Safety and security in hospitals

P2para.Text: Regulations may authorise

P3para.Text: the search of such persons detained in hospital by virtue of this Act or the 1995 Act as may be specified in the regulations and of anything they have with them in the hospital in which they are detained;

the taking, from external parts of the body of those persons and, by means of swabbing, from the mouth of those persons, of samples of body tissue, blood or other body fluid or other material, the taking hypodermically from those persons of samples of blood and the examination of those samples;

the placing of restrictions on the kinds of things which those persons may have with them in the hospitals in which they are detained and the removal from them of articles kept in breach of such restrictions;

the placing of prohibitions and restrictions on the entry into and the conduct while in those hospitals of persons (visitors) visiting those persons or otherwise entering or seeking to enter those hospitals and on the kinds of things which visitors may bring with them into those hospitals;
the surveillance, whether directly or otherwise, of those persons and visitors;
the search of visitors and of anything they bring with them into those hospitals,

P2para.Text: and make that which is authorised subject to conditions specified in the regulations.
Regulations may require the managers of each hospital of such class as is or classes as are specified to provide

P3para.Text: the Scottish Ministers, on their request, with a statement describing how regulations made under subsection (1) above

P4para.Text: have been implemented in that hospital during the period the Ministers specify in their request;
are being implemented there at the time of the request;
are proposed by those managers to be implemented there after that time;

P3para.Text: the Commission with statements of the incidence and circumstances of the implementation there of regulations under subsection (1) above in such ways as are specified.

P2para.Text: Regulations may confer power on the Commission, by direction

P3para.Text: to prohibit the implementation of regulations under subsection (1) above in relation to a specified patient in a specified way;
to require the managers of a hospital in which a specified patient is detained to notify a specified person that such a regulation has been implemented in relation to such a patient in such a way.

P2para.Text: In each of subsections (2) and (3) above, specified means specified in the regulations made under that subsection.

The Scottish Ministers may give to the managers of a hospital directions as to the implementation by those managers of regulations made under subsection (1) above; and the managers shall comply with any such directions.
Before making regulations under this section the Scottish Ministers shall consult such persons as they consider appropriate.

P1group.Title: Scottish Ministers' power to require responsible medical officer to provide certain information

P1para.Text: The Scottish Ministers may, for the purposes of the discharge of their functions under

P3para.Text: Part 10, 11 or 13 of this Act; or
section 52F, 52L or 52P of the 1995 Act,

P1para.Text: in relation to a patient who has a responsible medical officer, require the patients responsible medical officer to provide them with such information as they may specify.

P1group.Title: Payments to persons in hospital to meet personal expenses

P2para.Text: Where subsections (2) and (3) below apply in relation to a person, the Scottish Ministers may pay to the person such amounts as they consider appropriate in respect of the persons occasional personal expenses.
This subsection applies where the person

P3para.Text: has a mental disorder;
has been admitted to a hospital; and
is being given treatment there primarily for mental disorder.

P2para.Text: This subsection applies where it appears to the Scottish Ministers that the person would not otherwise have resources to meet the expenses in question.

For the purposes of the National Health Service (Scotland) Act 1978 (c. 29), the making of payments under this section to persons for whom services are provided under that Act shall be treated as included among those services.
In subsection (2) above, hospital means

P3para.Text: any health service hospital (as defined in section 108(1) of the National Health Service (Scotland) Act 1978 (c. 29)); or
any state hospital.

P1group.Title: Cross-border transfer: patients subject to requirement other than detention

P2para.Text: Regulations may make provision for or in connection with

Text.Addition: the removal of a patient subject to a relevant requirement from Scotland to a place outwith Scotland (whether or not a place in the United Kingdom).
the reception in Scotland of
a person subject to corresponding requirements in England, Wales, Northern Ireland, the Isle of Man or the Channel Islands and removed from there.
a person subject to corresponding requirements in a member State of the European Union (apart from the United Kingdom) and removed from that State.

P2para.Text: Where provision is made by regulations under paragraph (a) of subsection (1) above, the regulations shall

P3para.Text: require a patients removal to be authorised by warrant issued by the patients responsible medical officer;
provide that a responsible medical officer may give that authority only

P4para.Text: where the patient has notified the responsible medical officer of the patients wish to be so removed; or

where, in the case where the patient is not capable of giving that notification, the patients named person has notified the responsible medical officer that that person considers that it is in the patients best interests to be so removed;

P3para.Text: provide that the responsible medical officer may give that authority only if satisfied that there are in existence, in the place to which the patient is to go after being so removed, arrangements which will secure for the patient measures, treatment, care or services corresponding or similar to those which the patient is subject to or is receiving by virtue of this Act or, as the case may be, the 1995 Act;
require a patients responsible medical officer, before making a decision whether to authorise the removal of the patient, to notify

P4para.Text: except where notification referred to in paragraph (b) above has been given by the patients named person, that person;
the mental health officer; and
the Commission,

P3para.Text: of the circumstances of the case; and
authorise a patients responsible medical officer to give directions in connection with the removal of the patient.

Text.Addition: Where provision is made by regulations under paragraph (a) of subsection (1) above, the regulations may make provision for exceptions to provisions included in them by virtue of subsection (2)(d).
Where provision is made by regulations under paragraph (b) of subsection (1) above, the regulations shall provide for the reception of persons to take place only if
the managers of a hospital consent to the reception; and
those managers undertake to appoint an approved medical practitioner to be the person's responsible medical officer.
Regulations under subsection (1) above may in particular
make provision for things done under the law of a territory other than Scotland to be treated as things done under provisions of the law of Scotland,
confer powers and immunities on persons engaged in
escorting persons being moved under the regulations;
pursuing persons who have absconded while being so moved;
restraining persons who have absconded, or attempt to abscond, while being so moved;

P3para.Text: make provision amending provisions of this Act (other than this section) or any other enactment, or providing for any such provision or enactment to have effect with modification.

Text.Addition: without prejudice to the generality of the powers conferred by subsection (1) above.

P2para.Text: References in this section to

P3para.Text: a relevant requirement are, as respects a patient, references to a requirement imposed in relation to the patient under section 66(1) of this Act or section 57A(8) of the 1995 Act, not being detention in a hospital;
a patient subject to a relevant requirement include references to a patient in respect of whom section 128(1) (either as enacted or as applied by section 179 of this Act) is in operation.

Text.Addition: For the purposes of subsection (1)(b) above, a person is subject to corresponding requirements in a territory if under the law of that territory the person is subject to measures corresponding or similar to a requirement imposed in relation to a person under section 66(1) of this Act or section 57A(8) of the 1995 Act, not being detention in a hospital.

P1group.Title: Cross-border transfer: patients subject to detention requirement or otherwise in hospital

P2para.Text: Regulations may make provision for or in connection with

P3para.Text: the removal, of a patient whose detention in hospital is authorised by virtue of this Act or the 1995 Act, from Scotland to a place outwith Scotland (whether or not a place in the United Kingdom);

the removal, of a patient who for the purposes of being given treatment for mental disorder is in hospital otherwise than by virtue of this Act or the 1995 Act, from Scotland to a place outwith the United Kingdom;
the reception in Scotland of

P4para.Text: a person subject to corresponding measures in England, Wales, Northern Ireland, the Isle of Man or the Channel Islands and removed from there.

Text.Addition: a person subject to corresponding measures in a member State of the European Union (apart from the United Kingdom) and removed from that State.

P2para.Text: Where provision is made by regulations under paragraph (a) or (b) of subsection (1) above, the regulations shall

P3para.Text: require a patients removal from Scotland to be authorised by warrant issued by the Scottish Ministers;

require that, among the factors to which the Scottish Ministers have regard in deciding whether to authorise that removal, there are included, as well as the best interests of the patient, the following

P4para.Text: the existence, in the place to which a patient is to go after being removed from Scotland, of arrangements which will secure for the patient , in the case of paragraph (a) of subsection (1) above, measures, treatment, care or services corresponding or similar to those to which the patient is subject or is receiving by virtue of this Act or, as the case may be, the 1995 Act or, in the case of paragraph (b) of subsection (1) above, treatment for mental disorder corresponding or similar to that which the patient is receiving in hospital;
any wish or preference as to the patients removal from Scotland of which the patient has given notice to the Scottish Ministers; and
any risk to the safety of any person;

P3para.Text: require notice to be given to

P4para.Text: the patient;
the patients named person;
the mental health officer; and
the Commission,

P3para.Text: of any decision that the patient be removed from Scotland under the regulations;
require any such giving of notice to be effected, in a case where removal is to a place in the United Kingdom, at least 7 days before the date proposed for the patients removal;
require any such giving of notice to be effected, in a case where removal is to a place outwith the United Kingdom, at least 28 days before the date proposed for the patients removal;

Text.Addition: enable an appeal against any such decision to be made by
such a patient,
the named person of such a patient,
if such a patient has no named person
any guardian of such a patient,
any welfare attorney of such a patient,
the primary carer (if any) of such a patient,
the nearest relative of such a patient;

P3para.Text: provide for such a patients removal not to take place until proceedings on any such appeal have been concluded.

P2para.Text: Where provision is made by regulations under paragraph (a) or (b) of subsection (1) above, the regulations may make provision for exceptions to provisions included in them by virtue of subsection (2)(c), (d), (e) or (g) above.

Where provision is made by regulations under paragraph (c) of subsection (1) above, the regulations shall provide for the reception of patients in Scotland to take place only with the consent of the Scottish Ministers.
Regulations under subsection (1) above may in particular

P3para.Text: make provision for things done under the law of a territory other than Scotland to be treated as things done under provisions of the law of Scotland;
confer powers and immunities on persons engaged in

P4para.Text: escorting persons being moved under the regulations;
pursuing persons who have absconded while being so moved;
restraining persons who have absconded, or attempt to abscond, while being so moved;

P3para.Text: authorise the Scottish Ministers to arrange for any of their functions under the regulations to be exercised by other persons;
authorise the Scottish Ministers to give directions in connection with removals of persons under the regulations or any particular such removal or removals;
make provision amending provisions of this Act (other than this section) or any other enactment, or providing for any such provision or enactment to have effect with modification.

P2para.Text: Subsections (2) to (5) above are without prejudice to the generality of the powers conferred by subsection (1) above.
References in this section to a patient whose detention in hospital is authorised by virtue of this Act or the 1995 Act include references to a patient

P3para.Text: in respect of whom a certificate under section 41(1), 53(1), 127(1) or (3) (either as enacted or as applied by section 179 of this Act), 221(2) or 224(2) of this Act is in operation; or
who has been conditionally discharged under section 193(7) of this Act and not recalled under section 202 of this Act.

P2para.Text: For the purposes of paragraph (c) of subsection (1) above, a person is subject to corresponding measures in a territory if under the law of that territory the person

P3para.Text: is subject to measures corresponding or similar to detention in hospital authorised by virtue of this Act or the 1995 Act; or
has a status corresponding or similar to that of a patient such as is mentioned in paragraph (b) of that subsection.

P1group.Title: Application to Tribunal in relation to unlawful detention

P2para.Text: This section applies where, otherwise than by virtue of this Act or the 1995 Act, a person (the patient)

P3para.Text: has been admitted to a hospital; and
is being given treatment there primarily for mental disorder.

P2para.Text: A person mentioned in subsection (4) below may apply to the Tribunal for an order requiring the managers of the hospital to cease to detain the patient.
On an application under subsection (2) above the Tribunal shall

P3para.Text: if satisfied that the patient is being unlawfully detained in the hospital, make the order mentioned in subsection (2) above; or
if not satisfied about the matter mentioned in paragraph (a) above, refuse the application.

P2para.Text: The persons referred to in subsection (2) above are

P3para.Text: the patient;
the patients named person;
if the patient is a child, any person who has parental responsibilities in relation to the patient;
a mental health officer;
the Commission;
any guardian of the patient;
any welfare attorney of the patient; and
any other person having an interest in the welfare of the patient.

P2para.Text: Subsection (2) above is without prejudice to any right that a person has by virtue of any enactment or rule of law.
In subsection (4)(c) above, child and parental responsibilities have the same meanings as they have in Part I of the Children (Scotland) Act 1995 (c. 36).

Emphasis.Addition: Conflicts of interest to be avoided

Title.Addition: Conflicts of interest to be avoided

Text.Addition: There must not be a conflict of interest in relation to a medical examination to be carried out for the purpose of section 36(1), 44(1), 47(1), 57(2), 77(2), 78(2), 139(2), 140(2) or 182(2) of this Act.
Regulations may
specify circumstances in which, in the application of subsection (1) above
there is to be taken to be a conflict of interest,
there is not to be taken to be a conflict of interest,
specify circumstances in which subsection (1) above does not apply.

P1group.Title: Warrant to enter premises for purposes of taking patient

P2para.Text: If a sheriff or a justice of the peace is satisfied by an authorised persons evidence on oath as to the matters mentioned in subsection (2) below, the sheriff or, as the case may be, justice of the peace may grant a warrant under this subsection.
Those matters are

P3para.Text: that for the purposes for which the authorised person is authorised it is necessary to enter premises; and
that the authorised person

P4para.Text: is unable to obtain entry to those premises; or
reasonably apprehends that the authorised person will be unable to obtain entry to those premises.

P2para.Text: A warrant under subsection (1) above is a warrant

P3para.Text: authorising

P4para.Text: the authorised person;
any mental health officer appointed by the local authority for the area in which the premises are situated; and

Text.Substitution: any constable of the Police Service of Scotland,

P3para.Text: to enter the premises specified in the warrant; and
authorising any constable of the Police Service of Scotland, for the purpose of exercising the power mentioned in paragraph (a) above, to open lockfast places on premises so specified.

P2para.Text: In the execution of a warrant granted under subsection (1) above, the persons authorised for the purpose of subsection (3)(a) above may be accompanied by

P3para.Text: a medical practitioner;
any other authorised person.

P2para.Text: In this section, references to an authorised person are to a person who, in relation to a patient, is authorised by virtue of this Act

P3para.Text: to take the patient to any place; or
to take (or retake) into custody the patient where the patient is liable to be taken (or retaken).

P1group.Title: Removal order

P2para.Text: If, on the application of a relevant mental health officer, a sheriff is satisfied that

P3para.Text: a person who is aged 16 years or over has a mental disorder;
any of the circumstances mentioned in subsection (2) below apply in respect of that person; and
that person is likely to suffer significant harm if not removed to a place of safety,

P2para.Text: the sheriff may make an order under this section (any such order being referred to in this Act as a removal order) in respect of that person.
The circumstances referred to in subsection (1)(b) above are

P3para.Text: that the person is subject, or exposed, to

P4para.Text: ill-treatment;
neglect; or
some other deficiency in care or treatment;

P3para.Text: that, because of the mental disorder, the persons property

P4para.Text: is suffering loss or damage; or
is at risk of suffering loss or damage; and

P3para.Text: that the person is

P4para.Text: living alone or without care; and
unable to look after himself or his property or financial affairs.

P2para.Text: A removal order is an order

P3para.Text: authorising

P4para.Text: the mental health officer specified in the order;
any other persons so specified; and

Text.Substitution: any constable of the Police Service of Scotland,

P3para.Text: before the expiry of the period of 72 hours beginning with the granting of the order, to enter any premises so specified;
authorising any such constable, before the expiry of that period, for the purpose of exercising the power mentioned in paragraph (a) above, to open lockfast places on premises so specified; and
authorising

P4para.Text: before the expiry of that period, the removal of the person who is the subject of the removal order to a place of safety specified in the order; and
the detention of that person in that place for such period, not exceeding 7 days, as may be specified in the order.

P2para.Text: An application for a removal order shall be made to the sheriff of the sheriffdom in which the premises to which the application relates are situated.
Before determining an application for a removal order, the sheriff shall, subject to subsection (7) below, afford the persons mentioned in subsection (6) below the opportunity

P3para.Text: of making representations (whether orally or in writing); and
of leading, or producing, evidence.

P2para.Text: Those persons are

P3para.Text: the person who is the subject of the application; and
such other persons as may be prescribed by regulations.

P2para.Text: If the sheriff considers that such delay as would result from compliance with the requirements of subsection (5) above would be likely to be prejudicial to the person who is the subject of the application, the sheriff may dispense with the requirements of that subsection.
In this section relevant mental health officer means a mental health officer appointed by the local authority for the area in which the premises to which the application relates are situated.

P1group.Title: Removal order: urgent application to justice of the peace

P1para.Text: Where

P3para.Text: the making of an application to the sheriff for a removal order is impracticable; and
the circumstances are such that any delay in obtaining a removal order is likely to be prejudicial to the person who would be the subject of the application,

P1para.Text: the application may be made instead to a justice of the peace for the commission area in which the premises to which the application relates are situated; and subsections (1) to (3) of section 293 of this Act shall apply in relation to an application made by virtue of this section as those subsections apply as respects an application to the sheriff.

P1group.Title: Recall or variation of removal order

P2para.Text: A person who is the subject of a removal order, or any person claiming an interest in the welfare of that person, may apply to the sheriff for an order under this section

P3para.Text: recalling the removal order; or
varying that order by

P4para.Text: specifying a different place of safety;
authorising, before the expiry of the period mentioned in subsection (2) below, the removal of the person who is the subject of the removal order to that place of safety; and

authorising the detention of the person who is the subject of the removal order in that place of safety for the remainder of such period as may have been specified, by virtue of section 293(3)(c)(ii) of this Act, in the removal order.

P2para.Text: The period referred to in subsection (1)(b)(ii) above is the period of 72 hours beginning with the granting of the order varying the removal order.
An application under section (1) above shall be made to the sheriff of the sheriffdom in which the premises to which the application for a removal order related are situated.
Before determining an application under subsection (1) above, the sheriff shall afford the persons mentioned in subsection (5) below the opportunity

P3para.Text: of making representations (whether orally or in writing); and
of leading, or producing, evidence.

P2para.Text: Those persons are

P3para.Text: the person who is the subject of the removal order to which the application relates; and
such persons as may be prescribed by regulations.

P2para.Text: Where a sheriff makes an order under this section recalling a removal order, the sheriff may, in addition, make such order as the sheriff thinks fit for the person who was the subject of the removal order

P3para.Text: to be returned to the premises from which that person was, by virtue of the removal order, removed; or
to be taken to some appropriate place chosen by that person.

Title.Addition: Notification of decision under section 293 or 295

Text.Addition: Subsection (2) below applies in relation to a decision of a sheriff or a justice of the peace under section 293 of this Act making, or refusing to make, a removal order.
As soon as practicable after the decision is made, the mental health officer who made the application for the removal order must notify the Commission of the decision.
Subsection (4) below applies in relation to a decision of a sheriff under section 295 of this Act making, or refusing to make, an order recalling or varying a removal order.
As soon as practicable after the decision is made, the mental health officer specified in the removal order must notify the Commission of
the decision, and
any additional order made under subsection (6) of section 295 of this Act.

P1group.Title: No appeal against decision under section 293 or 295

P1para.Text: No appeal shall be competent against

P3para.Text: a decision of a sheriff under

P4para.Text: section 293(1) of this Act making, or refusing to make, a removal order; or
section 295 of this Act making, or refusing to make, an order recalling or varying a removal order; or

P3para.Text: a decision of a justice of the peace under section 293(1) of this Act making, or refusing to make, a removal order.

P1group.Title: Removal from public place

P2para.Text: Where

P3para.Text: a constable reasonably suspects

P4para.Text: that a person (referred to in this section and in section 298 of this Act as a relevant person) who is in a public place has a mental disorder; and
that the relevant person is in immediate need of care or treatment; and

P3para.Text: the constable considers that it would be in the interests of the relevant person, or necessary for the protection of any other person, to remove the relevant person to a place of safety,

P2para.Text: the constable may remove the relevant person to a place of safety.
A relevant person removed to a place of safety under subsection (1) above may, for the purposes of enabling

P3para.Text: arrangements to be made for a medical practitioner to carry out a medical examination of the relevant person; and
the making of such arrangements as the medical practitioner considers necessary for the relevant persons care or treatment,

P2para.Text: be detained there for a period ending not later than 24 hours after the time at which the relevant person is removed from the public place by the constable.
If a relevant person absconds

P3para.Text: while being removed to a place of safety under subsection (1) above; or
from the place of safety,

P2para.Text: a constable may, at any time during the period mentioned in subsection (2) above, take the person into custody and remove the person to a place of safety.

In this section, public place means a place to which the public, or any section of the public, has, or is permitted to have, access (whether on payment or otherwise); and includes the common parts of a building containing two or more separate dwellings.

If no place of safety is immediately available, a constable may, under subsection (1) or (3) above, remove a relevant person to a police station; and in any such case, any reference in this section and in section 298 of this Act to a place of safety shall be construed as being a reference to a police station.

P1group.Title: Removal under section 297: further provision

P2para.Text: This section applies where a constable removes a relevant person to a place of safety under section 297 of this Act.
The constable shall

P3para.Text: as soon as reasonably practicable after removing a relevant person to a place of safety, ensure

P4para.Text: that the local authority in whose area the place of safety is situated are informed of the matters mentioned in subsection (3) below; and
subject to subsection (4) below, that the nearest relative of the relevant person is informed of those matters; and

P3para.Text: before the expiry of the period of 14 days beginning with the day on which the person is removed to the place of safety, ensure that the Commission is given notice of those matters.

P2para.Text: The matters are

P3para.Text: the name and address of the relevant person;
the date and time at which the relevant person was removed from the public place;
the circumstances giving rise to the removal of the relevant person to the place of safety;
the address of the place of safety;
if the relevant person is removed to a police station, the reason why the relevant person was removed there; and
any other matter prescribed by regulations.

P2para.Text: Where

P3para.Text: it is impracticable to ensure that the relevant persons nearest relative is informed of the matters mentioned in subsection (3) above; or
the nearest relative is so informed but the nearest relative does not reside with the relevant person,

P2para.Text: the constable shall, as soon as reasonably practicable after removing the relevant person to the place of safety, ensure that, where reasonably practicable, a person falling within subsection (5) below is informed of those matters.
A person falls within this subsection if

P3para.Text: the person

P4para.Text: resides with the relevant person; or
provides a care service or, independent health care service to the relevant person; or

P3para.Text: the person is an individual who, otherwise than

P4para.Text: by virtue of a contract of employment, or other contract, with any person; or
as a volunteer for a voluntary organisation,

P3para.Text: provides care for the relevant person.

P2para.Text: In this section

Para.Text: care service has the meaning given by section47(1) of the Public Services Reform (Scotland) Act 2010 (asp 8);

Text.Addition: independent health care service means any of the following
an independent hospital;
a private psychiatric hospital;
an independent clinic; or
an independent medical agency,
as each of those terms is defined in section 10F(2) of the National Health Service (Scotland) Act

Para.Text: nearest relative has the meaning given by section 254 of this Act; and
public place has the meaning given by section 297 of this Act.

P1group.Title: Nurses power to detain pending medical examination

P2para.Text: This section applies where

P3para.Text: by virtue of an order under section 227A(1) of the 1995 Act which includes

P4para.Text: by virtue of subsections (1) and (3)(a) of section 227R of that Act, a requirement that the patient submit to treatment as a resident patient in a hospital; or
by virtue of subsections (1) and (3)(b) of that section, a requirement that the patient submit to treatment as a non-resident patient at an institution or place specified in the order,

P3para.Text: a patient is in hospital and being given medical treatment; or
otherwise than by virtue of

P4para.Text: an order such as is mentioned in paragraph (a) above;
any other provision of the 1995 Act; or
this Act,

P3para.Text: a patient is in hospital and being given medical treatment.

P2para.Text: Where

P3para.Text: a nurse of such class as may be prescribed by regulations considers that it is likely that the conditions mentioned in subsection (3) below are met in respect of the patient; ...

P2para.Text: the patient may be detained in the hospital for a period not exceeding 3 hours (holding period) for the purpose of enabling the carrying out of a medical examination of the patient by a medical practitioner.
The conditions referred to in subsection (2)(a) above are

P3para.Text: that the patient has a mental disorder;
that it is necessary for the protection of

P4para.Text: the health, safety or welfare of the patient; or
the safety of any other person,

P3para.Text: that the patient be immediately restrained from leaving the hospital; and
that it is necessary for a medical examination of the patient to be carried out by a medical practitioner for the purpose of determining whether the granting of

P4para.Text: an emergency detention certificate; or
a short-term detention certificate,

P3para.Text: is warranted.

P2para.Text: Where the patient is detained under subsection (2) above the nurse shall, as soon as practicable after the holding period begins, take all reasonable steps to inform a mental health officer of the detention.
Where the patient is detained under subsection (2) above, the nurse shall, as soon as practicable after the holding period begins, record in writing

P3para.Text: the fact that the patient has been detained;
the time at which the holding period began; and
the nurses reasons for believing that it is likely that the conditions mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (c) of subsection (3) are met in respect of the patient.

P2para.Text: A record made under subsection (6) above shall, as soon as practicable after it is made, be delivered to the managers of the hospital in which the patient is detained by

P3para.Text: the nurse; or
a person authorised for the purpose by the nurse.

P2para.Text: Where the managers of a hospital receive a record by virtue of subsection (7) above, they shall, before the expiry of the period of 14 days beginning with the day on which they receive it, send a copy of it to the Commission.

Any subordinate legislation made under section 25 of the Mental Health (Scotland) Act 1984 (c. 36) (detention of patients already in hospital) shall, if in force immediately before the day on which this section comes into force, have effect on and after that day as if made under this section.

P1group.Title: Meaning of place of safety

P1para.Text: In this Part of this Act, place of safety means

P3para.Text: a hospital;
premises which are used for the purpose of providing a care home service (as defined in paragraph 2 of schedule 12 to the Public Services Reform (Scotland) Act 2010 (asp 8)); or
any other suitable place (other than a police station) the occupier of which is willing temporarily to receive mentally disordered persons.

P1group.Title: Absconding etc. by patients subject to compulsory treatment order

P2para.Text: A patient who is subject to a compulsory treatment order authorising detention in hospital and who

P3para.Text: absconds from

P4para.Text: any place where the patient is kept pending removal to hospital under the order; or
the hospital in which, under the order, the patient is being detained; or

P3para.Text: while being removed to hospital under the order or transferred under section 124 of this Act, absconds,

P2para.Text: is liable to be taken into custody and dealt with in accordance with section 303 of this Act.
A patient who is subject to such an order and in respect of whom

P3para.Text: a certificate under section 127(1) of this Act has effect; and
a condition under subsection (6) of that section requires

P4para.Text: that the patient be kept in the charge of an authorised person or reside continuously or for or at specified times at a specified place; or

that the patient, on being recalled or on the expiry of a specified period or on or after the occurrence of a specified event, return to the hospital in which the patient was detained under the order or go to such other place as may be specified,

P2para.Text: and who absconds from the charge of that authorised person or otherwise fails to comply with the condition is liable to be taken into custody and dealt with in accordance with section 303 of this Act.

A patient who is subject to a compulsory treatment order imposing a requirement that the patient reside at a specified place and who fails to comply with that requirement is liable to be taken into custody and dealt with in accordance with section 303 of this Act.

A patient who is subject to a compulsory treatment order imposing a requirement that the patient obtain the approval of the mental health officer to any proposed change of address and who changes address without having obtained that approval is liable to be taken into custody and dealt with in accordance with section 303 of this Act.
A patient who has been taken into custody under this section and who absconds from that custody remains liable to be taken into custody and dealt with in accordance with section 303 of this Act.

P1group.Title: Absconding etc. by other patients

P2para.Text: Subsection (2) below applies to a patient

P3para.Text: who is subject to

P4para.Text: an interim compulsory treatment order authorising detention;
a short-term detention certificate; or
a certificate under section 114(2) or 115(2) of this Act authorising continued detention;

P3para.Text: who is being detained in pursuance of an extension certificate or under the power conferred by section 68 of this Act;
to whom an emergency detention certificate applies; or
who is being detained in hospital under the power conferred by section 113(5) or 299 of this Act.

P2para.Text: A patient to whom this subsection applies and who absconds from

P3para.Text: any place where the patient is kept pending removal to hospital under the order or certificate; or
the hospital in which, under the order, certificate or, as the case may be, power, the patient is detained,

P2para.Text: is liable to be taken into custody and dealt with in accordance with section 303 of this Act.

A patient who is subject to an interim compulsory treatment order imposing a requirement that the patient reside continuously or for or at specified times at a specified place and who fails to comply with that requirement is liable to be taken into custody and dealt with in accordance with section 303 of this Act.
A patient who is subject to an interim compulsory treatment order authorising detention and in respect of whom

P3para.Text: a certificate under section 127(3) of this Act has effect; and
a condition under subsection (6) of that section requires

P4para.Text: that the patient be kept in the charge of an authorised person or reside continuously or for or at specified times at a specified place; or

that the patient, on being recalled or on the expiry of a specified period or on or after the occurrence of a specified event, return to the hospital in which the patient was detained under the order or go to such other place as may be specified,

P2para.Text: and who absconds from the charge of that authorised person or otherwise fails to comply with any such condition is liable to be taken into custody and dealt with in accordance with section 303 of this Act.
A patient who is subject to a short-term detention certificate in respect of whom

P3para.Text: a certificate under section 53(1) of this Act has effect; and
a condition under subsection (4) of that section requires

P4para.Text: that the patient be kept in the charge of an authorised person or reside continuously or for or at specified times at a specified place; or

that the patient, on being recalled or on the expiry of a specified period or on or after the occurrence of a specified event, return to the hospital in which the patient was detained under the certificate or go to such other place as may be specified,

P2para.Text: and who absconds from the charge of that authorised person or otherwise fails to comply with any such condition is liable to be taken into custody and dealt with in accordance with section 303 of this Act.
A patient who is subject to an emergency detention certificate in respect of whom

P3para.Text: a certificate under section 41(1) of this Act has effect; and
a condition under subsection (4) of that section requires

P4para.Text: that the patient be kept in the charge of an authorised person or reside continuously or for or at specified times at a specified place; or

that the patient, on being recalled or on the expiry of a specified period or on or after the occurrence of a specified event, return to the hospital in which the patient was detained under the certificate or go to such other place as may be specified,

P2para.Text: and who absconds from the charge of that authorised person or otherwise fails to comply with any such condition is liable to be taken into custody and dealt with in accordance with section 303 of this Act.

P1group.Title: Taking into custody and return of absconding patients

P2para.Text: A person specified in subsection (3)(a) below may, during the period specified in subsection (4) below

P3para.Text: take into custody any patient who, under sections 301 or 302 of this Act, is liable to be taken into custody;

return the patient to the hospital in which the patient was detained or, as the case may be, take the patient to the hospital in which the patient was to be detained or, if that is not appropriate or practicable, take the patient to any other place considered appropriate by the patients responsible medical officer;

return or take the patient to such other place as the patient absconded from or at which the patient failed to reside or, if that is not appropriate or practicable, take the patient to any other place considered appropriate by the patients responsible medical officer.

P2para.Text: The person specified in subsection (3)(b) below may, during the period specified in subsection (4) below

P3para.Text: take into custody any patient in respect of whom a certificate under section 41(1), 53(1) or 127(1) of this Act has effect and a condition under section 41(4), 53(4) or, as the case may be, 127(6) of this Act requires that the patient be kept in charge of that person and who, under section 301 or 302 of this Act is liable to be taken into custody; and
resume the charge of the patient or, if that is not appropriate or practicable, take the patient to any place considered appropriate by the patients responsible medical officer.

P2para.Text: The

P3para.Text: persons referred to in subsection (1) above are

P4para.Text: a mental health officer;
a constable;

a member of staff of any hospital and, where the patient liable to be taken into custody is subject to a compulsory treatment order or an interim compulsory treatment order a condition of which requires the patient to reside in an establishment the address of which is specified in the order, a member of staff of that establishment; and
any other person authorised for the purposes of that subsection by the patients responsible medical officer;

P3para.Text: person referred to in subsection (2) above is the person who is authorised under section 41(4), 53(4) or, as the case may be, 127(6) of this Act to have charge of the patient.

P2para.Text: The period referred to in subsection (1) above is

P3para.Text: in the case of a patient who is subject to a compulsory treatment order, the period of 3 months beginning with the day

P4para.Text: when the patient absconded; or
when the patients conduct or failure first gave rise to liability to be taken into custody;

P3para.Text: in any other case, the period ending with the expiry of the order, certificate, report or, as the case may be, provision under or in pursuance of which the patient was to be detained.

P2para.Text: The expiry, during the period referred to in subsection (1) above, of the authorised period in relation to the compulsory treatment order to which a patient is subject does not affect the powers conferred by this section.
The powers conferred by subsections (1) and (2) above include power to use reasonable force in their exercise.
A patient who is, under section 301 or 302 of this Act, liable to be taken into custody ceases to be so liable

P3para.Text: on returning to the hospital or other place from which the patient absconded or arriving at the hospital in which the patient was to be detained;
on being returned or taken either there or to such other place as is considered appropriate by the patients responsible medical officer under subsection (1)(b) or (c) or (2)(b) above; or
on being taken into custody under section 113 of this Act.

P1group.Title: Effect of unauthorised absence

P2para.Text: References in this section and sections 305 to 308 of this Act to a patients unauthorised absence are references to a patients being liable, under section 301 of this Act, to be taken into custody and dealt with under section 303 of this Act.

Subject to sections 305 to 308 of this Act, a patients unauthorised absence does not affect the continuity or measurement of any period of time fixed by, under or relative to any provision of this Act or requirement imposed by virtue of it, of which that absence is a breach.
Where, in the case of a patient who is subject to a compulsory treatment order, the patients unauthorised absence has continued for a period of 3 months, the order shall then cease to have effect.

P1group.Title: Effect of long unauthorised absence ending more than 14 days before expiry of compulsory treatment order

P2para.Text: Where the unauthorised absence of a patient who is subject to a compulsory treatment order

P3para.Text: lasted longer than 28 consecutive days; and
ceased before the beginning of the period of 14 days ending with the day when the compulsory treatment would, apart from this subsection, cease to authorise the measures specified in it,

P2para.Text: the order shall cease to have effect at the expiry of the period of 14 days beginning with the day when the patients unauthorised absence ceased.

The patients responsible medical officer shall, during the period of 14 days secondly referred to in subsection (1) above, carry out a review in respect of the compulsory treatment order to which the patient is subject by complying with the requirements set out in section 77(3) of this Act.

Where any part of the period of 14 days referred to in subsection (2) above occurs within the period of 2 months mentioned in subsection (5) of section 77 or subsection (3) of section 78 of this Act, the review which would (apart from this subsection) have been carried out during that period of 2 months under that section shall not be carried out.

The other review provisions (that is to say, section 83(2) and (3) and the subsequent provisions of Chapter 4 of Part 7 of this Act) shall, in accordance with subsections (5) and (6) below, apply in respect and in consequence of a review under this section as they apply in respect and in consequence of the reviews for which that Chapter provides.

Where the compulsory treatment order to which the patient is subject has not been extended as mentioned in section 78(1) of this Act, those of the other review provisions which relate to a first review apply.
Where that order has been so extended, those of the other review provisions which relate to a further review apply.

P1group.Title: Effect of unauthorised absence ending simultaneously with or within 14 days before expiry of compulsory treatment order

P2para.Text: Where the unauthorised absence of a patient who is subject to a compulsory treatment order

P3para.Text: ceases on the day that the order to which the patient is subject would, apart from this subsection, cease to authorise the measures specified in it; or
ceased within a period of 14 days ending with that day,

P2para.Text: the order shall be treated as having continued in effect and, subject to subsection (4) below, as continuing in effect until the end of the period of 14 days beginning with the day on which the patients unauthorised absence ceased.

The patients responsible medical officer shall, during the period of 14 days secondly referred to in subsection (1) above, carry out a review in respect of the compulsory treatment order to which the patient is subject by complying with the requirements set out in section 77(3) of this Act.

Where any part of the period of 14 days referred to in subsection (2) above occurs within the period of 2 months mentioned in subsection (5) of section 77 or subsection (3) of section 78 of this Act, the review which would (apart from this subsection) have been carried out during that period of 2 months under that section shall not be carried out.
Subsections (4) to (6) of section 305 of this Act apply for the purposes of a review under subsection (2) above as they apply for the purposes of a review under subsection (2) of that section.
Where

P3para.Text: the compulsory treatment order to which a patient is subject is, under this section, treated as continuing in effect; and
the patients unauthorised absence

P4para.Text: began at a time when a review of the order was being carried out under section 77 or 78 of this Act; and
lasted for 28 consecutive days or any shorter period,

P3para.Text: then anything done by the patients responsible medical officer for the purposes of that review which (apart from this subsection) would fall to be done for the purposes of a review under this section need not, for those latter purposes, be done.

P1group.Title: Effect of unauthorised absence ending after expiry of compulsory treatment order

P2para.Text: Where the unauthorised absence of a patient who is subject to a compulsory treatment order ceases

P3para.Text: within a period of 3 months beginning with the day on which it began; and
after the day when the compulsory treatment order to which the patient was subject would, but for this subsection, have ceased to authorise the measures specified in it,

P2para.Text: the order shall be treated as having continued in effect and, subject to subsection (3) below, as continuing in effect until the end of the period of 14 days beginning with the day on which the patients unauthorised absence ceased.

The patients responsible medical officer shall, during the period of 14 days referred to in subsection (1) above, carry out a review of the compulsory treatment order to which the patient is subject by complying with the requirements set out in section 77(3) of this Act.
Subsections (4) to (6) of section 305 of this Act apply for the purposes of a review under subsection (2) above as they apply for the purposes of a review under subsection (2) of that section.
Where

P3para.Text: the compulsory treatment order to which a patient is subject is, under this section, treated as continuing in effect; and
the patients unauthorised absence

P4para.Text: began at a time when a review of the order was being carried out under section 77 or 78 of this Act; and
lasted for 28 consecutive days or any shorter period,

P3para.Text: then anything done by the patients responsible medical officer for the purposes of that review which (apart from this subsection) would fall to be done for the purposes of a review under this section need not, for those latter purposes, be done.

P1group.Title: Effect of unauthorised absence of patient subject to short-term detention certificate or certificate under section 114(2) or 115(2)

P1para.Text: Where the unauthorised absence of a patient who is subject to a short-term detention certificate or a certificate under section 114(2) or 115(2) of this Act authorising continued detention ceases within the period of 13 days ending with the day on which the certificate would, but for this section, have ceased to authorise the measures specified in it, the certificate shall continue to authorise those measures until the end of the period of 14 days beginning with the day when the patients unauthorised absence ceased.

P1group.Title: Patients from other jurisdictions

P2para.Text: Regulations may make provision applying sections 301 to 303 of this Act to

P3para.Text: persons in Scotland who are subject to corresponding requirements or corresponding measures in England, Wales, Northern Ireland, the Isle of Man or the Channel Islands.

Text.Addition: persons in Scotland who are subject to corresponding requirements or corresponding measures in a member State of the European Union (apart from the United Kingdom).

P2para.Text: Regulations under subsection (1) above may make such modifications of those sections in that application as the Scottish Ministers think fit.

Text.Addition: Regulations may make provision applying specific provisions in Part 16 of this Act to persons to whom sections 301 to 303 of this Act apply by virtue of subsection (1) above.
Regulations under subsection (2ZA) above may make such modifications of that Part in that application as the Scottish Ministers think fit.
But regulations under subsection (2ZA) above may not
apply any of that Part to persons who are subject to requirements or measures corresponding only to detention in hospital in accordance with an emergency detention certificate, or
authorise medical treatment of the types mentioned in section 234(2) or 237(3) of this Act.
The reference in subsection (1) above to persons subject to corresponding requirements shall be construed in accordance with section 289(4) of this Act.

P2para.Text: The reference in subsection (1) above to persons subject to corresponding measures shall be construed in accordance with section 290(8) of this Act.

Title.Addition: Cross-border visits: leave of absence

Text.Addition: Regulations may make provision for and in connection with the keeping in charge of
a person who is subject to a corresponding suspension of detention in England, Wales, Northern Ireland, the Isle of Man or the Channel Islands.

Addition.Addition: a person who is subject to a corresponding suspension of detention in a member State of the European Union (apart from the United Kingdom).

Text.Addition: Those regulations may
make provision applying sections 301 to 303 of this Act to such persons;
make such modifications of those sections in that application as the Scottish Ministers think fit.
A person is subject to a corresponding suspension of detention in a territory if under the law of that territory

but for the leave of absence mentioned in paragraph (b), the person would be subject to measures corresponding or similar to detention in hospital authorised by virtue of this Act or the 1995 Act; and
the person has been granted a leave of absence subject to a condition corresponding or similar to the condition set out in section 127(6)(a) of this Act.

P1group.Title: Regulations as to absconding by other patients

P2para.Text: Regulations may provide as to

P3para.Text: the circumstances in which patients

P4para.Text: who are subject to any of the orders or directions mentioned in subsection (3) below; and
who abscond or fail to comply with requirements imposed on them by virtue of the orders or directions to which they are subject or otherwise by virtue of this Act or the 1995 Act,

P3para.Text: are to be liable to be taken into custody by specified persons;
the steps which may be taken by those persons upon their taking those patients into custody; and
the effect (whether upon the orders or directions to which those patients are subject or otherwise) of such absconding or failure.

P2para.Text: Regulations under subsection (1) above may include provision

P3para.Text: requiring patients' responsible medical officers to notify

P4para.Text: specified courts;

Text.Addition: specified prosecutors;

P4para.Text: the Commission;
the Scottish Ministers,

P3para.Text: of such absconding or failure;
authorising the use of reasonable force in the exercise of the powers conferred by virtue of subsection (1) above to take patients into custody and to take the steps referred to in that subsection;
for

P4para.Text: the review of those orders and directions; and
the authorisation of measures additional to or different from those authorised by them,

P3para.Text: in consequence of such absconding or failure;
corresponding to section 309 of this Act and any regulations which may be made under that section.

P2para.Text: The orders referred to in subsection (1) above are

P3para.Text: assessment orders;
treatment orders;
temporary compulsion orders made under section 54(1)(c) of the 1995 Act;
interim compulsion orders; and
compulsion orders,

P2para.Text: and the directions there referred to are hospital directions and transfer for treatment directions.

Text.Addition: In making provision as described in paragraphs (a) and (b) of subsection (1) above, regulations under that subsection may specify persons who are authorised by patients' responsible medical officers.

P2para.Text: In this section, specified means specified in the regulations.

P1group.Title: Non-consensual sexual acts
Offences under section 311: extended sentences
Persons providing care services: sexual offences
Notification requirements for offenders under sections 311 and 313
Ill-treatment and wilful neglect of mentally disordered person

P2para.Text: This section applies to a person (a relevant person) who

P3para.Text: is an individual employed in, or contracted to provide services in or to, a hospital;
not being the Scottish Ministers, is a manager of a hospital;
provides care services; or
is an individual who, otherwise than

P4para.Text: by virtue of a contract of employment or other contract with any person; or
as a volunteer for a voluntary organisation,

P3para.Text: provides care or treatment.

P2para.Text: A relevant person who

P3para.Text: whether under this Act or otherwise

P4para.Text: is providing care or treatment; or
purports to provide care or treatment,

P3para.Text: to a patient; and
ill-treats, or wilfully neglects, that patient,

P2para.Text: shall be guilty of an offence.
A person guilty of an offence under subsection (2) above shall be liable

P3para.Text: on summary conviction to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 6 months or to a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum or to both;
on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 5 years or to a fine or to both.

Text.Substitution: In subsection 1(c),
means anything done
by a care service,
by an employee of a care service, or
in the course of a service provided or supplied by a care service,
whether by virtue of a contract of employment or any other contract or in circumstances as may be prescribed by regulations.

Text.Addition: For the purposes of subsection (4),
means a service mentioned in section 47(1)(a), (b), (d), (f), (g), (j) or (m) of the Public Services Reform (Scotland) Act 2010.

P1group.Title: Inducing and assisting absconding etc.

P2para.Text: A person who knowingly

P3para.Text: induces or assists a patient to do or fail to do anything which results in the patients being liable under section 301 or 302 of this Act to be taken into custody and dealt with under section 303 of this Act; or
harbours a patient who has, with that result, done or failed to do anything ; or

Text.Addition: induces or assists a patient to abscond or to attempt to abscond or harbours a patient who absconds while that patient is being removed or transferred under regulations made under section
290 of this Act.

P2para.Text: shall be guilty of an offence.
Where a person is charged with an offence under subsection (1)(b) above, it shall be a defence for such person to prove that the doing of that with which the person is charged

P3para.Text: did not obstruct the discharge by any person of a function conferred or imposed on that person by virtue of this Act; and
was intended to protect the interests of the patient.

P2para.Text: A person guilty of an offence under this section shall be liable

P3para.Text: on summary conviction, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 6 months or to a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum or both;
on conviction on indictment, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 2 years or to a fine or both.

P2para.Text: The reference in subsection (1) above to sections 301 to 303 of this Act includes a reference to those sections as applied or as applied and modified under section 309 of this Act and to any regulations made under section 310 of this Act which make provision corresponding to sections 301 to 303 of this Act.

P1group.Title: Obstruction

P2para.Text: A person who

P3para.Text: refuses to allow a person authorised by virtue of this Act access to any premises;
refuses to allow access to a mentally disordered person by a person authorised by virtue of this Act to have such access;
refuses to allow the interview or examination of a mentally disordered person by a person authorised by virtue of this Act to interview or examine such person;
persists in being present when requested to withdraw by a person authorised by virtue of this Act to interview or examine, in private, a mentally disordered person;
refuses to produce any document or record to a person authorised by virtue of this Act to require the production of such document or record; or
otherwise obstructs a person in the exercise of any functions conferred on such person by virtue of this Act,

P2para.Text: shall be guilty of an offence.
A mentally disordered person shall not be guilty of an offence under subsection (1) above if the person mentioned in that subsection

P3para.Text: who is authorised by virtue of this Act, is so authorised; or
who is exercising functions conferred on that person by virtue of this Act, is exercising those functions,

P2para.Text: in relation to that mentally disordered person.

In any proceedings against a person for an offence under subsection (1) above it shall be a defence for the accused to show that the accused had a reasonable excuse for doing that with which the accused is charged.

A person guilty of an offence under subsection (1) above shall be liable on summary conviction to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 3 months or to a fine not exceeding level 3 on the standard scale or to both.

P1group.Title: False statements

P2para.Text: A person who

P3para.Text: knowingly makes, in a relevant document, an entry or statement which is false in a material particular; or
with intent to deceive, makes use of any such entry or statement knowing it to be false,

P2para.Text: shall be guilty of an offence.
For the purposes of subsection (1) above, a relevant document

P3para.Text: is

P4para.Text: an application under this Act;
a document accompanying any such application; or
any other document required or authorised to be granted, prepared, sent or given for any of the purposes of this Act; but

P3para.Text: does not include

P4para.Text: a nomination of a named person in accordance with section 250(2) of this Act;
an advance statement.

P2para.Text: A person guilty of an offence under this section shall be liable

P3para.Text: on summary conviction, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 6 months or to a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum or to both;
on conviction on indictment, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 2 years or to a fine or to both.

P1group.Title: Time limit for summary proceedings for offences under sections 311 and 313
Appeal to sheriff principal against certain decisions of the Tribunal

P2para.Text: This section applies to the following decisions of the Tribunal

P3para.Text: a decision under section 50(4) of this Act refusing an application for revocation of a short-term detention certificate;
