a decision under section 64(4)(a) or (b) of this Act making or refusing to make a compulsory treatment order;
a decision to make an interim compulsory treatment order under section 65(2) of this Act;
a decision to make an order under section 102(1)(c) or (d) of this Act confirming the determination of a patients responsible medical officer extending a compulsory treatment order;
a decision to make an order under section 103(1)(a) or (b) of this Act on an application by the patients responsible medical officer for an order extending and varying a compulsory treatment order;

a decision to make an order under section 103(2)(c) or (d) of this Act on an application for revocation of the determination of a patients responsible medical officer extending a compulsory treatment order;
a decision to make an order under section 103(3)(b) or (c) of this Act on an application under section 100(2)(a) of this Act to revoke a compulsory treatment order;
a decision to make an order under section 103(4)(a) of this Act on an application by a patients responsible medical officer to vary a compulsory treatment order;
a decision to make an order under section 103(4)(b) of this Act refusing an application under section 100(2)(b) of this Act to vary a compulsory treatment order;
a decision to make an order under section 104(1)(a) of this Act varying a compulsory treatment order;
a decision not to revoke under section 120(2) of this Act a certificate granted under section 114(2) or 115(2) of this Act;
a decision to make or refuse to make an order under section 125(5) or 126(5) of this Act preventing a transfer or requiring that a transferred patient be returned;
a decision to make an order under section 166(1)(c) or (d) of this Act confirming the determination of a patients responsible medical officer extending a compulsion order;
a decision to make an order under section 167(1)(a) of this Act on an application by the patients responsible medical officer for an order extending a compulsion order;
a decision to make an order under section 167(2)(a) or (b) of this Act on an application by the patients responsible medical officer for an order extending and varying a compulsion order;
a decision to make an order under section 167(3)(c) or (d) of this Act on an application for revocation of the determination of a patients responsible medical officer extending a compulsion order;
a decision to make an order under section 167(4)(b) or (c) of this Act on an application under section 164(2)(a) of this Act;
a decision to make an order under section 167(5)(a) of this Act on an application by a patients responsible medical officer to vary a compulsion order;
a decision to make an order under section 167(5)(b) of this Act refusing an application under section 164(2)(b) of this Act to vary a compulsion order;

a decision to make or refuse to make an order under section 257(2) of this Act declaring an acting named person not to be a named person or appointing a person to be a patients named person in place of an acting named person;
a decision to make an order under section 257(3) of this Act;
a decision, in relation to a patient who is not subject to a restriction order, a hospital direction or a transfer for treatment direction

P4para.Text: to make or refuse to make an order under section 264(2), 265(3) or 266(3) of this Act;
under section 267(2) of this Act to recall or refuse to recall an order made under section 264, 265 or 266 of this Act;
to make or refuse to make an order under section 268(2), 269(3) or 270(3) of this Act;
under section 271(2) of this Act to recall or refuse to recall an order made under section 268, 269 or 270 of this Act; and

P3para.Text: a decision granting or refusing an application for an order requiring the managers of the hospital to cease to detain a patient under section 291 of this Act.

P2para.Text: A relevant party to proceedings before the Tribunal may appeal to the sheriff principal against a decision to which this section applies.
An appeal to the sheriff principal under subsection (2) above shall be to the sheriff principal

P3para.Text: of the sheriffdom in which the person to whom the decision relates is resident at the time when the appeal is lodged;
where the person to whom the decision relates is detained in a hospital at the time when the appeal is lodged, of the sheriffdom in which the hospital is situated; or
in any other case, of any sheriffdom.

P2para.Text: If the sheriff principal to whom an appeal is made considers that the appeal raises an important or difficult question of law that makes it appropriate to remit the appeal to the Court of Session the sheriff principal may

P3para.Text: ex proprio motu; or
on the motion of any party to the appeal,

P2para.Text: do so.
Subject to subsections (6) to (9) below, in this section relevant party means

P3para.Text: the person to whom the decision relates;
that persons named person;
any guardian of the person;
any welfare attorney of the person;
the mental health officer; and
that persons responsible medical officer.

P2para.Text: Where the person to whom the decision relates is a person to whom subsection (7) below applies, relevant party means

P3para.Text: the person to whom the decision relates;
that persons named person;
any guardian of the person;
any welfare attorney of the person; and
the Scottish Ministers.

P2para.Text: This subsection applies to a patient who is subject to

P3para.Text: a compulsion order and a restriction order;
a hospital direction; or
a transfer for treatment direction.

P2para.Text: Where the appeal is against a decision mentioned in paragraph (w) of subsection (1) above, relevant party means

P3para.Text: the person to whom the decision relates;
that persons named person;
any guardian of the person;
any welfare attorney of the person;
the Commission; and
the relevant Health Board (within the meaning of section 273 of this Act).

P2para.Text: Where the appeal is against a decision mentioned in paragraph (x) of subsection (1) above, relevant party means

P3para.Text: the person to whom the decision relates;
that persons named person;
any guardian of the person;
any welfare attorney of the person;
the managers of the hospital; and
if the person who applied for the order does not fall within paragraphs (a) to (d) above, the person who applied for the order.

P1group.Title: Appeal to Court of Session against decisions of sheriff principal

P2para.Text: A relevant party to an appeal to the sheriff principal under section 320(2) of this Act may appeal to the Court of Session against the decision of the sheriff principal allowing or refusing the appeal.
In subsection (1) above, relevant party has the same meaning as in section 320 of this Act.

P1group.Title: Appeal to Court of Session against certain decisions of the Tribunal

P2para.Text: This section applies to the following decisions of the Tribunal

P3para.Text: a decision to make an order revoking a compulsion order under section 193(3) or (4) of this Act;
a decision to make an order revoking a restriction order under section 193(5) of this Act;
a decision to make an order varying a compulsion order under section 193(6) of this Act;
a decision to make an order conditionally discharging a patient under section 193(7) of this Act;
a decision, under section 193 of this Act, to make no order under that section;
a decision, under section 215(2) of this Act, to make no direction;
a decision to make a direction under section 215(3) or (4) of this Act;
a decision to make or refuse to make an order under section 219(5) or 220(5) of this Act preventing a transfer or requiring that a transferred patient be returned; and
a decision, in relation to a patient who is subject to a restriction order, a hospital direction or a transfer for treatment direction

P4para.Text: to make or refuse to make an order under section 264(2), 265(3) or 266(3) of this Act;
under section 267(2) of this Act to recall or refuse to recall an order made under section 264, 265 or 266 of this Act;
to make or refuse to make an order under section 268(2), 269(3) or 270(3) of this Act; or
under section 271(2) of this Act to recall or refuse to recall an order made under section 268, 269 or 270 of this Act.

P2para.Text: A relevant party to proceedings before the Tribunal may appeal to the Court of Session against a decision to which this section applies.
Subject to subsection (4) below, in this section relevant party means

P3para.Text: the person to whom the decision relates;
that persons named person;
any guardian of the person;
any welfare attorney of the person; and
the Scottish Ministers.

P2para.Text: Where the appeal is against a decision mentioned in paragraph (i) of subsection (1) above, relevant party means

P3para.Text: the person to whom the decision relates;
that persons named person;
any guardian of the person;
any welfare attorney of the person;
the Commission;
the relevant Health Board (within the meaning of section 273 of this Act); and
the Scottish Ministers.

P1group.Title: Suspension of decision of Tribunal pending determination of certain appeals

P2para.Text: Where the Scottish Ministers appeal under section 322(2) of this Act against any decision of the Tribunal under section 193 of this Act, or a decision of the Tribunal to make a direction under section 215(3) or (4) of this Act, the Court of Session may, on the motion of the Scottish Ministers, order

P3para.Text: that the patient in respect of whom the Tribunals decision was made shall continue, subject to subsection (2) below, to be detained; and

that both the compulsion order and restriction order or, as the case may be, the hospital direction or transfer for treatment direction to which the patient is subject shall continue to have effect accordingly.

P2para.Text: An order under subsection (1) above has the effect of continuing the patients detention

P3para.Text: in a case where no appeal is made to the Supreme Court against the decision of the Court of Session under section 322(2) of this Act, until the expiry of the time allowed to so appeal to the Supreme Court; or
in a case where such an appeal is made, until it is abandoned or finally determined.

P1group.Title: Appeals: general provisions

P2para.Text: An appeal

P3para.Text: to the sheriff principal under section 320(2) of this Act; or
to the Court of Session under section 322(2) of this Act,

P2para.Text: may be made only on one or more of the grounds mentioned in subsection (2) below.
The grounds referred to in subsection (1) above are

P3para.Text: that the Tribunals decision was based on an error of law;
that there has been a procedural impropriety in the conduct of any hearing by the Tribunal on the application;
that the Tribunal has acted unreasonably in the exercise of its discretion;
that the Tribunals decision was not supported by the facts found to be established by the Tribunal.

P2para.Text: The Tribunal may be a party to an appeal under section 320(2) or 322(2) and in any appeal from the decision of the sheriff principal under section 321(1).
The court may, where it considers it appropriate, order the Tribunal to be represented at any hearing of an appeal under section 320(2), 321(1) or 322(2).
In allowing an appeal under section 320(2), 321(1) or 322(2) of this Act the court

P3para.Text: shall set aside the decision of the Tribunal; and
shall

P4para.Text: if it considers that it can properly do so on the facts found to be established by the Tribunal, substitute its own decision; or
remit the case to the Tribunal for consideration anew.

P2para.Text: If the court remits a case under paragraph (b)(ii) of subsection (5) above, the court may

P3para.Text: direct that the Tribunal be differently constituted from when it made the decision; and
issue such other directions to the Tribunal about the consideration of the case as it considers appropriate.

P2para.Text: Regulations may specify the period within which an appeal under section 320(2), 321(1) or 322(2) of this Act shall be made.
In this section, the court means the sheriff principal or the Court of Session as the case may be.

P1group.Title: Power to prescribe forms

P1para.Text: Regulations may prescribe

P3para.Text: the form of any document that is required or authorised to be prepared by virtue of this Act; and
circumstances in which a form prescribed under paragraph (a) above for a document shall, or may, be used for the document.

P1group.Title: Orders, regulations and rules

P2para.Text: Any power conferred by this Act on the Scottish Ministers to make orders, regulations or rules shall be exercisable by statutory instrument.
Any power conferred by this Act on the Scottish Ministers to make orders, regulations or rules

P3para.Text: may be exercised so as to make different provision for different cases or descriptions of case or for different purposes; and
includes power to make such incidental, supplementary, consequential, transitory, transitional or saving provision as the Scottish Ministers consider appropriate.

P2para.Text: A statutory instrument containing an order, regulations or rules made under this Act (other than an order under section 333(2) or (3) of this Act) shall, subject to subsection (4) below, be subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of the Scottish Parliament.
A statutory instrument containing

P3para.Text: an order under section 240(5) or paragraph 2A(2) or 7A(4) of schedule 1 to this Act;
an order under section 330(1) of this Act containing provisions adding to, replacing or omitting any part of the text of an Act; or

P2para.Text: shall not be made unless a draft of the instrument has been laid before, and approved by resolution of, the Scottish Parliament.

P1group.Title: Directions

P2para.Text: Any power conferred by virtue of this Act to give a direction shall include power to vary or revoke the direction.
Any direction given by virtue of this Act shall be in writing.

P1group.Title: Meaning of mental disorder

P2para.Text: Subject to subsection (2) below, in this Act mental disorder means any

P3para.Text: mental illness;
personality disorder; or
learning disability,

P2para.Text: however caused or manifested; and cognate expressions shall be construed accordingly.
A person is not mentally disordered by reason only of any of the following

P3para.Text: sexual orientation;
sexual deviancy;
transsexualism;
transvestism;
dependence on, or use of, alcohol or drugs;
behaviour that causes, or is likely to cause, harassment, alarm or distress to any other person;
acting as no prudent person would act.

P1group.Title: Interpretation

P2para.Text: In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires

Para.Text: the 1995 Act means the Criminal Procedure (Scotland) Act 1995 (c. 46);
advance statement has the meaning given by section 275 of this Act;
approved medical practitioner has the meaning given by section 22(4) of this Act;
assessment order means an order made under section 52D(2) of the 1995 Act;

Text.Addition: care home service has the meaning given by

Addition.Substitution: paragraph 2 of schedule 12 to the Public Services Reform (Scotland) Act 2010

Text.Addition: asp 8;

Para.Text: care plan, in relation to a patient, means a plan prepared under subsection (1)(a) of section 76 of this Act; and includes a reference to a care plan amended by virtue of subsection (3) or (4)(a) of that section;
carer, in relation to a person, means an individual who, otherwise than
by virtue of a contract of employment or other contract with any person; or
as a volunteer for a voluntary organisation,

provides, on a regular basis, a substantial amount of care for, and support to, the person; and includes, in the case where the person is in hospital, an individual who, before the person was admitted to hospital, provided, on a regular basis, a substantial amount of care for, and support to, the person;
the Commission means the Mental Welfare Commission for Scotland;
community care services has the meaning given by section 12A(8) of the Social Work (Scotland) Act 1968 (c. 49);

Text.Substitution: means an order under section 57(2)(a) or 57A(2) of the 1995 Act;

Para.Text: compulsory treatment order means an order made under section 64(4)(a) of this Act;
designated medical practitioner has the meaning given by section 233(2) of this Act;
emergency detention certificate means a certificate granted under section 36(1) of this Act;
extension certificate means a certificate granted under section 47(1) of this Act;

guardian means a person appointed as a guardian under the Adults with Incapacity (Scotland) Act 2000 (asp 4) who has power by virtue of section 64(1)(a) or (b) of that Act in relation to the personal welfare of a person;
Health Board means a board constituted by order under section 2(1)(a) of the National Health Service (Scotland) Act 1978 (c. 29);
hospital means
any health service hospital (as defined in section 108(1) of the National Health Service (Scotland) Act 1978 (c. 29));
any independent health care service; or
any state hospital;
hospital direction means a direction made under section 59A of the 1995 Act;

Text.Substitution: independent health care service means any of the following
an independent hospital;
a private psychiatric hospital;
an independent clinic; or
an independent medical agency,
as each of those terms is defined in section
10F(2) of the

Para.Text: interim compulsory treatment order means an order made under section 65(2) of this Act;
local authority means a council constituted under section 2 of the Local Government etc. (Scotland) Act 1994 (c. 39);
managers, in relation to a hospital, means

in the case of a hospital vested in the Scottish Ministers for the purposes of their functions under the National Health Service (Scotland) Act 1978 (c. 29), the Health Board or Special Health Board responsible for the administration of the hospital;
in the case of a hospital vested in a National Health Service trust, the directors of the trust;

in the case of an independent health care service which is registered under section 10Q(1) of the National Health Service (Scotland) Act 1978 (c.29), the person identified under section10P(2)(b) of that Act in the application for registration; and
in the case of a state hospital

where the Scottish Ministers have delegated the management of the hospital to a Health Board, Special Health Board, National Health Service trust or the Common Services Agency for the Scottish Health Service, that Board, trust or Agency;
where the management of the hospital has not been so delegated, the Scottish Ministers;
medical practitioner means registered medical practitioner;
medical records has the meaning given by section 77(1) of the Regulation of Care (Scotland) Act 2001 (asp 8);
medical treatment means treatment for mental disorder; and for this purpose treatment includes
nursing;
care;
psychological intervention;
habilitation (including education, and training in work, social and independent living skills); and
rehabilitation (read in accordance with paragraph (d) above);

mental health officer means a person appointed (or deemed to be appointed) under section 32(1) of this Act, and the mental health officer, in relation to a patient, means a mental health officer having responsibility for the patients case;
mental health report has the meaning given by section 57(4) of this Act;
named person means the person (if any) who is, in relation to another person, that other persons named person by virtue of any of sections 250 to 254 and 257 of this Act;
National Health Service trust means a body established by order under section 12A(1) of the National Health Service (Scotland) Act 1978 (c. 29);
notice means notice in writing;
patient means a person who has, or appears to have, a mental disorder;
primary, in relation to a carer, means the individual who provides all, or most, of the care for, and support for, the person;
prison includes any prison other than a naval, military or air force prison;
recorded matter has the meaning given by section 64(4)(a)(ii) of this Act;
regulations means regulations made by the Scottish Ministers;
relevant services has the meaning given by section 20(2) of the Children (Scotland) Act 1995 (c. 36);
restriction order means an order made under section 59 of the 1995 Act;
short-term detention certificate means a certificate granted under section 44(1) of this Act;
Special Health Board means a board constituted by order under section 2(1)(b) of the National Health Service (Scotland) Act 1978 (c. 29);
state hospital means a hospital provided under section 102(1) of the National Health Service (Scotland) Act 1978 (c. 29);

Text.Addition: means an order made under section 54(1)(c) of the 1995 Act;

Para.Text: transfer for treatment direction has the meaning given by section 136 of this Act;
treatment order means an order made under section 52M of the 1995 Act;
the Tribunal means the Mental Health Tribunal for Scotland;

Text.Addition: means representations made under section 17B of the Criminal Justice (Scotland) Act 2003 in relation to the matter being considered;

Para.Text: voluntary organisation means a body, other than a public or local authority, the activities of which are not carried on for profit;

welfare attorney means an individual authorised, by a welfare power of attorney granted under section 16 of the Adults with Incapacity (Scotland) Act 2000 (asp 4) and registered under section 19 of that Act, to act as such; and
young offenders institution has the same meaning as in the Prisons (Scotland) Act 1989 (c. 45).

P2para.Text: In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires, a reference to the Tribunal is, where the power conferred by paragraph 7(1) of schedule 2 is exercised, to be construed as a reference to the tribunal concerned.
References in this Act to the giving of medical treatment to a person include references to medical treatment being performed on a person.

Text.Substitution: References in this Act to a patients responsible medical officer are references to the approved medical practitioner who is for the time being
appointed under section 230(1) or (3)(a) of this Act; or
authorised under section 230(3)(b) of this Act,
in respect of the patient.

P1group.Title: Supplementary provisions etc.

P2para.Text: The Scottish Ministers may by order make such supplementary, incidental or consequential provision as they consider appropriate for the purposes of, in consequence of, or for giving full effect to, any provision of this Act.
An order under subsection (1) above may modify any enactment (including this Act).

P1group.Title: Minor and consequential amendments, repeals and revocations

P2para.Text: Schedule 4 to this Act, which contains minor amendments and amendments consequential on the provisions of this Act, shall have effect.
The enactments mentioned in Part 1 of schedule 5 to this Act (which include provisions that are spent) are hereby repealed to the extent specified in the second column of that schedule.
The enactments mentioned in Part 2 of schedule 5 to this Act (which include provisions that are spent) are hereby revoked to the extent specified in the second column of that schedule.

Text.Addition: Notwithstanding the repeal in respect of sections 1, 125, 128 and 129 of the Mental Health (Scotland) Act
in schedule 5 to this Act, those sections shall continue to have effect for the purposes of sections 10 and 95 of that Act.

P1group.Title: Transitional provisions etc.

P2para.Text: Schedule 6 to this Act (which contains certain transitory amendments of the Mental Health (Scotland) Act 1984) shall have effect.

The Scottish Ministers may by order make such other provision as they consider necessary or expedient for transitory, transitional or saving purposes in connection with the coming into force of any provision of this Act.

P1group.Title: Short title and commencement

P2para.Text: This Act may be cited as the Mental Health (Care and Treatment) (Scotland) Act 2003.
Chapter 3 of Part 17 of this Act shall come into force on 1st May 2006 or such earlier day as the Scottish Ministers may by order appoint.
The remaining provisions of this Act, other than this section and sections 325, 326, 330 and 332, shall come into force on such day as the Scottish Ministers may by order appoint.
Different days may be appointed under subsection (2) or (3) above for different purposes.

TitleBlock.Title: The Mental Welfare Commission for Scotland

P1para.Text: The Commission shall not be regarded as the servant or agent of the Crown, or as having any status, immunity or privilege of the Crown, nor shall its members or employees be regarded as civil servants, nor its property as property of, or held on behalf of, the Crown.

The Commission may do anything which appears to it to be necessary or expedient for the purposes of, or in connection with, the exercise of its functions; and without prejudice to that generality the Commission may in particular

P3para.Text: acquire and dispose of land and other property; and
enter into contracts.

Text.Addition: The Commission is to consist of the following members
a person appointed by the Scottish Ministers to chair the Commission; and
no fewer than
other members appointed by the Scottish Ministers.
The Scottish Ministers may by order amend sub-paragraph (1)(b) by substituting for the minimum or maximum number of members for the time being specified there such other number as they think fit.

P2para.Text: In appointing members, the Scottish Ministers are to have regard to the desirability of including

P3para.Text: persons who have experience of, and have shown capacity and capability in, the provision of services to those who have a mental disorder;
persons who use, or have used, such services;
persons who are, or have been, carers of those who have a mental disorder;
persons who have such other skills, knowledge or experience as the Scottish Ministers consider to be relevant in relation to the exercise of the Commission's functions.

P2para.Text: In appointing members under paragraph 2A(1)(b), the Scottish Ministers must appoint at least

P3para.Text: one person who falls within paragraph (b) of sub-paragraph (1) of this paragraph; and
one person who falls within paragraph (c) of sub-paragraph (1) of this paragraph ...

Text.Addition: Each member of the Commission is to be appointed for such period as the Scottish Ministers think fit.
A member
holds and vacates office in accordance with the terms and conditions of appointment; but
may, by written notice to the Scottish Ministers, resign office as a member.
A person is, on ceasing to be a member, eligible for reappointment.
The Scottish Ministers may, by written notice, remove a member from office if they are satisfied that
the member
has been adjudged bankrupt;
has granted a trust deed for creditors or a composition contract;
has proposed a voluntary arrangement which has been approved;
the member's estate has been sequestrated;
the member has been absent from 3 consecutive meetings of the Commission without the permission of the Commission;
the member is otherwise unfit or unable to discharge the functions of a member.
A person is disqualified from appointment, and from holding office, as a member of the Commission if that person is
a member of the Scottish Parliament;
a member of the House of Commons;
a member of the European Parliament.

P1para.Text: The Commission shall pay

P3para.Text: to its members (and to the members of its committees and sub-committees who are not members of the Commission) such remuneration and allowances

P4para.Text: on such terms; and
subject to such conditions,

P3para.Text: as the Scottish Ministers may determine;
to, or in respect of, persons who have been a member of it (or such members of committees and sub-committees as are mentioned in paragraph (a) above) such pensions, allowances and gratuities

P4para.Text: on such terms; and
subject to such conditions,

P3para.Text: as the Scottish Ministers may determine; or
to any person who ceases, other than on the expiry of a term of office, to be a member of it, such compensation as the Scottish Ministers may determine.

Pblock.Title: Appointment etc. of chief executive and other staff

P2para.Text: Subject to sub-paragraphs (2) and (3) below and paragraph 10A, the Commission

P3para.Text: shall appoint a chief executive ; and
may appoint such other staff as it considers appropriate,

P2para.Text: on such terms and conditions as it may, with the approval of the Scottish Ministers, determine.
A member of the Commission may not be appointed as a member of its staff.
The Commission shall obtain the approval of the Scottish Ministers before appointing a chief executive.

The Commission may pay to the members of its staff, including its chief executive, (referred to in this paragraph collectively as employees) such remuneration and allowances as the Scottish Ministers may determine.
The Commission may

P3para.Text: pay, or make arrangements for the payment of;
make payments towards the provision of; and
provide and maintain schemes (whether contributory or not) for the payment of,

P2para.Text: such pensions, allowances and gratuities to or in respect of such of its employees, or former employees, as the Scottish Ministers may determine.

The reference in sub-paragraph (5) above to pensions, allowances and gratuities includes a reference to pensions, allowances and gratuities by way of compensation for loss of employment or reduction in remuneration.
A determination under sub-paragraph (4) or (5) above may make different provision for different cases or descriptions of case.

Text.Addition: The Commission must appoint such staff, employed under paragraph 7(1)(a) or (b), to exercise the functions of Commission Visitors; and when doing so those staff are to be known as Commission Visitors.

The Commission may arrange for such other persons as it thinks fit to be appointed as and exercise the functions of Commission Visitors; and when doing so those persons are to be known as Commission Visitors.
There may be no more than 10 Commission Visitors appointed by the Commission under sub-paragraph (2).
The Scottish Ministers may by order amend sub-paragraph (3) by substituting for the maximum number of Commission Visitors for the time being specified there such other number as they think fit.
In appointing Commission Visitors, the Commission is to have regard to the desirability of appointing
persons who have experience of, and have shown capacity and capability in, the provision of services to those who have a mental disorder;
persons who use, or have used, such services;
persons who are, or have been, carers of those who have a mental disorder;
persons who have such other skills, knowledge or experience as the Commission considers to be relevant in relation to the exercise of the functions of Commission Visitors.
In appointing Commission Visitors, the Commission must appoint at least
one person who falls within paragraph (b) of sub-paragraph (5); and
one person who falls within paragraph (c) of sub-paragraph (5).

In this Act (unless the context otherwise requires), any reference to a function of a Commission Visitor (or the functions of Commission Visitors) is a reference to a function conferred by this Act or any other enactment.
The arrangements entered into by virtue of paragraph 7A(2) may include provision with respect to the payment of remuneration and allowances to, or amounts in respect of, such persons.
Persons appointed as Commission Visitors by virtue of paragraph 7A(2) are not members of staff of the Commission.

In appointing Commission Visitors, the Commission must appoint one or more persons who have such qualifications, training and experience as may be prescribed by regulations for the purposes of carrying out the functions of Commission Visitors under section 15 of this Act.
Persons so appointed may also be known as Medical Visitors.
The Commission may establish committees for any purpose relating to its functions.
Subject to sub-paragraph (7), the Commission is to determine the composition of its committees.
The Commission may appoint persons who are not members of the Commission to be members of a committee.
A committee of the Commission is to comply with any directions given to it by the Commission.
The Commission must establish at least one committee (an advisory committee) for the purpose of giving advice to it about matters connected to its functions.
In considering how to exercise its functions, the Commission must have regard to relevant advice and information given to it by any advisory committee (whether or not given at its request).
An advisory committee must include persons of a description as may be prescribed by regulations.
The Commission may determine its own procedure and that of its committees, including a quorum for meetings.
The validity of any proceedings of the Commission, or any of its committees, is not affected by a vacancy in membership nor by any defect in the appointment of a member.

Members of the Scottish Executive and persons authorised by the Scottish Ministers may attend and take part in meetings of the Commission or any of its committees, but are not entitled to vote at such meetings.
A member of the Commission may not
exercise the functions of a Commission Visitor;
be appointed as a Commission Visitor.
The chief executive may not be a member of the Commission.
A member of staff of the Commission (other than a Commission Visitor) may not exercise the functions of a Commission Visitor.
An appointment as a Commission Visitor under paragraph 7A(1) does not affect the appointed person's
status as employed under paragraph 7(1)(a) or (b); or
ability to perform the duties of the person as so employed.
The Commission may, subject to sub-paragraphs (2), (3) and (4), authorise
the chief executive;
any other employee;
any of its committees,
to exercise such of its functions, and to such extent, as it may determine.
The Commission may not authorise any of the following functions to be exercised by any other person
the functions of the Commission under section 12 (investigations: further provision);

the approval of any acquisition or disposal of land or other property with a value greater than 50,000 or such other amount as the Commission may, with the consent of the Scottish Ministers, determine;
the approval of annual reports and accounts;
the approval of any budget or other financial plan.
Any function conferred on a Commission Visitor may not be delegated by the Commission.
Sub-paragraph (1) does not affect the responsibility of the Commission for the exercise of its functions.
The chief executive may, with the consent of the Commission, authorise
any other employee;
any of the Commission's committees,
to exercise such of the chief executive's functions, and to such extent, as the chief executive, with such consent, may determine.
Sub-paragraph (5) does not affect the responsibility of the chief executive for the exercise of the chief executive's functions.

Emphasis.Addition: Mandatory delegation of functions to chief executive

Text.Addition: The Commission must delegate to the chief executive the functions mentioned in sub-paragraph (2).
The functions are
the Commission's functions relating to the discharge of patients under this Act;
the Commission's functions under section 73 of the Adults with Incapacity (Scotland) Act 2000 (asp 4).
When exercising those functions so delegated, the chief executive must
consult the Commission;
consult a Commission Visitor in every case in which it appears to the chief executive appropriate to do so;
have regard to any relevant guidance issued by the Commission.
Sub-paragraph (1) does not affect the responsibility of the Commission for the exercise of its functions.
The Commission's determination of the location of its office premises is subject to the approval of the Scottish Ministers.

Pblock.Title: Regulations as to proceedings and delegation of functions

P1para.Text: The following provisions of the National Health Service (Scotland) Act 1978 (c. 29) shall continue to apply to the Commission as they apply to a Special Health Board

P3para.Text: section 85 (which makes provision for payment of funds by the Scottish Ministers towards expenditure attributable to performance of functions by the Board);
section 85A(1) and (3) (which imposes corresponding financial duties on the Board); and
section 86 (which provides for the keeping, transmission to Scottish Ministers and auditing, of accounts).

P2para.Text: The Mental Health (Scotland) Act 1984 (c. 36) shall be amended as follows.
In section 2 (membership etc. of the Mental Welfare Commission)

P3para.Text: after subsection (5), insert

P2para.Text: The person who holds the post of chief officer of the Mental Welfare Commission shall

P3para.Text: be a member ex officio of the Commission; and
cease automatically to hold office as such member on ceasing to hold that post.
in subsection (7), for the said commissioners, in both places where it occurs, substitute commissioners appointed under subsection (4) of this section .

P2para.Text: In section 6 (appointment and payment etc. of officers and staff)

P3para.Text: at the beginning, insert

P2para.Text: The Mental Welfare Commission shall appoint a chief officer on such terms and conditions as the Scottish Ministers may determine.
Before appointing a chief officer under subsection (1) above, the Commission shall obtain the approval of the Scottish Ministers.

P3para.Text:
in subsection (3)
(being the existing wording of the section)

P4para.Text: in paragraph (a), after appoint, insert other ; and
in paragraph (b)(ii), after of, insert its chief officer or in respect of .

Text.Addition: The person who, immediately before the coming into force of this paragraph, holds (by virtue of paragraph 7) the post of chief officer of the Commission becomes the first chief executive of the Commission.
But if
there is no person holding that post immediately before the coming into force of this paragraph; or
the person holding the post immediately before the coming into force of this paragraph is unwilling or unable to be the chief executive,
the Scottish Ministers are to make the first appointment of the chief executive of the Commission on such terms and conditions as the Scottish Ministers may determine.
Each subsequent chief executive is appointed in accordance with paragraph 7.
Where sub-paragraph (1) applies, the person becoming the first chief executive of the Commission does so on the terms and conditions which applied to the post of chief officer held by that person.

Any person who, immediately before the coming into force of this paragraph, is a member of the Commission (including any ex officio members) by virtue of paragraph 3 ceases automatically to hold office as such a member.

TitleBlock.Title: The Mental Health Tribunal for Scotland

P2para.Text: The Scottish Ministers shall appoint as members of the Tribunal

P3para.Text: a panel of persons who have such legal

P4para.Text: qualifications;
training; and
experience,

P3para.Text: as may be prescribed in regulations for the purposes of serving as legal members of the Tribunal;
a panel of persons who have such qualifications, training and experience

P4para.Text: in medicine; and
in the diagnosis and treatment of mental disorder,

P3para.Text: as may be prescribed in regulations for the purposes of serving as medical members of the Tribunal; and
a panel of persons who have

P4para.Text: such qualifications, training, skills and experience in caring for, or providing services to, persons having a mental disorder; or
experience of such description,

P3para.Text: as may be prescribed in regulations for the purposes of serving as general members of the Tribunal.

P2para.Text: A person is disqualified from appointment as, and being, a member of the Tribunal if the person

P3para.Text: is a member of the Scottish Parliament;
is a member of the Scottish Executive or a junior Scottish Minister; or
is of such other description as may be prescribed in regulations.

P1para.Text: There shall be a panel consisting of each person who for the time being holds the office of

P3para.Text: sheriff principal;
sheriff; or
part-time sheriff,

P1para.Text: for the purposes of serving as sheriff conveners of the Tribunal.

P2para.Text: The Scottish Ministers shall appoint a person to be known as the President of the Mental Health Tribunal for Scotland (the President).
The President

P3para.Text: shall preside over the discharge of the Tribunals functions; and
may serve as a convener of the Tribunal.

P2para.Text: The Scottish Ministers may not appoint a person to be the President unless that person has such

P3para.Text: qualifications;
training; and
experience,

P2para.Text: as may be prescribed by regulations.
The following provisions of this schedule apply (with the necessary modifications) to the President as they apply to a member of the Tribunal

P3para.Text: paragraph 1(2);
paragraph 4;
paragraph 5; and
paragraph 6.

P2para.Text: The functions of the President may, if the President is absent or otherwise unable to act, be discharged by one of the members of the panel mentioned in paragraph 1(1)(a) above appointed for that purpose by the Scottish Ministers.
Regulations may make provision as to the delegation by the President of any of the Presidents functions to any of the members of the Tribunal or its staff.
Regulations made under sub-paragraph (6) above may include provision for different functions to be delegated to different persons for different areas.
Subject to this paragraph and paragraph 5 below, each member of the Tribunal shall hold office in accordance with the terms of such members instrument of appointment.
An appointment as a member of the Tribunal shall, subject to sub-paragraphs (3) and (4) below, last for 5 years.
A member of the Tribunal

P3para.Text: may at any time resign office by notice to the Scottish Ministers;
shall vacate office on becoming disqualified from being a member of the Tribunal by virtue of paragraph 1(2) above.

P2para.Text: A member of the Tribunals appointment shall come to an end upon the members being removed from office under paragraph 5(1) below.

A member of the Tribunal whose appointment comes to an end by operation of sub-paragraph (2) above may be reappointed and, except in the circumstances set out in sub-paragraph (6) below, shall be reappointed.
The circumstances referred to in sub-paragraph (5) above are that

P3para.Text: the member of the Tribunal has declined that reappointment;
the President has made a recommendation to the Scottish Ministers against the reappointment;
there has, since the member of the Tribunal was last appointed, been a reduction in the number of members of the panel to which the member belongs required by the Tribunal to discharge its functions;
since the member of the Tribunal was last appointed, the member has, without reasonable excuse, failed to comply with the terms of the members appointment; or

the member of the Tribunal does not have such qualifications, training, skills or experience as are for the time being prescribed under paragraph 1(1) above for appointment to the panel to which the member of the Tribunal belongs.

P2para.Text: A member of the Tribunal may be removed from office only by order of the disciplinary committee constituted under sub-paragraph (3) below.

The disciplinary committee may order the removal from office of a member of the Tribunal only if, after investigation carried out at the request of the Scottish Ministers, it finds that the member is unfit for office by reason of inability, neglect of duty or misbehaviour.
The disciplinary committee shall consist of

P3para.Text: a Senator of the College of Justice or a sheriff principal (who shall preside);
a person who is a solicitor or an advocate of at least ten years' standing; and
one other person,

P2para.Text: all appointed by the Lord President of the Court of Session.
Regulations

P3para.Text: may make provision

P4para.Text: enabling the disciplinary committee, at any time during an investigation, to suspend a member of the Tribunal from office; and
as to the effect and duration of such suspension; and

P3para.Text: shall make such further provision as respects the disciplinary committee (including in particular provision for the procedure of the committee) as the Scottish Ministers consider necessary or expedient.

P2para.Text: The Scottish Courts and Tribunals Service must pay, or make provision for paying, to, or in respect of, each member of the Tribunal such remuneration, expenses, pensions, allowances and gratuities (including by way of compensation for loss of office) as the Scottish Ministers may determine.

Sub-paragraph (1) above, so far as relating to pensions, allowances and gratuities, shall not have effect in relation to persons to whom Part I of the Judicial Pensions and Retirement Act 1993 (c. 8) applies, except to the extent provided by virtue of that Act.

Part.Title: Organisation and administration of the Tribunal

Pblock.Title: Organisation and administration of the functions of the Tribunal

P2para.Text: The functions of the Tribunal shall be discharged by such number of tribunals as may be determined from time to time by the President.
The Tribunal shall sit at such times and in such places as the President may determine.
Subject to sub-paragraph (4) below, and to any rules made under paragraph 10(1) below, a tribunal constituted under sub-paragraph (1) above shall consist of

P3para.Text: a convener who shall be

P4para.Text: the President; or
a member selected by the President from the panel mentioned in paragraph 1(1)(a) above; and

P3para.Text: a member selected by the President from each of the panels mentioned in paragraph 1(1)(b) and (c) above.

P2para.Text: In relation to proceedings (other than excepted proceedings) before the Tribunal in relation to a patient subject to a compulsion order and a restriction order, a hospital direction or a transfer for treatment direction, the convener shall be

P3para.Text: the President; or
a person selected by the President from the panel mentioned in paragraph 2 above.

Text.Addition: For the purpose of sub-paragraph (4) above, the following are excepted proceedings
proceedings relating solely to an application under section 255 or 256 of this Act, or
proceedings relating to an application for a compulsory treatment order in respect of a patient subject to
a hospital direction, or
a transfer for treatment direction.

P2para.Text: Subject to the provisions of this Act, regulations made under section 21 of this Act and rules made under paragraph 10 below, the President shall secure that the functions of the Tribunal are discharged efficiently and effectively.
The President may

P3para.Text: give such directions; and
issue such guidance,

P2para.Text: about the administration of the Tribunal as appear to the President to be necessary or expedient for the purpose of securing that the functions of the Tribunal are discharged efficiently and effectively.

The persons mentioned in sub-paragraph (4) below shall, in so far as it is reasonably practicable to do so, provide, in response to a request by the President, accommodation for the holding of hearings by the Tribunal.
The persons referred to in sub-paragraph (3) above are

P3para.Text: a Health Board;
the State Hospitals Board for Scotland;
a local authority.

P1para.Text: Such expenses of the Tribunal as the Scottish Ministers may determine shall be defrayed by the Scottish Ministers.

P2para.Text: The Scottish Ministers may make rules as to the practice and procedure of the Tribunal.
Such rules may, without prejudice to the generality of sub-paragraph (1) above, include provision for or in connection with

P3para.Text: the composition of the Tribunal for the purposes of its discharge of particular functions;
where the functions of the Tribunal are being discharged by more than one tribunal

P4para.Text: determining by which tribunal any proceedings are to be dealt with; and
transferring proceedings from one tribunal to another;

P3para.Text: the form of applications to the Tribunal;
the recovery and inspection of documents;
the persons who may appear on behalf of the parties;
enabling specified persons other than the parties to appear or be represented in specified circumstances;
requiring specified persons to give notice to other specified persons of specified matters in such form and by such method as may be specified;
as to the time within which any notice by virtue of sub-paragraph (g) above shall be given;
enabling any matters that are preliminary or incidental to the determination of proceedings to be determined by the convener alone or with such other members of the Tribunal as may be specified;
enabling hearings to be held in private;

enabling the Tribunal (or the convener, with such other members of the Tribunal as may be specified, as the case may be) to exclude the person to whom the proceedings relate from attending all or part of hearings;

enabling specified proceedings or specified matters that are preliminary or incidental to the determination of proceedings to be determined in specified circumstances without the holding of a hearing;
enabling the Tribunal to hear and determine concurrently two or more sets of proceedings relating to the same person;
the recording, publication and enforcement of decisions and orders of the Tribunal;
the admissibility of evidence to the Tribunal;
enabling matters to be referred to the Commission;
enabling the Tribunal to commission medical and other reports in specified circumstances;

requiring specified proceedings, or specified matters that are preliminary or incidental to the determination of proceedings, to be determined, or other specified actions to be taken, within specified periods;
the circumstances in which a curator ad litem may be appointed.

P2para.Text: In sub-paragraph (2) above, specified means specified in the rules.

P1para.Text: Subject to rules made under paragraph 10 above the President may give directions as to the practice and procedure to be followed by the Tribunal in relation to any matter.

P2para.Text: The Tribunal may by citation require any person to attend, at such time and place as is specified in the citation, for the purpose of

P3para.Text: giving evidence; or
producing any document in the custody, or under the control, of such person which the Tribunal considers it necessary to examine.

P2para.Text: In relation to persons giving evidence the Tribunal may administer oaths and take affirmations.
A person who is cited to attend the Tribunal and

P3para.Text: refuses or fails

P4para.Text: to attend; or
to give evidence; or

P3para.Text: alters, conceals or destroys, or refuses to produce, a document which such person may be required to produce for the purposes of proceedings before the Tribunal,

P2para.Text: shall, subject to sub-paragraph (4) below, be guilty of an offence.

A person need not give evidence or produce any document if, were it evidence which might be given or a document that might be produced in any court in Scotland, the person having that evidence or document could not be compelled to give or produce it in such proceedings.
It shall be a defence for a person charged with contravening sub-paragraph (3) above to show that the person has a reasonable excuse for such contravention.
A person guilty of an offence under sub-paragraph (3)(a) above shall be liable on summary conviction to a fine not exceeding level 5 on the standard scale.
A person guilty of an offence under sub-paragraph (3)(b) above shall be liable

P3para.Text: on summary conviction to a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum;
on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 2 years or a fine or both.

P2para.Text: Subject to sub-paragraph (2) below, where a decision is to be made by more than one member of the Tribunal, the decision of the Tribunal shall be made by majority.
If there is a tie, the convener shall have a second vote as a casting vote.
A decision of the Tribunal shall be recorded in a document which contains a full statement of the facts found by the Tribunal and the reasons for the decision.
The Tribunal shall

P3para.Text: inform each party of its decision; and
as soon as practicable after completion of the document mentioned in sub-paragraph (3) above, send a copy to each party.

Title.Addition: Withdrawn applications to be disregarded for certain purposes

P2para.Text: The President shall, in respect of each period of 12 months beginning on 1st April, prepare a written report as to the Tribunals discharge of its functions during that period.
The President shall submit each report prepared under sub-paragraph (1) above, as soon as practicable after the period to which it relates, to the Scottish Ministers.
The Scottish Ministers shall lay before the Scottish Parliament a copy of each report submitted to them under sub-paragraph (2) above.

P1para.Text: The President shall, at such times and in respect of such periods as the Scottish Ministers may specify, provide to

P3para.Text: the Scottish Ministers;
such persons as the Scottish Ministers may specify,

P1para.Text: such information relating to the discharge of the Tribunals functions as the Scottish Ministers may direct.

Pblock.Title: Allowances etc. for attendance at hearings of the Tribunal and preparation of reports

P2para.Text: The Tribunal may pay to any person (other than a member of the Tribunal or a member of the staff of the Tribunal) such allowances and expenses as the President shall determine for the purposes of, or in connection with, the persons attendance at hearings of the Tribunal.

The Tribunal may pay to any person (other than a member of the Tribunal or a member of the staff of the Tribunal) such amounts as the President shall determine in connection with any report prepared by the person in accordance with rules made under paragraph 10(2)(q) above.

TitleBlock.Title: Application of Chapter 1 of Part 7 to certain patients

P1para.Text: Section 57(3) of this Act shall have effect as if, for paragraph (e), there were substituted the following

P3para.Text: that it will be necessary, immediately after the hospital direction or, as the case may be, transfer for treatment direction to which the patient is subject ceases to have effect, for the patient to be subject to a compulsory treatment order.

Text.Addition: In the case of a patient subject to a hospital direction or a transfer for treatment direction, section 60(1) of this Act shall have effect as if, after paragraph (b), there were inserted
to the Scottish Ministers;

P2para.Text: Section 64(4)(a)(i) of this Act shall have effect subject to the following

P3para.Text: where a compulsory treatment order is made in respect of a patient who is subject to

P4para.Text: a hospital direction; or
a transfer for treatment direction,

P3para.Text: that order shall authorise the measures specified in it only if the direction to which the patient is subject ceases, by virtue of section 217(2) of this Act, to have effect before the expiry of the period of 28 days beginning with the day on which the order is made; and
where

P4para.Text: a compulsory treatment order is made in respect of such a patient; and
the direction to which the patient is subject ceases, by virtue of section 217(2) of this Act, to have effect before the expiry of the period of 28 days mentioned in sub-sub-paragraph (a) above,

P3para.Text: the compulsory treatment order shall authorise the measures specified in it for the period of 6 months beginning with the day on which that direction ceases to have effect.

P2para.Text: Section 64(5) shall have effect as if, for paragraph (e), there were substituted

P3para.Text: that it will be necessary, immediately after the hospital direction or, as the case may be, transfer for treatment direction to which the patient is subject ceases to have effect, for the patient to be subject to a compulsory treatment order.

P1para.Text: Section 65 of this Act shall not have effect.

(Scotland) Act 2003 (asp 13) .

(compliance by local authorities with directions by Scottish Ministers in exercise of functions under certain Acts), for paragraph (k) substitute

the Mental Health (Care and Treatment)
(Scotland) Act 2003 (asp 13);

P2para.Text:

(local authority plans for community care services), in the definition of community care services, for the words from section 7 to 1984 substitute section 25 (provision of care and support services for persons who have or have had a mental disorder), 26 (provision of services designed to promote well-being and social development of such persons) or 27 (assistance with travel in connection with such services) of the Mental Health (Care and Treatment)

(provision by local authorities of residential and other establishments etc.), for the words section 13A substitute sections 12 and 13A .

In section 86(1)

P2para.Text:
In section 94(1)
(interpretation), for the definition of mental health officer substitute

P3para.Text:
mental health officer means a person appointed under subsection (1) of section 32 of the Mental Health (Care and Treatment)
(Scotland) Act 2003 (asp 13); and includes a person deemed, by virtue of subsection (3) of that section, to be so appointed;

P1para.Text: In section 64(5) of the Local Government (Scotland) Act 1973 (enactments concerning appointment of officers continuing to have effect), for paragraph (bb) substitute

P3para.Text: section 32 of the Mental Health (Care and Treatment) (Scotland) Act 2003 (asp 13);

P1para.Text: In section 102(1) of the National Health Service (Scotland) Act 1978 (duty of Scottish Ministers to provide state hospitals)

P3para.Text: after the word under insert the Criminal Procedure (Scotland) Act 1995 (c. 46) or ; and

for the words Mental Health (Scotland) Act 1984 substitute Mental Health (Care and Treatment)

Pblock.Title: The Disabled Persons (Services, Consultation and Representation) Act 1986 (c.33)

P2para.Text: The Disabled Persons (Services, Consultation and Representation) Act 1986 shall be amended as follows.

In section 2(5)(b)
(right of authorised representative to visit disabled person in accommodation provided by virtue of certain enactments), for the words section 7 of the 1984 Act substitute section 25 of the 2003 Act .

In section 16(1)
(interpretation)

P3para.Text: for the definition of the 1984 Act substitute

the 2003 Act means the Mental Health (Care and Treatment)
(Scotland) Act 2003 (asp 13);
in paragraph (b) of the definition of the welfare enactments, for the words sections 7 and 8 of the 1984 Act substitute sections 25 and 26 of the 2003 Act .

P1para.Text: In Part II of Schedule 1 to the Tribunals and Inquiries Act 1992 (tribunals under the supervision of the Scottish Committee of the Council on Tribunals), after paragraph 54 insert

tr.td: 54A. The Mental Health Tribunal for Scotland constituted under section 21 of the Mental Health (Care and Treatment) (Scotland) Act 2003 (asp 13).

Pblock.Title: The Prisoners and Criminal Proceedings (Scotland) Act 1993 (c.9)

P1para.Text:
In section 4(1) of the Prisoners and Criminal Proceedings (Scotland) Act 1993 (persons detained under the Mental Health (Scotland) Act 1984 (c. 36) by virtue of transfer direction and restriction direction), for the words from first direction to given, substitute for treatment direction under section 136(2) of the Mental Health (Care and Treatment)
(Scotland) Act 2003 (asp 13) is made .

In section 23(2) of the Children (Scotland) Act 1995 (children affected by disability), for the words from suffers to the end substitute has a mental disorder (as defined in section 328(1) of the Mental Health (Care and Treatment)

P2para.Text: The Criminal Procedure (Scotland) Act 1995 shall be amended as follows.
In section 54 (insanity in bar of trial)

P3para.Text: in paragraph (c) of subsection (1)

P2para.Text: The conditions referred to in subsection (1)(c)(i) above are

P1group.Title: Hospital direction

P2para.Text: This section applies where a person, not being a child, (in this section and in sections 59B and 59C of this Act referred to as the offender) is convicted on indictment in

P3para.Text: the High Court; or
the sheriff court,

P2para.Text: of an offence punishable by imprisonment.
If the court is satisfied

P3para.Text: on the written or oral evidence of two medical practitioners

P4para.Text: that the conditions mentioned in subsection (3) below are met in respect of the offender; and
as to the matters mentioned in subsection (4) below; and

P3para.Text: that, having regard to the matters mentioned in subsection (5) below, it is appropriate,

P2para.Text: the court may, in addition to any sentence of imprisonment which it has the power or the duty to impose, make, subject to subsection (6) below, a direction (in this Act referred to as a hospital direction) authorising the measures mentioned in subsection (7) below.
The conditions referred to in subsection (2)(a)(i) above are

P3para.Text: that the offender has a mental disorder;
that medical treatment which would be likely to

P4para.Text: prevent the mental disorder worsening; or
alleviate any of the symptoms, or effects, of the disorder,

P3para.Text: is available for the offender;
that if the offender were not provided with such medical treatment there would be a significant risk

P4para.Text: to the health, safety or welfare of the offender; or
to the safety of any other person; and

P3para.Text: that the making of a hospital direction in respect of the offender is necessary.

P2para.Text: The matters referred to in subsection (2)(a)(ii) above are

P3para.Text: that the hospital proposed by the two medical practitioners mentioned in subsection (2)(a) above is suitable for the purpose of giving the medical treatment mentioned in paragraph (b) of subsection (3) above to the offender; and
that, were a hospital direction made, the offender could be admitted to such hospital before the expiry of the period of 7 days beginning with the day on which the direction is made.

P2para.Text: The matters referred to in subsection (2)(b) above are

P3para.Text: the mental health officers report, prepared in accordance with section 59B of this Act, in respect of the offender;
all the circumstances, including

P4para.Text: the nature of the offence of which the offender was convicted; and
the antecedents of the offender; and

P3para.Text: any alternative means of dealing with the offender.

P2para.Text: A hospital direction may authorise detention in a state hospital only if, on the written or oral evidence of the two medical practitioners mentioned in subsection (2)(a) above, it appears to the court

P3para.Text: that the offender requires to be detained in a state hospital under conditions of special security; and
that such conditions of special security can be provided only in a state hospital.

P2para.Text: The measures mentioned in subsection (2) above are

P3para.Text: in the case of an offender who, when the hospital direction is made, has not been admitted to the specified hospital, the removal, before the expiry of the period of 7 days beginning with the day on which the direction is made, of the offender to the specified hospital by

P4para.Text: a constable;

a person employed in, or contracted to provide services in or to, the specified hospital who is authorised by the managers of that hospital to remove persons to hospital for the purposes of this section; or
a specified person;

P3para.Text: the detention of the offender in the specified hospital; and
the giving to the offender, in accordance with Part 16 of the Mental Health (Care and Treatment) (Scotland) Act 2003 (asp 13), of medical treatment.

P2para.Text: The court shall be satisfied as to the condition mentioned in subsection (3)(a) above only if the description of the offenders mental disorder by each of the medical practitioners mentioned in subsection (2)(a) above specifies, by reference to the appropriate paragraph (or paragraphs) of the definition of mental disorder in section 328(1) of the Mental Health (Care and Treatment) (Scotland) Act 2003 (asp 13), at least one type of mental disorder that the offender has that is also specified by the other.
A hospital direction

P3para.Text: shall specify, by reference to the appropriate paragraph (or paragraphs) of the definition of mental disorder in section 328(1) of the Mental Health (Care and Treatment) (Scotland) Act 2003 (asp 13), the type (or types) of mental disorder that each of the medical practitioners mentioned in subsection (2)(a) above specifies that is also specified by the other; and

may include such directions as the court thinks fit for the removal of the offender to, and the detention of the offender in, a place of safety pending the offenders admission to the specified hospital.

P2para.Text: In this section

Para.Text: medical treatment has the same meaning as in section 52D of this Act; and
specified means specified in the hospital direction.

P1group.Title: Hospital direction: mental health officers report

P2para.Text: This section applies where the court is considering making a hospital direction in relation to an offender under section 59A of this Act.
If directed to do so by the court, the mental health officer shall

P3para.Text: subject to subsection (3) below, interview the offender; and
prepare a report in relation to the offender in accordance with subsection (4) below.

P2para.Text: If it is impracticable for the mental health officer to comply with the requirement in subsection (2)(a) above, the mental health officer need not do so.
The report shall state

P3para.Text: the name and address of the offender;
if known by the mental health officer, the name and address of the offenders primary carer;
in so far as relevant for the purposes of section 59A of this Act, details of the personal circumstances of the offender; and
any other information that the mental health officer considers relevant for the purposes of that section.

P2para.Text: In this section, carer, primary, in relation to a carer, and mental health officer have the same meanings as in section 57C of this Act.

P1group.Title: Hospital direction: supplementary

P2para.Text: If, before the expiry of the period of 7 days beginning with the day on which a hospital direction is made, it appears to the court, or, as the case may be, the Scottish Ministers, that, by reason of emergency or other special circumstances, it is not reasonably practicable for the offender to be admitted to the hospital specified in the hospital direction, the court, or, as the case may be, the Scottish Ministers, may direct that the offender be admitted to such other hospital as is specified.
Where

P3para.Text: the court makes a direction under subsection (1) above, it shall inform the person having custody of the offender; and
the Scottish Ministers make such a direction, they shall inform

P4para.Text: the court; and
the person having custody of the offender.

P2para.Text: Where a direction is made under subsection (1) above, the hospital direction shall have effect as if the hospital specified in the hospital direction were the hospital specified by the court, or, as the case may be, the Scottish Ministers, under subsection (1) above.
In this section, court means the court which made the hospital direction.
